content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Thursday’s session are Supervalu Inc., Men’s Wearhouse Inc. and VeriFone Systems Inc. Thursday’s roster of companies scheduled to report quarterly financial results includes Hovnanian Enterprises Inc. HOV, +0.55% Hooker Furniture Corp. HOFT, +1.66% Mattress Firm Holding Corp. MFRM Cherokee Inc. CHKE, +1.96% Cooper Cos. COO, +1.63% Met-Pro Corp. MPR Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% Lannett Co. LCI, +5.59% Ulta Beauty ULTA, -0.41% Quiksilver Inc. ZQK Layne Christensen Co. LAYN, +3.54% UTi Worldwide Inc. UTIW, +0.74% Smith & Wesson Holding Corp. SWHC  and Descartes Systems Group Inc. DSGX, +2.70% among others. TimeSUPERVALU Inc.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:SVU $20.0 $15.0 $17.5 Supervalu SVU, -1.42%  will close some 60 stores that it characterized as “underperforming or non-strategic,” a majority of which are expected to be shut down before Dec. 1. Two of the stores had been previously targeted for closure. A total of 27 Albertsons stores will be closed — 19 in Southern California and the rest located elsewhere in the western U.S. Another 22 are Save-A-Lot locations, Minneapolis-based Supervalu said. The closings reflect management’s “commitment to move with a greater sense of urgency to reduce costs and improve shareholder value,” said Wayne Sales, president, chief executive and chairman, in a statement. The move will mean a pre-tax charge of $80 million to $90 million to be taken against Supervalu’s results for fiscal 2013; $3 million will be for estimated severance costs and the rest will be non-cash. Supervalu also said it will include a pre-tax gain of about $10 million from the sale of assets in results for the second quarter of fiscal 2013. The company estimated that the store closings will “be accretive to net earnings” and yield $80 million to $90 million in cash from selling off real estate, asset disposals and elimination of cash operating losses. The cash generated from these actions will be used by Supervalu to reduce outstanding debt, among other things. Citing constrained supplies in NAND flash memory, OCZ Technology Group Inc. OCZ, +0.00%  said it won’t meet management’s prior forecast for second-quarter sales. As revised, the San Jose-based data-storage company now sees sales in a range of $110 million to $120 million for the three months ended Aug. 31. This would be lower than the previously projected $130 million to $140 million and would come in well shy of analysts’ consensus $134.4 million forecast. OCZ will formally report results for the second quarter of fiscal 2013 on Oct. 3. Also late Wednesday, Men’s Wearhouse MW  raised its financial forecast for fiscal 2013 as the Houston-based retailer reported modestly higher earnings and sales for the second quarter ended July 28. Reflecting expectations for stronger sales growth in both the third and fourth quarters, management pegged earnings in a range of 95 cents to 98 cents a share in the current quarter, followed by swinging to an estimated profit of 12 cents to 15 cents a share in the fourth quarter. For the full fiscal year, management now sees Men’s Wearhouse generating earnings of $2.74 to $2.80 a share, which would be 15% to 18% higher than what it earned on an adjusted basis in the prior fiscal year. Fidelity National Financial Inc. FNF, +0.53%  agreed to raise the price of its tender offer for J. Alexander’s Corp. JAX, +4.09% the Nashville-based operator of casual dining restaurants, to $14.50 a share, up from $13 a share previously. J. Alexander’s said its board unanimously approved the parties’ amended merger agreement and recommends that stockholders tender their shares into the offer, which will be extended for at least 10 business days until Sept. 19. A majority of the total number of J. Alexander’s shares outstanding must be tendered for the offer to become effective. The transaction’s expected to close in the fourth quarter. Snyder’s-Lance Inc. LNCE  announced a deal to acquire Snack Factory LLC and certain affiliates, agreeing to pay 340 million in cash for the producer of Pretzel Crisps crackers. The acquisition will contribute, excluding transaction-related costs, 2 cents a share to earnings in 2012, followed by about 10 cents a share in 2013, Charlotte-based Snyder’s-Lance said. Snack Factory also is expected to add about $160 million to estimated net revenue for 2013. With the deal, Snyder’s-Lance said it will gain entry into the deli-bakery section of grocery stores and add a “fast- growing, differentiated national core brand to our existing portfolio.” It’s expected to close early in the fourth quarter. Terms of the acquisition include about $60 million of net present value of future tax benefits, Snyder’s-Lance said. TimeM/I Homes Inc.15 Jan29 Jan12 Feb26 Feb12 Mar26 Mar US:MHO $30.0 $32.5 $35.0 $37.5 M/I Homes Inc. MHO, +1.92%  priced at $17.63 each a public offering of 2.2 million common shares. The sale will run concurrently with a $50 million public offering of five-year convertible senior subordinated notes. The initial conversion rate on the notes has been set at 42.0159 common shares per $1,000 principal amount, equal to a conversion price of about $23.80 a share. The notes will pay interest semi-annually in arrears at a rate of 3.25% a year. Underwriters will have the option of buying up to 330,000 additional shares and up to $7.5 million of the notes if investors demand warrants. Neither the notes offering nor the equity offering will be conditioned upon consummation of the other. Net proceeds from the offerings will be used for general corporate purposes, which may include land acquisition and development, home construction, capital expenditures, working capital and debt repayment, Columbus, Ohio-based M/I Homes said. Zillow Inc. Z, +0.62%  will make a secondary offering of 3.5 million Class A shares, with existing stockholders seeking to sell about 9% of the shares going up for sale. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, the Seattle-based online real-estate firm said. It marks Zillow’s first stock offering since going public in July 2011. Underwriters have the option of buying of 525,000 shares if warranted by investor demand. BreitBurn Energy Partners LP BBEP  said it’s commenced a public offering of 10 million common units. Net proceeds will be put to use repaying outstanding debt under its revolving credit facility, BreitBurn said. BreitBurn also said underwriters will have a 30-day greenshoe to buy up to 1.5 million additional common units, which represent limited-partner interests in the Los Angeles-based partnership. Warner Chilcott PLC WCRX  said certain selling stockholders plan on making a secondary offering of ordinary shares. The Dublin-based identified the sellers as members of senior management as well as funds affiliated with J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, +1.82%  and private-equity houses Thomas H. Lee and Bain Capital. No terms of the offering, including the number of shares to be put up for sale, were announced. Warner Chilcott said it will receive no proceeds. Wednesday earnings recap VeriFone Systems PAY, -0.52%  reported a profit of $37.7 million, or 34 cents a share, for the third quarter ended July 31, up from $26.3 million, or 28 cents, earned in the same period during fiscal 2011. Quarterly revenue reached $489.1 million from the prior year’s $317 million. Backing out one-time items, the San Jose-based company specializing in electronic-payments technology would have earned 75 cents a share for the latest quarter. The consensus of analysts polled by FactSet Research had been for VeriFone to earn 70 cents a share on $495 million in revenue. However, the company also forecast earnings of 75 cents to 77 cents a share on an adjusted basis for the fourth quarter, on revenue pegged at $495 million to $500 million. These compare with consensus estimates of 74 cents a share and $520.9 million, respectively. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Thursday: Supervalu, OCZ, VeriFone

content: WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) — Among the stocks that could see active trade in Friday’s session are Texas Instruments Inc., Dendreon Corp. and Tessera Technologies Inc. It’s a thin calendar for earnings reports Friday, with Kroger Co. KR, +1.35% Lululemon Athletica Inc. LULU, +3.68% Ocean Power Technologies Inc. OPTT, -0.93%  and Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97%  scheduled to release quarterly results. Citing “broadly lower demand across a wide range of products, markets and customers,” Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94%  revised lower its financial forecast for the third quarter after Thursday’s close. Management now expects earnings in a range of 56 cents a share to 60 cents a share; the prior forecast had been for 55 cents a share to 65 cents a share. TI also pegged quarterly revenue in a range of $3.23 billion to $3.37 billion, down from $3.4 billion to $3.7 billion previously. As part of a previously announced restructuring, Dendreon DNDN  said it would lay off 500 employees as a result of lower-than-expected sales of Provenge, the biotech company’s new therapy for treating prostate cancer. The cuts, concentrated among manufacturing workers, amount to about about 25% of the company’s headcount. Dendreon also said Hans Bishop is leaving as chief operating officer. Tessera Technologies TSRA  issued an update on projected revenue for the third quarter. Revenue are expected to be about $60 million, which would be down from both $82.1 million generated in the year-ago third quarter and $70.7 million in the second quarter of 2011. The company cited in part “the impact of volume pricing adjustments” for its Tessera Inc. subsidiary. Also late Thursday, Kohl’s Corp. KSS, +1.47%  notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that it needs an extension on the deadline for filing its second-quarter financial results. The retailer’s working through previously reported errors in its accounting for both store and equipment leases, with plans to record additional property and financing obligations on its balance sheet. The corrections won’t have an impact on the net increase or decrease in cash and cash equivalents, Kohl’s said. The company now expects to file first- and second-quarter results as well as a restated 2010 annual report by no later than Sept. 13. Reporting performance results for August, United Continental Holdings Inc. UAL, +2.30%  said both revenue passenger miles and load factor decreased compared to the same month in 2010. On a consolidated basis, RPMs flown on domestic and international routes for August fell 2.7%, while load factor dropped to 85.7% from 86.6%. Figures for August 2010 are pro forma for the merger of United Airlines and Continental Airlines. Dollar General Corp. DG, +0.66%  priced a public offering of 25 million common shares at a price of $34.75 each. The greenshoe granted to underwriters is for an additional 3.75 million shares if demand warrants. Certain existing stockholders are selling the shares under the offering, expected to close Sept. 14. The deep discounter said it will not receive any proceeds from the offering. The board of Warnaco Group Inc. WRC, -7.60%  approved the repurchase of up to $200 million in outstanding common stock. As of Aug. 31, Warnaco completed its previously announced 2010 share-buyback program, under which 5 million shares were repurchased, the New York-based apparel company said. The board of HollyFrontier Corp. HFC, +2.73%  authorized the repurchase of up to $100 million in common stock. Buybacks under this program will be made in the open market or through privately negotiated transactions, the company said. Thursday earnings recap Ulta Salon Cosmetics & Fragrance Inc. ULTA, -0.41%  reported above-consensus results for the second quarter and forecast continued strong performance for the third quarter. In the three months ended July 30, Ulta posted a profit of $23.9 million, or 38 cents a share, up from $13.1 million, or 22 cents, earned in the year-earlier second quarter, as sales jumped 23% to $394.6 million and same-store sales increased 11.3%. For the third quarter, Ulta pegged projected earnings in a range 36 cents to 38 cents a share on sales of $400 million to $407 million. Korn/Ferry International KFY, +0.47%  reported a profit of $15.4 million, or 33 cents a share, for the first quarter ended July 31, up from $10.9 million, or 24 cents, earned in the year-earlier three months. The latest profit was the midpoint of a range that the executive-search company had forecast in June. And for the second quarter, Korn/Ferry’s looking to generate earnings of 30 cents to 36 cents a share on fee revenue of $192 million to $210 million. The consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters stands at 35 cents a share and $201 million, respectively. title: Stocks to watch Friday: TI, Dendreon, Tessera

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies made notable moves Friday in the U.S. stock market: Advancers Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% shares rose 6.2% after the chemical manufacturer reported a profitable fourth quarter. Allos Therapeutics Inc. ALTH shares gained 6.8% after the biotech group on Thursday said it would present data on its lung cancer drug at a meeting next month. American Eagle Outfitters Inc. AEO, +1.37% shares climbed 6.6% after a regulatory filing showed the company's chairman on Wednesday purchased 500,000 shares in the clothing retailer. KV Pharmaceutical Co. KV shares rallied 74% after the drug developer said U.S. regulators approved the return to market of its potassium medicine. Lululemon Athletica Inc. LULU, +3.68% shares rose 13% after the Canadian seller of yoga clothes hiked its 2010 outlook. The Medicines Co. MDCO, -0.84% shares climbed 6% after it said APP Pharmaceuticals LLC won't be allowed to appeal its court win involving a patent term. Moody's Corp. MCO, +1.48% shares picked up 5.9% after Piper Jaffray Cos. upgraded the credit-rating firm from neutral to overweight. Transocean Ltd. RIG, +1.43% shares advanced 6.4% after news it would appeal a Swiss regulator's decision to block it from paying a large dividend and after FBR Capital Markets said the rig owner's liability for the Gulf of Mexico oil spill could be less than the market has already discounted. Decliners Capstead Mortgage Corp. CMO, -0.12% fell 6.4% after the real-estate investment trust trimmed its third-quarter dividend. National Semiconductor Corp. NSM, -0.28% shares fell 6.4% after the maker of analog chips for electronic devices projected second-quarter sales beneath estimates. PG&E Corp. PCG, +1.60% shares dropped 8.4% after a fatal explosion in San Bruno, Calif., where the holding company for Pacific Gas and Electric Co. provides natural-gas service. Smith & Wesson Holding SWHC shares fell 7.8% after the handgun maker forecast second-quarter sales beneath Wall Street expectations. title: Friday's biggest gaining and declining stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO - Among the stocks that might make notable moves on Friday are Campbell Soup Co., Abbott Laboratories and Pericom Semiconductor Corp. Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% is projected to post fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 11 cents a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. Campbell Soup Co. CPB, -0.23% is expected to post fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 26 cents a share. Frequency Electronics Inc. FEIM, +0.92% is forecast to post a fiscal first-quarter loss of 4 cents a share. Immersion Corp. IMMR, +1.70% is expected to post a second-quarter loss of 26 cents a share. Pericom Semiconductor Corp. PSEM is forecast to post fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 3 cents a share. After Thursday's bell, Abbott Laboratories ABT, +1.16% said it will acquire the 90% of Evalve Inc. it does not already own for $320 million in cash. Evalve makes devices used to repair heart valves in a minimally invasive manner. Abbott said it will also pay an additional $90 million if certain regulatory milestones are met. Abbot expects the transaction to close in the fourth quarter. Watch List General Mills Inc. GIS, +1.60% said Thursday its profit for its just-ended quarter came in ahead of its internal target, helped by lower food-ingredient and manufacturing costs compared to last year, while sales matched its expectations. Also, the company plans to increase spending on media advertisements by double-digits over the next 12 months to promote its cereals and snacks. Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% lifted the wraps on a new smart phone Thursday that the company hopes will lead its turnaround effort and better compete in a marketplace dominated by well-known rivals such as the iPhone and the BlackBerry. Morgan Stanley MS, +1.98% said Thursday that its chief executive, John Mack, will turn over the title to co-president, James Gorman, at the start of next year. Mack will remain chairman of the firm, and London-based co-President Walid Chammah will become chairman of Morgan Stanley International. National Semiconductor Corp. NSM, -0.28% forecast second-quarter sales to rise roughly 3% to 8% sequentially, or a range of about $325 million to $340 million on Thursday. Analysts polled by FactSet Research currently expect the company to report sales of $316.4 million. The company said its first-quarter net earnings dropped to $29.8 million, or 13 cents a share, on a 32% fall in revenue. title: Stocks in focus for Friday

content: Xerox: MPI Tech awarded $89M by Canada tribunal in dispute (6:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Xerox Corp. XRX, -0.24% said MPI Technologies Inc. has been awarded $89 million by a Canadian arbitration panel in its dispute with Xerox and its Xerox Canada Ltd. unit, according to a filing late Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The dispute stems from a 1994 license agreement. Xerox expects to take a pre-tax charge of $89 million plus interest in the third quarter. The Stamford, Conn.-based company plans to seek a judicial review of the decision. Books-A-Million lowers 3Q, FY 2006 forecast post-Katrina (6:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Books-A-Million Inc. BAMM said after Friday's closing bell that it has lowered its forecast for third-quarter and fiscal 2006 earnings to reflect the impact of Hurricane Katrina on its sales. The Birmingham, Ala.-based retailer said it has closed 15 stores temporarily as a result of the hurricane and experienced lower-than-expected sales. Looking ahead, Books-A-Million forecast a third-quarter net loss of 6 cents to 9 cents a share, down from its previous estimate of a net loss of 1 cent to 3 cents a share. The company also lowered its fiscal 2006 net earnings estimate to 68 cents to 71 cents a share, down from its previous estimate of 73 cents to 77 cents a share. Delta Petroleum to delay 10-K filing with SEC (2:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Delta Petroleum Corp. DPTR said Friday that it will delay the filing of its Form 10-K for fiscal year 2005 with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Denver-based energy exploration and development company said it was delaying the filing to complete matters required in connection with Section 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. Delta said it expects to file its annual report within the extension period. Source Interlink shares fall as co.'s earns miss by 2c (2:14 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Source Interlink Cos. SORC shares fell 9% to $10.91 on Friday after the Bonita Springs, Fla., provider of family entertainment CD and DVD products reported pro forma earnings of $6.1 million, or 12 cents a share, for the second quarter, missing the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by 2 cents. Looking ahead, the company reaffirmed its outlook for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $85 million to $90 million in fiscal 2006. Systemax restates 2004 earnings following accounting errors (1:04 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Systemax Inc. SYX, +0.18% on Friday restated its financial results for the year ended Dec. 31, 2004, following the discovery of errors in accounting for inventory at its Tiger Direct Inc. subsidiary. Port Washington, N.Y.-based Systemax restated its 2004 net earnings to $10.6 million, or 30 cents a share, vs. the previously reported $12.6 million, or 35 cents a share. The distributor and manufacturer of PC hardware-related computer products and industrial products posted 2004 revenue of $1.927 billion vs. the previously reported $1.928 billion. Quantum Fuel Systems' shares off on wider than expected loss (12:03 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies Worldwide Inc. QTWW fell 10.2% to $4.07 on Friday after the Irvine, Calif., fuel systems manufacturer posted a loss of $8.1 million, or 15 cents a share, wider than its year-ago loss of $2.4 million, or 8 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 15 cents a share in the July period. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $47.4 million from $6.4 million in the same period a year earlier, but the performance was slightly below Wall Street's consensus estimate of $47.6 million. The company attributed the wider loss to a shortfall in development program-related revenue, as well as higher than expected costs in this business. Terex to restate results for 2 quarters, adding income (9:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Terex Corp. TEX, +2.13% said Friday it would restate net income for the quarters ended March 31, 2004 and June 30, 2004, adding $2.4 million and $7.4 million, respectively. The Westport, Conn., construction and industrial manufacturer said the difference was a result of a valuation allowance change in its U.S. tax assessment. Shares of Terex rose about 2% early Friday to $49.11. Wells Gardner sees wider than expected FY05 loss (8:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Wells-Gardner Electronics Corp. WGA Friday said it expects a loss of $2.2 million to $2.8 million, or 25 to 32 cents a share, for fiscal 2005. This outlook includes charges of $650,000, or 8 cents a share. The Chicago maker of color video monitors said this loss estimate its $700,000 wider than its prior projection. "Margin improvement is proving to be a slower process than we had originally expected," said Anthony Spier, the company's chairman and CEO. The stock closed Thursday at $2.04, down 3.8%. Build A Bear Workshop reaffirms FY05 profit outlook (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Build A Bear Workshop BBW, -1.61% Friday reaffirmed its outlook for fiscal 2005, backing its projections for a profit of $25.1 million to $26.3 million, or $1.24 to $1.30 a share, with same-store sales coming in flat. The St. Louis gift bear maker said its financial results weren't materially affected by Hurricane Katrina. The stock closed Thursday at $19.86, down 16 cents. Genomic Health sets IPO price range (8:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Genomic Health, Inc. on Friday set an estimated price range of $12-$14 a share for its initial public offering. With 5.02 million shares in the offering, the Redwood City, Calif. developer of genomic-based clinical diagnostic tests for cancer will raise about $65 million with underwriters JP Morgan and Lehman Brothers. The company plans to trade on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "GHDX." Diodes sees Q3 sequential revs growth at high end of range (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Diodes Inc. DIOD, +0.00% Friday said it expects revenue for the third quarter to come in at the high end of its previous projection for sequential growth of 1% to 5%. The Westlake Village, Calif., chip maker expects gross margins to be comparable with its second-quarter performance. The stock closed Thursday at $37.90, down 2 cents. LSI Industries adjusts results by 2c a share (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- LSI Industries Inc. LYTS, +0.50% on Friday said it lowered its operating results for the year ended June 30 by 2 cents a share to 73 cents a share. The adjustment came after the company changed the distribution method for its deferred compensation plan. LSI recorded a $469,000 non-cash net of tax expense and a similar net long-term liability to reflect the market price of the company's common shares on June 30. Shares of LSI fell 16 cents to $17.05 on Thursday. Aceto tops Wall St. view by penny (8:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% Friday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.79 million, or 11 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, the Lake Success, N.Y., drug and chemical distributor posted a profit of $2.84 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter. Sales slipped in the latest three months to $73.7 million from $76.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 10 cents a share in the June period. The stock closed Thursday at $7.44, down 4%. Biovail wins FDA OK for Tramadol ER (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Biovail Corp. VRX, +2.65% on Friday said the Food and Drug Association cleared it to market once-daily Tramadol ER and that it's in talks with a potential partner to do so. The company did not name the marketing partner. The Toronto company anticipates the commercial launch of Tramadol ER to occur in early 2006. The drug is used to treat pain. Shares ose 19 cents to $18.27 on Thursday. Geac Comp. earns, rev. decline, miss expectations (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Geac Computer GEAC reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $11.3 million, or 13 cents a share, down from $13.5 million, or 15 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 16 cents a share. Revenue fell to $103.7 million from last year's $106.9 million, missing analyst forecasts of $107.9 million, as declines in software and support and services revenue offset a rise in hardware revenue. The company said it plans to buy back up to $35 million worth of its common stock. The shares closed Thursday up 8 cents at $10.12. Continental still sees significant 2005 loss (6:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% said it still sees a significant loss for 2005 due to record high fuel prices, despite improving revenue trends. In a statement filed at the Securities and Exchange Commission, the airline said it expects $300 million in savings from pay and benefit reductions during 2005. Continental, which said it doesn't have any fuel hedges, sees ending the third quarter of 2005 with an unrestricted cash and short-term investments balance between $1.9 billion and $2.0 billion and ending the year with approximately $1.5 billion. McCarthy & Stone sees satisfactory fiscal year result (2:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Retirement home builder McCarthy & Stone(UK:MCTY)said Friday that it is expecting to report a satisfactory set of fiscal 2005 results, after it sold a lower number of units at a higher average selling prices during the year. The company sold 1,983 units, down from 2,055 a year ago, at an average selling price of 163,500 pounds, compared to 154,300 pounds a year ago. McCarthy & Stone said it is carrying forward 255 reservations into its new fiscal year, compared to 440 last year. "The market continues to be tougher than the group has experienced in recent years but the board is encouraged by visitor levels," it said. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Albertson's ABS, +1.81% shares ended Friday's session higher by 7.9%. The move comes after The Daily Deal reported that several large private equity firms have expressed interest in the Boise, Idaho-based supermarket operator, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberst & Co., Apollo Advisors LP, Bain Capital LLC, Thomas H. Lee Partners LP, and Carlyle Group. The report, which cites undisclosed sources, said the company could attract a bid as high as $16 billion, including debt assumption. See full story. Shares of Ballard Power Systems BLDP, +1.43% rose 11.8% after the company inked a deal with General Hydrogen Corp. to deliver more than 100 fuel cells for the lift truck market. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. The fuel cells range in power output from 4.8 kilowatts to 21.1 kilowatts, Vancouver, British Columbia-based Ballard said. The company expects to begin deliveries in the fourth quarter. The supply agreement runs through the fourth quarter of 2006. Biovail Corp. VRX, +2.65% shares rallied 23.6% after the company said the Food and Drug Association cleared it to market once-daily Tramadol ER and that it's in talks with a potential partner to do so. The company did not name the marketing partner. The Toronto company anticipates the commercial launch of Tramadol ER to occur in early 2006. The drug is used to treat pain. See full story. Build-A-Bear Workshop BBW, -1.61% shares added 6.9% after the company reaffirmed its outlook for fiscal 2005, backing its projections for a profit of $25.1 million to $26.3 million, or $1.24 to $1.30 a share, with same-store sales coming in flat. The St. Louis gift bear maker said its financial results weren't materially affected by Hurricane Katrina. Globecomm Systems GCOM ] shares surged 12.3% after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $1.07 million, or 7 cents a share, vs. $377,000, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Hauppauge, N.Y.-based satellite communication solutions provider rose to $26.7 million from $20.8 million last year. The company expects 2006 earnings of more than 25 cents a share on revenue of more than $125 million. Shares of Medical Staffing Network Holdings MRN, -0.73% rose 5.7% after the Boca Raton, Fla., provider of nurse staffing services said it's been selected along with another company, JCNationwide, to be the primary providers for a multi-year contract with the Department of Health and Human Services. The company said the government estimates the annual volume of purchases under the deal will be more than $55 million per year, or roughly $275 million during its five-year term. Meritage Corp. MTH, +1.57% shares advanced 7.4% after JMP Securities raised its rating on the company to strong buy from outperform. See full story. Open Text Corp. OTEX, +2.23% shares tacked on 10.3% after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 10 cents a share, down from a profit of $9 million, or 16 cents a share, last year. Adjusted earnings were $9 million, or 18 cents a share. Revenue rose to $109.4 million vs. $105 million. The software maker also said it will consolidate facilities and reduce its workforce in moves to increase profitability. The actions will save $30 million a year in fiscal 2005 and $40 million a year beginning in fiscal 2007. PalmSource PSRC shares soared 78.2% after the company agreed to be acquired by Access Co. Ltd., a Tokyo-based provider of mobile content software, for $324.5 million, or $18.50 a share. See full story. Siebel Systems SEBL added 5.2% as chatter once again swirled about a potential takeover of the business software maker. In recent trading, the stock rose 48 cents, or 5.5%, to $9.16 on heavy volume. Speculation has long been rife that San Mateo, Calif.-based Siebel could be an acquisition target for the likes of Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71% of nearby Redwood Shores, Calif. Analyst Peter Coleman at Think Equity said the latest round of unconfirmed rumors centered on a deal or a potential move by the company to go private. Richard Williams, an analyst at Garban Institutional Equities, noted the challenge of sorting through the perennial rumors. "It's like trying to predict the lottery," he said. An Oracle spokeswoman declined to comment and a Siebel spokesman couldn't immediately be reached. Decliners Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% ended the session down 25.3% after the company topped Wall Street's consensus view for its fourth-quarter results by a penny but said it expects earnings from continuing operations of at least 7 cents a share for the first quarter, below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 11 cents a share. The Lake Success, N.Y., chemicals and drug distribution company also said it doesn't expect business from two active product ingredient products, which has suffered of late due to intense competition, to return. Harris Interactive HPOL shares gave back 9.5% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.15 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. down from a profit of $24.8 million, or 43 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Rochester, N.Y.-based market research and opinion polling firm posted revenue of $54.2 million vs. $39.6 million. Additionally, Harris Interactive named Gregory Novak chief executive. Novak has served as acting CEO since May. Looking ahead, the company said it expects first-quarter earnings of breakeven to a penny a share on revenue of $46 million to $48 million. Host America Corp. CAFE, -0.75% shares plummeted 40.8% after the company said the Nasdaq plans to delist its shares and warrants, effective at the start of trading Monday. The Hamden, Conn.-based food and energy services company has yet to determine whether it will seek a review of the delisting decision by the exchange. Martek Biosciences Corp. MATK shares lost 8.8% after the company reported a third-quarter net loss of $109,000, or breakeven a share. During the same period a year ago, Martek reported net earnings of $5.01 million, or 16 cents a share. The Columbia, Md.-based biosciences company posted revenue of $39.5 million vs. $47.3 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast a third-quarter loss of 3 cents a share on revenue of $40 million. Additionally, Martek named Peter Nitze chief operating officer, effective this month. Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies Worldwide QTWW tumbled 11% after the Irvine, Calif., fuel systems manufacturer posted a quarterly loss of $8.1 million, or 15 cents a share, wider than its year-ago loss of $2.4 million, or 8 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 15 cents a share in the July period. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $47.4 million from $6.4 million in the same period a year earlier, but the performance was slightly below Wall Street's consensus estimate of $47.6 million. The company attributed the wider loss to a shortfall in development program-related revenue, as well as higher than expected costs in this business. Source Interlink Cos. SORC shares fell 9.6% after the Bonita Springs, Fla., provider of family entertainment CD and DVD products reported pro forma earnings of $6.1 million, or 12 cents a share, for the second quarter, missing the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by 2 cents. Looking ahead, the company reaffirmed its outlook for earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $85 million to $90 million in fiscal 2006. Yellow Roadway Corp. YELL shares shed 7% after the company lowered its third-quarter earnings forecast to $1.40 to $1.45 a share from $1.60 to $1.65 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call estimate earnings at $1.62 a share. The Overland Park, Kan.-based transportation service provider cited Hurricane Katrina as one reason for the lowered forecast. The company estimated the storm's impact at 5 cents a share in the third quarter. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% Friday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.79 million, or 11 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, the Lake Success, N.Y., drug and chemical distributor posted a profit of $2.84 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter. Sales slipped in the latest three months to $73.7 million from $76.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 10 cents a share in the June period. The stock closed Thursday at $7.44, down 4%.
title: Aceto tops Wall St. view by penny

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% said Wednesday it agreed to sell the majority of the product lines formulated and marketed by its CDC Products Corp. unit. Terms weren't disclosed. In 2004, CDC recorded sales of $4.3 million. The company will include CDC within continuing operations, which may cut 2 cents from Aceto's earings estimate of 9 cents to 11 cents for the fourth quarter. Aceto is a chemicals company based in Lake Success, N.Y.
title: Aceto to sell CDC pdt lines; expects 2c charge in Q4

Shares of Equifax added 29 cents, or 1 percent, to end at $29.10 in Wednesday's dealings. Starwood's Q4 adjusted EPS up 36%; upbeat on Q1 profit (6:21 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide Inc. HOT, -0.41% posted fourth-quarter net income of $100 million, or 46 cents per share, up from $87 million, or 42 cents, earned in the same period in 2003. Revenue rose 20.5 percent, reaching $1.442 billion. On an adjusted basis, quarterly earnings from continuing operations would have totaled 57 cents per share, up from the prior year's 42 cents. Analysts' average forecasts had been for the hotel operator to earn 45 cents per share on revenue of $1.308 billion. Starwood also projected first-quarter earnings of 30 cents per share, higher than the First Call-derived average of 26 cents. Shares of Starwood ended Wednesday's trading unchanged at $58.30. Lexar Media delays Q4 earnings report to Feb. 24 (6:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Digital media manufacturer Lexar Media LEXR said it has postponed the release of its fourth quarter and fiscal 2004 earnings reports to after the market close on Feb 24. "Due primarily to price volatility in the retail market for digital media products, the company intends to account for revenue from certain customers on a sell-through rather than a sell-to basis," it said, saying this will defer revenue from the fourth quarter to future periods and will reduce fourth quarter revenues as compared to its previously provided guidance and requires extra time. Jos Bank sees fy 2004 earns 'at least' $1.71 a share (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Retailer JoS. A. Bank Clothiers JOSB citing increased gross margins as well as "strong" sales in its catalogue and Internet businesses, said it expects earnings of "at least" $1.71 a share for its January-ending year, up from $1.20 a share in the year ending January 2004. The consensus from analysts is for earnings at $1.71 a share, it said. January sales rose 13.8 percent to $23.9 million. Comparable store sales decreased 5.7 percent in January 2005. "Sales were severely impacted by the snow storms throughout the country mid-month and ice storms in the southeast in the latter part of the month. Our direct segment, which is typically not affected by weather, continued to post double-digit sales gains," it said. Whirlpool steers 2005 profit estimates higher (6:12 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Whirlpool Corp. WHR, +1.28% posted fourth-quarter net earnings of $97 million, or $1.44 per share, down from $124 million, or $1.76 per share, earned in the same period in 2003. Quarterly sales came in at $3.632 billion, up 8.1 percent, with currency translations accounting for 3.1 percentage points of this growth. North American sales rose 5.3 percent to $2.2 billion. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of $1.43 per share on revenue of $3.544 billion, according to a survey by Thomson First Call. The appliance manufacturer also said it's putting price increases into effect as a result of "an unprecedented material costs environment." Whirlpool projected 2005 earnings of $5.90 to $6.10 per share; Wall Street's average stands at $5.88. Shares of Whirlpool slipped 81 cents, or 1.2 percent, to end at $68.27 in Wednesday's trading. Pier 1 Imports Jan. same-store sales down 10.4% (6:05 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pier 1 Imports PIR, +2.88% said same-store sales fell 10.4 percent in January. Total sales in January fell 5.4 percent to $118.9 million. It said severe weather across the U.S. hurt January's comparable store sales by 2 percent to 3 percent. "Based on results so far this quarter, we project earnings to be at the low end of the previously announced range of 31 cents to 38 cents per diluted share," it said. RD-Shell ups reserve restatement, to restart buybacks (2:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Royal Dutch/Shell RD SC, +1.62% on Thursday said it was lifting the amount of proved reserves it had to reduce in 2003, from the 900 million barrels of oil equivalent per day flagged in late October, to 1.4 billion barrels of oil equivalent per day. The oil giant said it was restarting its share buyback plan with between $3 billion and $5 billion earmarked for buybacks in 2005, and said it'll pay at least $10 billion in cash to shareholders. Fourth-quarter net income climbed 134 percent to $4.47 billion, or up 204 percent on a CCS basis to $5.12 billion and said the 3.8 million barrels of oil equivalent per day production is at high end of indicated range. Deutsche to review UK asset manage as net outflows grow (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Deutsche Bank(DE:804010) DB, +1.60% Germany's largest bank, said it would review its UK asset management business as net asset outflows in the fourth quarter totalled 20 billion euros "largely in the UK Institutional, Continental Europe Retail (primarily short-term) and Americas Retail business." Underlying revenue in the quarter "suffered from lower performance fees compared to the fourth quarter 2003 due to continued difficult market conditions... and from the absence of significant gains from the sale of real estate investments. Compounding this decline was the impact of unfavorable foreign exchange developments and invested asset net outflows," the bank said . Page Jaunes 2004 earns up 25% to 228.2m euros (2:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pages Jaunes Group, a spinoff of France Telecom FTE, +0.55% reported fiscal 2004 pro forma earnings up 25 percent to 228.2 million euros ($297 million). Revenue for the period climbed 7.3 percent to 984.1 million euros, higher than the 4 percent to 6 percent previously forecast. Looking ahead, Page Jaunes said it sees 2005 sales up 5 percent to 7 percent. Deutsche Bank Q4 earns lower, sees net 5,200 jobs cut (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Deutsche Bank(DE:804010) DB, +1.60% Germany's largest bank, expects to reduce its full-time headcount by a net 5,200 as part of a cost-cutting plan and to take charges for 4,800 of the positions this year. Total costs of its restructuring recorded in the fourth quarter 2004 and expected in 2005 are estimated to be 1.3 billion euros, the bank said. The bank posted pre-tax profit of 418 million euros after reorganisation charges of 574 million euros. Analysts had projection pre-tax earnings from 192 million to 365 million euros. Net income for the quarter was 269 million euros, compared to 436 million euros for the fourth quarter 2003. Rio Tinto 2004 net jumps to $2.81 b vs $1.50b (2:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Rio Tinto(UK:RIO) RIO, +2.65% reported 2004 net income that rose to $2.81 billion, or $2.04 per share, from $1.50 billion, or $1.09 per share, in 2003. Adjusted earnings for the period climbed 61 percent to $2.21 billion. The Anglo-Australian miner said adjusted earnings exclude net exceptional items of $592 million comprising net gains from the disposal of businesses of $913 million less asset writedowns and provision for contract obligations of $321 million. Dividend for 2004 increased 20 percent to 77 cents per share. Rio Tinto said it plans to return $1.5 billion of capital through share buy backs programs over the next two years. Looking ahead, the company said it sees strong demand continuing in 2005. Epcos swings to Q1 loss, doesn't see demand picking up (2:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German electronic components maker Epcos EPC, +0.91% (DE:512800)said it experienced a "severe" decline in sales in the first quarter of fiscal 2005 and swung to a net loss of 400,000 euros. Last year, its net income was 10 million euros. Sales fell 13 percent to 289 million euros and new orders fell 22 percent to 287 million euros. Its net cash flow loss widened to 43 million euros from 1 million euros. Looking ahead, it said "demand still does not appear to be picking up significantly." It sees "only a slight" increase in sales in the second quarter from the first quarter, and expects fiscal 2005 sales and earnings to be lower than fiscal 2004. UK's Caffe Nero H1 same-store sales up 6% (2:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Caffe Nero(UK:CFN), the U.K. coffee bar retailer that competes with Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% among others, said sales at operations open at least a year rose 6 percent in the half-year to Nov. 30. Total sales rose 40 percent to 32.8 million pounds as profits before tax and items rose to 2.4 million pounds from 1 million pounds in the year-ago period. "New stores are being opened at a rate of four per month and group remains on target to have at least 210 open by the year end," it said. BNP Paribas Q4 net up 2.7% after provisions drop 71% (2:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French bank BNP Paribas(FR:013110)said Thursday that fourth-quarter net profit rose 2.7 percent to 952 million euros, with provisions down 71.2 percent in the quarter to 102 million euros. It said its dividend will rise 37.9 percent to 2 euros per share and added that share buybacks will be carried out through 2007. Analysts forecast net profits between 914 million and 1.069 billion euros, AFX News said. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Aceto ACET, +3.97% Thursday reported that its second-quarter net income was $2 million, or 8 cents per share, down from $3 million, or 12 cents per share, pressured partly by losses from discontinued operations. Quarterly income from continuing operations was $2.5 million, or 10 cents per share, compared to $3.2 million, or 13 cents per share, a year befofe. Revenue rose 12 percent to $75.8 million. On Wednesday shares of the Lake Success, N.Y. biopharmaceuticals and chemicals company increased 6 cents to $9.36.
title: Aceto Q2 profit falls below yr-earlier

content: Peak International prelim Q3 net loss $2.5M-$2.7M (7:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Peak International Ltd. PEAK Friday after the bell issued its preliminary third-quarter revenue and income results. For the quarter, the Newark, Calif.-based packaging products maker reported a preliminary loss of $2.5 million to $2.7 million on revenue of $16.8 million. Additionally, the company said that expenses related to the results of an internal review of payroll practices at its factory in China may impact Peak's third-quarter results. Peak also said it has delayed releasing its third-quarter financial results. Tripath Technology to restate certain Q2 financial info (5:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tripath Technology Inc. TRPH said Friday after the bell that it plans to restate certain financial information from its second-quarter financial results. The decision to restate was based on findings by its own internal investigation, the San Jose, Calif.-based company said, and involved $1.4 million worth of product. Ashland revises Q1 financial results, reduces EPS 11c (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Ashland Inc. ASH, +1.04% said Friday after the bell that it has made a revision to its first-quarter 2005 financial results that were issued on Tuesday. As a result, net income was reduced to $94 million, or $1.28 a share, rather than the previously reported $101 million, or $1.39 a share. Operating income was reduced to $180 million from $193 million, the Covington, Ky.-based diversified industrial firm said. Ashland said the revision came after an internal review, in conjunction with its independent accountants, regarding the accounting treatment of certain insurance policies. Enbridge Energy Partners Q4 profit rises 24% (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Enbridge Energy Partners L.P. EEP, +2.99% reported Friday after the bell that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 24 percent to $36.6 million, or 61 cents per unit, from $27 million, or 54 cents per unit, a year ago. Operating revenue for the company was $1.33 billion vs. $760.4 million a year earlier. The Houston-based company said it expects its 2005 net income to be between $150 million and $160 million. Giga-tronics swings to Q3 profit; rev up 34% (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Giga-tronics Inc. GIGA, +0.00% Friday after the bell reported third-quarter earnings of $28,000, or 1 cent a share. Last year, the San Ramon, Calif.-based electronic devices company reported a loss of $994,000, or 21 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter increased to $5.1 million from $3.8 million. Savannah Bancorp Q4 profit jumps 49% (3:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Savannah Bancorp SAVB on Friday reported fourth-quarter net income of $1.8 million, or 42 cents a share, a 49 percent increase from $1.2 million, or 28 cents a share. Net interest income rose 35 percent to $5.8 million from $4.3 million last year, the Savannah, Ga. bank-holding company said. Air T Q3 profit more than doubles (3:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Air T AIRT, -0.78% on Friday said that it earned $485,000, or 18 cents a share, in the third quarter, up 110 percent from $230,000, or 8 cents a share, last year. The Maiden, N.C.-based air transport company said that its revenue for the quarter rose to $18.3 million, up from $13 million. FNB Corp Q4 profit up 10% (3:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FNB Corp. FNB, +0.98% on Friday said that fourth-quarter earnings rose 10 percent to $3.7 million, or 50 cents a share, up from $3.4 million, or 46 cents a share, last year. Net interest income at the Christianburg, Va.-based bank holding company rose 2.6 percent to $13.3 million. Phoenix Tech shares rally in wake of Q1 earnings report (2:26 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Phoenix Technologies Ltd. PTEC, -0.30% added more than 7 percent to $7.65 after the Milpitas, Calif., system software for digital devices reported first-quarter earnings of $2.2 million, or 9 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $2.6 million, or 10 cents per share, but 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $26.2 million from $24.5 million in the same period a year earlier. OSI shares crumble on poor outlook, downgrade (1:38 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of OSI Systems OSIS, +2.61% dropped more than 13 percent to $16.96 in afternoon action. After Thursday's closing bell, the Hawthorne, Calif., maker of security systems and medical monitoring products posted a profit before items of 19 cents per share for the second quarter, meeting Wall Street's consensus estimate, but OSI also issued a disappointing outlook for the third quarter. The company said it sees earnings of 8 to 10 cents per share, including a charge of 4 cents, in the March period on revenue of between $96 million and $98 million. This view is well below the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 20 cents per share. Morgan Keegan lowered its rating on the stock to "market perform" from "outperform" in the wake of the news. The firm said the poor outlook was due to losses in OSI's Large Cargo business. Lincoln Bancorp Q4 profit falls 11% (1:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lincoln Bancorp LNCB Friday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $722,000, or 14 cents a share, vs. $811,000, or 20 cents a share, last year. Net interest income for the quarter at the Plainfield, Ind.-based firm was $5.7 million compared with $4 million. BOE Financial Q4 profit up 18% (1:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- BOE Financial Services of Virginia Inc. BSXT Friday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $751,000, or 63 cents a share, vs. $634,000, or 53 cents a share, a year ago. Net interest income for the quarter at the Tappahannock, Va.-based firm increased to $2.4 million from $2.3 million. Jefferson Bancshares Q2 profit falls 9% (10:59 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Jefferson Bancshares JFBI on Friday reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of $882,000, or 12 cents a share, down 9 percent from $966,000, or 11 cents a share, last year. Net interest income for the Morristown, Tenn. bank-holding company was $2.79 million compared with $2.8 million a year ago. DeVry shares rally in wake of Q2 report (10:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- DeVry DV, +2.94% shares rose more than 17 percent to $18.06 in morning trades. After Thursday's closing bell, the Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., education services provider reported second-quarter earnings of $5.9 million, or 8 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $15.6 million, or 22 cents per share. The latest results include a $2.2 million pre-tax accrual for a work force reduction. Revenue fell in the latest three months to $194.5 million from $198.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the year-over-year decline in earnings to its previously disclosed reduced full-time campus enrollments for the fall-term and increasing levels of part-time students. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 11 cents per share in the December period. Looking ahead, DeVry said it's seeing a favorable response to its early marketing and recruiting efforts for the 2005 spring-term. Lilly backs Q1, 2005 outlook (9:22 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Eli Lilly & Co. LLY, +0.47% on Friday backed its first-quarter and 2005 financial outlook, reiterating its expectations last given on Jan. 26 when the Indianapolis-based drug giant reported its financial results. The company said the statement was made along with another announcement about a U.S. drug application for duloxetine. Escalade sees 04 net of 60c, 'significantly below' 03 (9:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Escalade Inc. ESCA, +0.74% said it expects 2004 net income of $7.8 million, or 60 cents per share, 'significantly below' 2003 results. The manufacturer of sporting goods attributed the shortfall to excess inventory, restructuring costs and other costs associated with the company's European operations. Cott Q4 earns fall, miss forecast even as sales climb (9:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Cott Corp. COT, +1.94% reported fourth-quarter net income that fell to $11.4 million, or 16 cents per diluted share, from $16.6 million, or 23 cents per diluted share, in the year-earlier quarter. The earnings include a 2-cent charge related to supplier rebates. Excluding the one-time item, earnings would have been 18 cents per diluted share, missing the forecast for earnings of 22 cents per share from analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period rose to $369 million from $345 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the soft drink supplier said it sees 2005 earnings in the range of $1.21 to $1.25 per diluted share, on sales up 8 percent to 10 percent. Cott also said it sees 2005 capital expenditure at about $95 million. Stewart Enterprises cuts Q1 earnings forecast (9:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)-- Stewart Enterprises Inc. STEI cut its earnings outlook Friday for the first quarter to a range of 9 to 11 cents from its previous estimate of 11 to 13 cents. "We experienced a decrease of almost 5 percent in the number of events performed by our funeral homes," said Stewart CEO Kenneth Budde. Stewart shares fell 16 cents to close at $6.72 Thursday. ChevronTexaco doubles net income in Q4 to $3.4B (9:01 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- ChevronTexaco Corp. CVX, +1.73% on Friday reported fourth quarter net income of $3.4 billion, or $1.63 a share, versus $1.7 billion, or 82 cents a share, for the same period a year ago on stronger oil and gas prices. The results for the quarter included special-item gains of $146 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of $1.40 a share. For the fourth quarter, revenue reached $42.7 billion compared with $30.3 billion for the quarter a year ago. For the full year, net income rose to $13.3 billion, or $6.28 a share, compared with $7.2 billion, or $3.48 a share, in 2003. Tidewater Q3 earns, rev. rise above expectations (8:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tidewater Inc. TDW, -0.97% reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $19.8 million, or 34 cents a share, up from $18.3 million, or 32 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 32 cents a share. Revenue rose 11 percent to $187.6 from last year's $169.4 million and above analyst forecasts of $174 million. The oil services company's stock closed Thursday up 21 cents at $37.86. Pinnacle West Q4 earns fall, miss forecast (8:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pinnacle West Capital Corp. PNW, +0.42% reported fourth-quarter net income that fell to $33.7 million, or 37 cents per diluted share, from $49.1 million, or 54 cents per diluted share, in the year-earlier quarter. Adjusted earnings for the period came in at 34 cents per share, missing the forecast for earnings of 44 cents per share of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period rose to $734.7 million from $723.6 million a year ago. Peoples Energy Q1 profits drop on restructuring charge (8:46 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Peoples Energy PGL, +1.35% on Friday reported fiscal 2005 first quarter net income of $22.5 million, or 59 cents a share, compared with $31.4 million, or 85 cents a share, for the prior year. Excluding a non-cash, pension-related charge, earnings totaled $29.2 million, or 77 cents a share. Analysts, on average, expected quarterly profits of 83 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue totaled $737.4 million compared with $604.9 million for year earlier period. McDonald's leaves financial targets intact for 2005 (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- McDonald's MCD, -1.28% left its average annual financial targets intact for 2005, forecasting systemwide sales and revenue growth of 3 to 5 percent and operating income growth of 6 to 7 percent. It expects to add 350 net new McDonald's restaurants during the year. The Dow component also said it would explore its strategic alternatives with regard to its Chipolte Mexican Grill business due to its strong performance and growing popularity. The strategic options could include raising additional equity capital in the public or private markets. The stock closed Thursday at $32.12, up 13 cents. McDonald's boosts Q4 net to $397.9M vs $125.7M (8:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- McDonald's MCD, -1.28% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $397.9 million, or 31 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $125.7 million, or 10 cents per share. The Oak Brook, Ill., hamburger purveyor and Dow component attributed the strong year--over-year increase in earnings to a strong comparable sales increase of 5.1 percent and higher margins. Total sales rose in the latest three months to $5.01 billion from $4.56 billion in the same period a year earlier. The latest results include a charge of 8 cents per share related to a review of the company's lease accounting, an impairment charge of 8 cents per share, and a gain of 2 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 46 cents per share in the December quarter on sales of $4.88 billion. The stock closed Thursday at $32.12, up 13 cents. Alaska Air's losses widen in Q4 (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)-- Alaska Air Group Inc. ALK, +0.63% said Friday that its losses in the fourth quarter grew to $44.9 million, or $1.66 a share, vs. a loss of $16.1 million, or 60 cents a share, a year ago. The latest results include a restructuring charge of $25.9 million, or 59 cents a share. Wall Street's consensus estimate was for a loss of 65 cents per share in the December period. "As we head into 2005, we must continue to pursue cost savings initiatives that will help us become consistently profitable, and weather the onslaught of low-cost competition, restructured network airlines and very high fuel prices," Alaska Air CEO Bill Ayer said. Alaska Air shares closed 12 cents lower at $28.63 on Thursday. CP Ships cuts 2004 earnings estimate (8:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - U.K. container shipping company CP Ships Ltd. TEU lowered its earnings estimate Friday for 2004 to $70 million to $73 million, down from its earlier projections of $82 million in net income. The lower figure is before a charge of $5 million for litigation, restatement and the departure of its CEO in December. The shares lost 20 cents Thursday to $13.45. Sunoco lowers previously disclosed Q4 earnings by $10M (8:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sunoco Inc. SUN, -0.47% revised its previously reported earnings for the fourth quarter and full year, lowering earnings by $10 million, to reflect changes in its accounting for certain insurance policies issued through an energy industry mutual insurance consortium. The company is now recording a $10 million charge for estimated liabilities from retrospective premiums. The charge lowers its fourth-quarter earnings to $178 million and its full-year earnings to $605 million. The stock closed Thursday at $86.56, up 1.5 percent. Aceto Corp Q2 EPS (8:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% said Friday it expects to report earnings of about 10 cents per share before any non-cash impairment costs associated with the sale of its discontinued Institutional Sanitary Supplies business. The impairment costs are expected to cut earnings by about 2 cents per share. The company had previously said it expected to earn 12 cents to 15 cents per share. Aceto shares rose 50 cents on Thursday and closed at $11.76. Littlefuse cuts staff, to take $3.5M charge (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Littlefuse Inc. LFUS, +3.26% said Friday it will take a pre-tax charge of about $3.5 million in the first quarter of 2005 in connection with staffing cuts taken as a result of a recent slowdown in sales. "We have now right-sized our manufacturing plants globally and reduced operating expenses, which will result in annual cost savings of approximately $5 million," Littlefuse President and CEO Gordon Hunter said in a press release. The maker of circuit protection products said it had adjusted employment levels at its plants worldwide and also had reduced staffing its selling, administrative and other overhead functions. Littlefuse shares closed down 0.5 percent at $31.49 on Thursday. Lancaster Colony Q4 earnings excluding items ease (7:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Specialty food and candle maker Lancaster Colony LANC, +1.19% said its second fiscal quarter earnings rose to $38.1 million, or $1.08 share, from $26.6 million, or 74 cents a share, with sales up 2 percent to $297 million. Excluding 47 cents per share of income from the Continued Dumping and Subsidy Offset Act, it would've seen an EPS decline to 61 cents a share, which the company attributed to higher material, freight and energy costs. The company said fiscal second half will likely benefit from a reduction in certain food ingredient costs, although this benefit will be mitigated by continuing higher costs for many nonfood raw materials. T. Rowe Price Q4 profit climbs 41% (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- T. Rowe Price TROW, +2.06% on Friday reported fourth-quarter net income of $97 million, or 71 cents per share, up 41 percent from $69 million, or 53 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Baltimore financial services firm said revenue grew to $345 million from $281 million. T. Rowe Price was expected to earn 66 cents per share with revenue of $338 million. Shares rose 78 cents to $58.88 on Thursday. Halliburton Q4 losses narrow, but revenue declines (7:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Halliburton HAL, +1.93% reported a fourth-quarter loss of $201 million, or 45 cents a share vs. a loss of $947 million, or $2.17 a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding losses from discontinued operations, earnings rose to 41 cents a share from last year's 34 cents. Revenue fell 4.8 percent to $5.2 billion from last year's $5.46 billion, as a 17 percent drop in total engineering and construction revenue offset a 21 percent increase in total energy services revenue. The oil services company's stock closed Thursday up 77 cents at $43.51. Triumph Group posts Q3 loss on asset sale (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Triumph Group Inc. TGI, -0.59% posted Friday a third quarter loss of $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share compared with a profit $2.7 million, or 17 cents a share in the year-ago, as the disposal of its remaining assets in the Metals Group weighed. Profits from continuing operations rose 49 percent to $3.9 million, or 25 cents a share from year-ago levels. The maker of aircraft components said sales from continuing operations climbed 17 percent to $171.3 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 39 cents a share on revenue of $172.5 million. Triumph Group shares rose 3.1 percent, to $37.85 in trading Thursday. AGL 04 earns rise, 2005 guidance raised (7:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- AGL Resources, Inc. ATG, -9.09% posted fourth-quarter net income that rose to $46 million, or 64 cents per share, from $35 million, or 54 cents per share, in the year-earlier quarter. The results beat the forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 50 cents per share. Operating revenue for the period surged to $626 million from $279 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the natural gas distributor raised its 2005 earnings forecast to the range of $2.25 to $2.35 per share from a previous guidance of $2.20 to $2.30 per share. USF Q4 earnings miss estimates by 36 cents a share (7:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)-- USF Corp. USFC said Friday that its fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations fell to $6.6 million, 23 cents a share, vs. $18.7 million, 68 cents, a year ago. The latest results included USF Red Star pre-tax shutdown costs and operating losses resulting in charges of $7.2 million, or 20 cents per diluted share, and executive severance pre-tax costs of $1.9 million, or 5 cents per diluted share. Wall Street's consensus estimate was for a profit of 59 cents per share. "Our fourth quarter results came in under plan in part due to the December weather negatively affecting our West Coast and Midwest operations. Our results were also negatively impacted by a 51.5 percent tax rate for the quarter," said acting CEO Thomas Bergmann. The Chicago-based trucker's shares fell 72 cents in trading Thursday to close at $33.93. Idexx Q4 earns rise, beat forecast by a penny (7:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Idexx Laboratories, Inc. IDXX, +1.38% posted fourth-quarter net income that rose 37 percent from the year-earlier quarter to $16.9 million, or 49 cents per diluted share, beating the forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by a penny. Excluding year-ago special items, fourth-quarter earnings would have risen 14 percent. Revenue for the fourth quarter climbed 16 percent to $144.3 million. Looking ahead, Idexx said it sees 2005 revenue in the range of $630 million to $640 million and diluted earnings in the range of $2.20 to $2.25 per share. The company sees first-quarter diluted earnings in the range of 47 cents to 48 cents per share. ITT Industries tops Q4 forecasts (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ITT Industries ITT, +2.13% said Friday it earned $121.6 million, or $1.29 a share, on revenue of $1.9 billion in its fourth quarter up from $108.1 million, or $1.15 a share, on revenue of $1.5 billion a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, earnings for the quarter would have been $1.28 compared to an adjusted figure of $1.06 for the year ago period. The results were ahead of the average analyst forecasts according to Thomson First Call for earnings of $1.25 a share and revenue of $1.8 billion. The company also said it has "confidence" in its full-year 2005 projected earnings of $5.00 to $5.15 a share on revenue of $7.15 to $7.43 billion. Honeywell Q4 earns rise 4%, in line with estimates (7:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Honeywell International, Inc. HON, +0.87% posted fourth-quarter net earnings that rose 4 percent to $419 million, or 49 cents per share, from the year-earlier quarter, in line with the forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period climbed 7 percent to $6.6 billion. Looking ahead, the aerospace and defense company lifted its 2005 estimates for net earnings to the range of $1.95 to $2.05 per share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call anticipate 2005 earnings of $1.98 per share. Beckman Coulter Q4 profit slumps, misses forecast (7:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Medical products maker Beckman Coulter BEC, -2.19% said fourth-quarter earnings fell 15.1 percent to $59.8 million, or 91 cents a diluted share, with sales rising 8.5 percent to $693 million. Brokers had seen an EPS of 98 cents, according to Thomson First Call. A favorable currency impact was offset by continued infrastructure investment, higher than anticipated mix of systems-to-aftermarket sales and increased freight costs, and the year-ago quarter benefited from favorable litigation settlement. It also plans to up its dividend by a penny to 14 cents a share and has authorized buybacks of up to 2.5 million shares. It sees 2005 EPS in a $3.55 to $3.65 range -- analysts had forecast $3.62 -- on 7 percent to 9 percent sales rise. Anadarko Petroleum Q4 earns, rev. rise above forecasts (7:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Anadarko Petroleum APC, +2.56% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $405 million, or $1.64 a share, up from $294 million, or $1.17 a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding one-time items, such as legal settlements and restructuring charges, earnings would have been $2.04 a share, exceeding the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.86 a share. Revenue rose 25 percent to $1.6 billion from $1.28 billion, topping analyst forecasts of $1.55 billion, amid a 23 percent rise in gas sales, 28 percent growth in oil and condensate and natural gas liquids sales. The stock closed Thursday up 66 cents at $65.76. Manor Care posts Q4 net of $48M; lifts dividend by 7% (7:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Manor Care HCR, +0.00% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $48 million, or 55 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $38 million, or 42 cents per share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $806 million from $787 million in the same period a year earlier. Manor Care said a lower effective tax rate lifted earnings by 6 cents per share in the latest quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 49 cents per share in the December period on revenue of $816.8 million. The Toledo, Ohio, healthcare company said its board has increased the quarterly cash dividend by 7 percent to 15 cents per share from 14 cents. The stock closed Thursday at $35.13, down 54 cents. Constellation Energy's Q4 net profit rises 13.4% (6:27 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Constellation Energy CEGR3, -0.03% posted fourth-quarter net income of $134.9 million, or 76 cents per share, up from $119 million, or 71 cents, earned in the year-earlier period. The utility operator and power wholesaler's quarterly revenue reached $3.287 billion from the prior year's $2.495 billion. Excluding a one-time charge associated with job cuts, the company would have earned 79 cents in the latest quarter, up from 67 cents a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been looking for quarterly earnings of 80 cents per share on revenue of $2.866 billion. For 2005, the company is projecting earnings of $3.35 to $3.60 per share, as opposed to analysts' average of $3.39 and the $3.24 earned on an adjusted basis for 2004. Constellation Energy's shares rose 24 cents to end Thursday's trading at $45.37. Alliant Energy Q4 EPS fall, milder weather hurts 04 EPS (6:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Alliant Energy Corp. LNT, +0.59% reported fourth-quarter net earnings that fell to $42.7 million, or 37 cents per share, from $48.6 million, or 44 cents per share, in the year-earlier quarter. The utility company posted earnings from continuing operation of 52 cents per share, compared to 53 cents per share in the prior-year quarter. Alliant noted that mild weather had a negative impact of 22 cents to 25 cents per share on its 2004 earnings. Looking ahead, Alliant said it sees 2005 earnings from continuing operations in the range of $1.70 to $2 per share. W&T Offshore prices IPO at $19 a share (6:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWAtch) -- Oil and gas company W&T Offshore WTI, +2.78% said it has priced its initial public offering of 12.65 million shares priced at $19 a share. The company said it has granted the underwriters, led by Lehman Bros. and Jeffries, a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 1.9 million shares of common stock. Tribune Co.'s Q4 revenue up 1% (6:08 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Tribune Co. TRB, -14.29% posted fourth-quarter net earnings of $216.8 million, or 67 cents per share, down from $332.4 million, or $1.00 per share, earned in the final three months of 2003. The media company's quarterly revenue rose 1 percent, reaching $1.484 billion. Excluding special items, Tribune Co. would have earned 71 cents per share in the latest quarter. Analysts, on average, had expected the company to earn 70 cents per share on an adjusted basis and generate revenue of $1.498 billion. Shares of Tribune Co. slipped 14 cents to end Thursday's trading at $39.01. Smith International ups Q1 view after in-line Q4 rise (5:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil services group Smith International SII, +0.97% said it was lifting its first-quarter earnings guidance after posting an in-line fourth-quarter earnings rise to $58.2 million, or 57 cents a share, from $38 million, or 38 cents a share, on revenue growing to $1.21 billion from $983 million. Increased exploration and production spending favorably influenced both the oilfield and distribution segments, it said. Smith said it was lifting its first-quarter EPS guidance to a range of 60 to 62 cents because business demand is now stronger than originally anticipated; brokers had forecast a first-quarter EPS of 59 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. UCBH Q4 profits rise 32 percent, top forecast (5:00 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- UCBH UCBH said fourth-quarter net profits rose 32 percent to $24.4 million, or 51 cents a share, with revenue up 20 percent to $10.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected an EPS of 46 cents a share. The San Francisco-based bank holding company said it expects 2005 EPS to grow to $2.10 a diluted share vs. the $1.81 EPS it had in 2004, in line with broker forecasts. H&M Nov. qtr profits climb on sales, margin gains (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Hennes & Mauritz(SE:000010627), the Stockholm-based clothing retailer, said fourth-quarter ending Nov. 30 profits after financials rose 24 percent to SEK4.05 billion ($581 million) with sales climbing 14 percent to SEK15.87 billion ($2.27 billion) and operating margin climbing to 25 percent from 22.9 percent, which it said was "very satisfactory." H&M said it benefited from splitting its buying department into separate production and buying divisions, and added that American operations showed a strong increase during the quarter. H&M also said it was upping its dividend to SEK8 per share from SEK6 per share, and said December revenue rose 13 percent at constant exchange rates. Fortis sees double-digit organic growth in 2005-2009 (2:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- In its first meeting with analysts since Jean-Paul Votron became Chief Executive, Belgian-Dutch bank and insurance provider Fortis(NL:30086)said it sees organic growth in the double digits over the 2005-2009 period. In addition, Votron said that "selective acquisitions and partnerships" will help Fortis to secure a strategic position in Europe. Regarding its geographical expansion, Fortis noted that it would focus on the enlarged Europe and "selectively grow" in Asia and North America. Porsche H1 profits up 4.5%, sales rise 3.4% (2:25 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Sportscar maker Porsche(DE:693773)on Friday said first half ending Jan. 31 profits rose 4.5 percent to 125 million euros, with sales up 3.4 percent to 2.95 billion euros. Vehicle sales overall rose 9.7 percent to 35,660 vehicles, with sales of its 911 model up 19.5 percent to 12,300, sales of its Cayenne sports utility vehicle climbing 13.3 percent to 19,200, while sales of its Boxster declined 25.9 percent to 3,900 unit as the new line was introduced gradually since the end of November. Looking ahead, Porsche said it was optimistic for the fiscal year, see unit sales of at least 80,000 and revenue growth. Novo Nordisk '04 sales up, sees US dollar impact in '05 (2:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Danish pharmaceutical company Novo Nordisk NVO, +0.26% said net profit in 2004 rose 4 percent to DKr5.03 billion and sales rose 11 percent to DKr29.03 billion. North American sales rose 22 percent driven by sales and market share growth of insulin analogues NovoLog and NovoLog Mix. Novo Nordisk said it sees sales rising 10 percent to 15 percent and operating profit up 15 percent in 2005 in local currencies, but expects the weak U.S. dollar to reduce those estimates to 10 percent sales growth and 5 percent operating profit growth in Danish kroners. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Shares of Aspect Communications Corp.
