ASPT, +20.00% rose more than 7 percent after the company reported that fourth-quarter earnings were $15.5 million, or 19 cents a share, vs. $14.6 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter increased to $96.8 million from $97.4 million. Analysts expected earnings of 13 cents a share on revenue of $92 million, according to Thomson First Call. The San Jose, Calif.-based customer communications company also forecast first-quarter earnings of 11 to 13 cents a share on revenue of $88 million to $90 million. August Technology Corp. AUGT gained more than 17 percent after the company received an acquisition offer from Rudolph Technologies Inc. RTEC, +1.28% for about $190 million in cash and stock. Avnet Inc. AVT, +1.21% shares surged more than 4 percent after the company reported a jump in second-quarter profit to $43.5 million from restated earnings of $8.9 million last year. Sales increased 13 percent to $2.88 billion from $2.55 billion a year ago. The chip equipment distributor forecast third-quarter earnings of 33 cents to 37 cents a share on sales of $2.67 billion to $2.77 billion, surrounding Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 34 cents. Catapult Communications Corp. CATT rose more than 11 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $3.8 million, or 25 cents a share, 2 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. The Mountain View, Calif.-based company also forecast second-quarter earnings of 34 cents a share on revenue of $18.9 million. Constellation Energy CEGR3, -0.03% added almost 8 percent after the company posted fourth-quarter net income of $134.9 million, or 76 cents per share, up from $119 million, or 71 cents, earned in the year-earlier period. The utility operator and power wholesaler's quarterly revenue reached $3.287 billion from the prior year's $2.495 billion. Excluding a charge associated with job cuts, the company would have earned 79 cents in the latest quarter, up from 67 cents a year earlier. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been looking for quarterly earnings of 80 cents per share on revenue of $2.866 billion. China Finance Online JRJC, -0.89% shares gained more than 9 percent after the Beijing provider of online financial information posted a profit of $1.85 million, or 2 cents per American Depositary Share. In the same period a year earlier, the company earned $352,000. Shares of CTS Corp. CTS, +1.30% advanced more than 6 percent after the company reported that fourth-quarter earnings were $6.6 million, or 17 cents a share, vs. $3.9 million, or 11 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter rose to $142.5 million from $132 million. Analysts expected earnings of 16 cents a share on revenue of $141 million, according to Thomson First Call. DeVry DV, +2.94% shares rose more than 13 percent after the Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., education services provider reported second-quarter earnings of $5.9 million, or 8 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $15.6 million, or 22 cents per share. The latest results include a $2.2 million pre-tax accrual for a work force reduction. The company attributed the year-over-year decline in earnings to its previously disclosed reduced full-time campus enrollments for the fall-term and increasing levels of part-time students. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 11 cents per share in the December period. Looking ahead, DeVry said it's seeing a favorable response to its early marketing and recruiting efforts for the 2005 spring-term. FMC Corp. FMC, +4.73% shares surged almost 6 percent after the Philadelphia chemical company reported fourth-quarter earnings rose to $94.5 million, or $2.47 a share, from $6.3 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago. The Philadelphia-based company benefited from a tax adjustment. Excluding the adjustment and other items, the company earned 88 cents a share, a nickel ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Getty Images' GYI shares leapt more than 5 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $28.7 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $28.2 million, or 48 cents a share, last year. Revenue was $117.4 million, up from $96.7 million last year. Getty Images, which provides photographic and stock-film footage, forecast first-quarter net earnings of 51 cents to 54 cents on revenue of $175 million to $180 million. It raised its 2005 earnings view to $2.10 to $2.20, excluding stock-option expensing, on revenue of $705 million to $715 million. Gillette G, +1.27% soared more than 12 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Procter & Gamble PG, +0.56% in a deal worth roughly $57 billion in stock. P&G, whose shares slid almost 3 percent, also reported better than expected results for the second quarter, and lifted their outlook for the full year. See full story. Shares of International Business Machines IBM, +0.60% gained 1 percent after Bear Stearns raised its recommendation on Big Blue to "outperform" from "peer perform" to reflect a "more attractive" valuation. Kronos Inc. KRON shares rose more than 6 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $10.7 million, or 33 cents per share, up from $7.4 million, or 23 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $118.3 million, compared with $99.7 million in 2003. The Chelmsford, Mass.-based software company forecast second-quarter earnings of 34 cents to 38 cents per share, on revenue of $122 million to $126 million. For 2005, the company forecast earnings of $1.64 to $1.70 per share, with revenue of $520 million to $530 million. McData Corp. MCDTA tacked on more than 3 percent after the company was upgraded to "outperform" from "neutral" by Robert Baird, which believes the sell-off in the stock is overdone. MicroStrategy MSTR, +1.01% shares rose more than 6 percent after the business software maker posted strong fourth-quarter earnings. The stock received upgrades from First Albany and First Analysis. McKesson Corp. MCK, +0.15% jumped more than 10 percent after the company ended the third quarter in the red, but posted better-than-expected results. See full story. National Instruments' NATI, +2.68% shares gained more than 6 percent after the Austin, Texas-based virtual instrumentation technology posted fourth-quarter earnings of $16.5 million, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $11.2 million, or 14 cents per share. Nelnet Inc., NNI, +0.33% surged more than 5 percent after the Lincoln, Neb., provider of student loan financing and software reported that fourth-quarter net income more than tripled, while its year-end student-loan assets climbed 29 percent. Fourth-quarter net rose to $47.2 million, or 88 cents a share, from $10.3 million, or 22 cents, in the year-earlier period. Net student loan assets at Dec. 31 were $13.5 billion, up from $10.5 billion at year-end 2003. Neurobiological Technologies NTII, -2.44% added more than 16 percent after the company received fast-track designation of its Viprinex drug for the treatment of ischemic stroke from the Food and Drug Administration. Shares of Olin Corp. OLN, +1.91% rose more than 4 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings rose to $22.8 million, or 32 cents a share, from its year-ago equivalent profit of $400,000, or a penny a share, a year ago. The Clayton, Mo.-based metals and chemical manufacturing company cited a better-than-expected performance from its Chlor Alki Products division. PerkinElmer PKI, +1.14% shares advanced more than 4 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $37.9 million, or 29 cents a share, up 36 percent from $27.9 million, or 22 cents a year ago. Income from continuing operations, excluding intangibles amortization, was 33 cents a share, 2 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. The company also received an upgrade to "buy" from "neutral" from Merrill Lynch, saying it anticipates better contribution from the company's growth initiatives in digital imaging and genetic screening. Shares of Phoenix Technologies Ltd. PTEC, -0.30% added more than 6 percent after the Milpitas, Calif., system software for digital devices reported first-quarter earnings of $2.2 million, or 9 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $2.6 million, or 10 cents per share, but 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $26.2 million from $24.5 million in the same period a year earlier. PMC-Sierra Inc. PMCS gained more than 5 percent after the company reported fourth quarter earnings were $13.1 million, or 7 cents a share, vs. $6.3 million, or 3 cents a share, last year. Pro forma earnings were $1.9 million, or 1 cent a share. SanDisk Corp SNDK surged more than 11 percent after the flash memory maker reported a fourth-quarter profit down from the same period a year earlier, yet its sales were markedly higher. The earnings of 42 cents per share were well ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 27 cents. See full story. Shares of Synagro Technologies Inc. SYGR gained more than 33 percent after the Houston-based provider of water and wastewater residuals management services said it plans to start paying quarterly dividends at an annual rate of roughly 40 to 42 cents per share. The company also said it has secured a commitment for a $305 million senior secured credit facility to refinance its existing debt. In addition, Synagro plans to sell up to $175 million worth of its common stock. Xyratex Ltd. XRTX shares jumped more than 9 percent after the U.K. data storage technology company forecast earnings of 22 to 27 cents per share for the first quarter, above its previous projections for a profit of 14 to 19 cents per share. Decliners Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% shares fell more than 19 percent after the company expects to report earnings before items of about 10 cents per share. The company had previously said it expected to earn 12 cents to 15 cents per share. Beckman Coulter BEC, -2.19% lost more than 6 percent after the company said fourth-quarter earnings fell 15.1 percent to $59.8 million, or 91 cents a diluted share, with sales rising 8.5 percent to $693 million. Brokers had seen an EPS of 98 cents, according to Thomson First Call. A favorable currency impact was offset by continued infrastructure investment, higher than anticipated mix of systems-to-aftermarket sales and increased freight costs, and the year-ago quarter benefited from favorable litigation settlement. Cott Corp. COT, +1.94% tumbled more than 1 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter net income that fell to $11.4 million, or 16 cents per diluted share, from $16.6 million, or 23 cents per diluted share, in the year-ago quarter. The earnings include a 2-cent charge related to supplier rebates. Excluding the charge, earnings would have been 18 cents per diluted share, 4 cents below Wall Street's consensus view. Looking ahead, the soft drink supplier said it sees 2005 earnings in the range of $1.21 to $1.25 per diluted share, on sales up 8 percent to 10 percent. Foundry Networks Inc. FDRY lost more than 8 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $16.7 million, or 12 cents a share, vs. $24.1 million, or 17 cent a share, a year ago. Revenue fell to $104.8 million from $111.1 million. Analysts expected earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $107 million. It also forecast first-quarter earnings of 8 cents to 12 cents a share on revenue of $100 million to $110 million. Frontier Airlines' FRNT, +0.00% shares tumbled more than 1 percent after the company swung to a loss in the third quarter. Denver-based Frontier posted a loss of $11.1 million, or 31 cents a share, for the period ended Dec. 31. Last year, it made $5.5 million, or 14 cents a share. Revenue rose to $202.2 million from $163.6 million. Gateway Inc. GTW dropped more than 7 percent after the company offered a disappointing revenue outlook for the first quarter. See full story. Graco GGG, +2.53% shares slid more than 4 percent after the Minneapolis maker of fluid management products posted fourth-quarter earnings of $27.6 million, or 39 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $21.3 million, or 30 cents per share, a penny below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Halliburton HAL, +1.93% fell more than 6 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $201 million, or 45 cents a share vs. a loss of $947 million, or $2.17 a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding losses from discontinued operations, earnings rose to 41 cents a share from last year's 34 cents. Revenue fell 4.8 percent to $5.2 billion from last year's $5.46 billion, as a 17 percent drop in total engineering and construction revenue offset a 21 percent increase in total energy services revenue. See full story. Honeywell International, Inc. HON, +0.87% dipped almost 1 percent after the Dow component posted fourth-quarter earnings that rose 4 percent to $419 million, or 49 cents per share, from the year-earlier quarter, in line with the forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period climbed 7 percent to $6.6 billion. Looking ahead, the aerospace and defense company lifted its 2005 estimates for net earnings to the range of $1.95 to $2.05 per share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call anticipate 2005 earnings of $1.98 per share. See full story. Insituform Technologies' INSU shares lost more than 20 percent after the company said it expects to report its fourth-quarter and full-year 2004 financial results by March 16. The Chesterfield, Mo.-based piping system rehabilitation company said it expects to post a loss of $4.5 million, or 17 cents a share, for the period. As a result, Insituform expects to be in violation of certain of its debt covenants in the second quarter. Management plans to immediately begin working with its lenders to rectify the situation but said there is no guaranty it will be able to negotiate appropriate amendments to the covenants or obtain new financing. LookSmart Ltd. LOOK, -1.02% slumped more than 10 percent after the company posted a loss for the fourth quarter of $1.7 million, or 1 cent a share. It broke even in the same period last year. Revenue fell to $16.5 million from $17.5 million. It also said it sees first-quarter revenue of $12 million to $14 million. Shares of Maytag Corp. MYG lost more than 10 percent after the Newton, Iowa, home appliance maker reported a fourth-quarter loss of 18 cents a share on 8.4 percent lower revenue. Maytag's loss reflected 26 cents of charges. Thomson First Call's consensus analyst estimate was for net income of 17 cents per share in the period. Maytag's fourth-quarter revenue fell to $1.1 billion. The company also forecast earnings below Wall Street's current view for the full year. See full story. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% slid nearly 1 percent after reporting fourth-quarter earnings of $397.9 million, or 31 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $125.7 million, or 10 cents per share. The Oak Brook, Ill., hamburger purveyor and Dow component attributed the strong year-over-year increase in earnings to a strong comparable sales increase of 5.1 percent and higher margins. Total sales rose in the latest three months to $5.01 billion from $4.56 billion in the same period a year earlier. The latest results include a charge of 8 cents per share related to a review of the company's lease accounting, an impairment charge of 8 cents per share, and a gain of 2 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 46 cents per share in the December quarter on sales of $4.88 billion. See full story. Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% shares lost more than 10 percent after the company said the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is now conducting a formal investigation of the recall of its Vioxx anti-inflammatory drug. The company said the SEC's action was "not unexpected" and that it will cooperate with the regulatory agency. Also, a federal court of appeals ruled that a key patent on Merck's top-selling osteoporosis drug Fosamax is invalid, allowing for generic competition as soon as 2008. See full story. Millipore Corp. MIL, -3.92% sank more than 8 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings were $24.8 million, or 49 cents a share, vs. $32.6 million, or 66 cents a share, last year. Revenue was $225.4 million vs. $215.8 million. Analysts expected earnings of 55 cents. Overnite Corp. OVNT dropped more than 7 percent after the company was downgraded by BB&T Capital to "hold." Overstock.com Inc. OSTK, -0.96% lost more than 19 percent in morning action. The move comes after the online retailer reported fourth-quarter income of $2.5 million, or 12 cents a share, up from its year-ago loss of $3.1 million, or 19 cents, a year ago, and 4 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus. But the company also told investors that it's unlikely gross margins will rise above 15 percent at the company. Peoples Energy PGL, +1.35% slid more than 1 percent after the company reported fiscal 2005 first quarter net income of $22.5 million, or 59 cents a share, compared with $31.4 million, or 85 cents a share, for the prior year. Excluding a pension-related charge, earnings totaled $29.2 million, or 77 cents a share. Analysts, on average, expected quarterly profits of 83 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue totaled $737.4 million compared with $604.9 million for year earlier period. Sanmina-SCI SANM, +0.77% plummeted more than 14 percent after the company posted first-quarter income of $24.4 million, or 5 cents a share, vs. its year-ago profit of $15.7 million, or 3 cents a year earlier. Analysts expected earnings of 10 cents. It also said it will take an additional restructuring charge of $75 million on top of $100 million announced last July. Sanmina-SCI sees fiscal second quarter revenue of $2.85 billion to $3.15 billion and earnings of 4 cents to 7 cents a share. Stewart Enterprises Inc. STEI lost more than 5 percent after the company cut its earnings outlook for the first quarter to a range of 9 to 11 cents from its previous estimate of 11 to 13 cents. "We experienced a decrease of almost 5 percent in the number of events performed by our funeral homes," said Stewart CEO Kenneth Budde. Stewart shares fell 16 cents to close at $6.72 Thursday. Shares of Varian Semiconductor Equipment Associates VSEA slid more than 3 percent after the company said it expects second-quarter earnings of 23 to 31 cents a share on revenue of $128 million and $138 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 30 cents per share in the March period. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% said Friday it expects to report earnings of about 10 cents per share before any non-cash impairment costs associated with the sale of its discontinued Institutional Sanitary Supplies business. The impairment costs are expected to cut earnings by about 2 cents per share. The company had previously said it expected to earn 12 cents to 15 cents per share. Aceto shares rose 50 cents on Thursday and closed at $11.76.
title: Aceto Corp Q2 EPS

content: Advancers Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% shares gained almost 5 percent Friday after the company announced a 3-for-2 stock dividend and raised its regular annual dividend by 30 percent to 15 cents per share. The stock dividend and the cash dividend will be distributed on Jan.10 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 24, the company said. Shares of AK Steel AKS, +5.84% advanced more than 6 percent after a spokesman said the company agreed to a $1.2 million settlement with the Environmental Protection Agency to cover allegations of pollution at a company steel plant in Butler, Pa. The settlement will cover a $300,000 penalty and $900,000 to fund projects to reduce smog in Pennsylvania. August Technology AUGT shares surged more than 16 percent after Adams Harkness upgraded the Minneapolis-based microelectronics manufacturing software provider to "strong buy" from "buy," due to valuation. Biomira Inc. shares BIOM, +17.14% rocketed more than 114 percent after it and partner Merck KGAA said data from a Phase II trial of a lung cancer drug was encouraging. More than half the patients are alive after 23 months, it said. Partner Merck's shares rose 5 percent in German trading. The companies plan to discuss a Phase III multinational registration trial with regulatory authorities in 2005. Catuity Inc. CTTYD shares gained almost 1 percent after the company said that it has regained listing compliance with Nasdaq by meeting the exchange's minimum bid price requirement. The software company said the 1-for-15 reverse stock split its board authorized on Nov. 12 helped to bring it back into compliance after its stock had traded under $1 for 10 consecutive business days. I-many Inc. IMNY shares rose more than 4 percent on news that the company will be acquired by Selectica Inc. SLTC Selectica will pay $1.55 per share in cash for all outstanding I-many shares, giving the transaction a total value of $70 million. Shares of Selectica fell more than 4 percent. The deal has been approved by both boards and is expected to close in the first calendar quarter of 2005. Inamed Corp. IMDC whose shares advanced almost 2 percent, and Genzyme Corp. GENZ whose shares rose almost 2 percent, said they have received market approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for Captique, a product used for facial wrinkles. Inamed will market the dermal filler to physicians, said the companies. Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% shares surged more than 5 percent after the company lifted its sales forecast for the fourth quarter. See full story. MGM Mirage MGG, +3.51% shares rose almost 5 percent after the company said it's mulling strategic alternatives for its operations in Detroit, where it currently operates the MGM Grand Detroit Casino in cooperation with local partners. Nutraceutical International NUTR, -0.46% shares advanced more than 8 percent after the company said it earned $3.3 million, or 28 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $3.3 million, or 29 cents a share, a year ago. Sales climbed to $36.1 million from $35.3 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 29 cents a share on sales of $35.2 million. Shares of Qsound Labs Inc. QSND gained almost 3 percent after the Canadian-based developer of audio and voice software announced a licensing agreement with VIA Technologies Inc., a developer of silicon chip technologies. Financial terms were not disclosed. Sapient Corp. SAPE shares climbed almost 2 percent after the company said it plans to buy back up to $25 million in stock during the next two years. The company said it had 123 million shares outstanding as of Nov. 30. ViroPharma Inc. VPHM shares surged more than 9 percent after the company said it has received an upfront payment of $10 million related to its licensing agreement with Schering-Plough SGP, -1.28% for the proposed pleconaril treatment for the common cold. The payment was triggered by early termination of the Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust waiting period related to the licensing deal. Wegener Corp. WGNR, -0.62% shares soared more than 63 percent after the company followed up its report of a fourth-quarter net loss Thursday with news of three sales contracts. See full story. Decliners Barbecues Galore Ltd. BBQZ shares plunged almost 24 percent after the company announced a third-quarter loss of $24,000, or 1 cent per share, against year-earlier net income of $488,000, or 12 cents per share. During the third quarter, total sales reached $50.5 million, up from about $48.2 million a year earlier, while same-store sales climbed 5.3 percent above year-earlier levels. BioSante Pharmaceuticals BP.A, -0.98% shares plunged 35 percent after the company said Friday that the Food and Drug Administration Advisory Committee's decision to not recommend approval of Procter & Gamble's PG, +0.56% Intrinsa testosterone patch was "unexpected." BioSante is developing a rival female libido drug. The committee wants more safety data on using testosterone to treat female sexual dysfunction. Procter & Gamble shares fell 0.77 percent. Catalyst Semiconductor CATS, +4.58% shares slumped more than 11 percent following a quarterly report that severely missed analysts' earnings and revenue expectations. See full story. DynTek Inc. DYTK DYTKP shares sank more than 3 percent after the company said it has received a deficiency notice from Nasdaq because it didn't comply with a rule about sales of shares. The company said Nasdaq believes DynTek shareholders should have approved the sale of shares held by DynCorp, a former significant shareholder in DynTek, in 2003. Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% shares slid more than 7 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter earnings of 28 cents to 30 cents a share as it cuts long-term debt by about $3 billion and sells about $6.5 billion of its securities portfolio. See full story. Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% shares slipped more than 2 percent after the company said that it has submitted regulatory filings in the United States and Europe for Revatio, its treatment for pulmonary arterial hypertension. Revatio is the product name for sildenafil citrate; sildenafil is the active ingredient in Viagra. The company said it filed a new drug application with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and submitted its Revatio dossier to regulatory authorities in the Netherlands and Spain, the reporting sponsors, and the European Medicines Agency. Quantum Corp. DSS, +9.84% shares fell more than 5 percent after the company was downgraded by Baird to neutral from outperform, citing continued share loss to LTO products, "competitive threats at Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% its largest customer, and acquisition integration risk with Certance." Hewlett-Packard gained more than 2 percent in morning trading. Select Comfort Corp. SCSS tumbled more than 21 percent after the company lowered its sales outlook for the fourth quarter due to slower than anticipated demand in the early part of the holiday season, especially over the Thanksgiving weekend. The Minneapolis mattress maker now sees sales of between $143 million to $149 million for the period, beneath its prior projection of $153 million to $158 million. Target Corp. TGT, +0.36% shares slipped almost 2 percent after the company was downgraded to "hold" by Citigroup Smith Barney analyst Deborah Weinswig, who suggested her clients consider shifting their investments to Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Chemical products distributor Aceto Corporation ACET, +3.97% announced a 3-for-2 stock dividend and raised its regular annual dividend by 30 percent to 15 cents per share. The stock dividend and the cash dividend will be distributed on January 10, 2005 to shareholders of record as of December 24, 2004, the company said.
title: Aceto announces 3-for-2 stock div., ups annual div.

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% said late Monday that its Aceto (Hong Kong) Limited unit is buying office space in Shanghai to serve as the company's Chinese headquarters. The new space, which is four times larger than its current office, cost $2.9 million and will allow the company to expand its staff by at least 10 percent. The Shanghai unit currently employs 24 people.
title: Aceto buys larger China office for $2.9M

content: Stocks that may be moving in Monday's trading: Volatility may return to shares of financially beleaguered US Airways Group UAIR which plunged 29 cents to end Friday's trading at $1.46. The Air Line Pilots Association bargaining unit representing US Air's pilots says it's open to a resumption of talks with the Arlington, Va.-based carrier. According to the pilots' Web site, US Air's management submitted a new proposal, details of which were not disclosed. US Air has been seeking labor givebacks as a means of staving off a looming Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. The pilots' leadership passed a motion "redirecting resumed negotiations with the company," the ALPA announcement said. See full story. Toyota Motor TM, +0.77% has set its sights on eclipsing General Motors GM, +2.45% as top dog in the global auto market in terms of market share by 2010, according to the cover story in this week's Barron's. Paced by the Camry, the Japanese automaker has seen its 2004-to-date sales grow 8.8 percent in the U.S., well ahead of DaimlerChrysler's DCX growth of 1.7 percent. Both GM and Ford Motor F, +2.03% have seen their 2004 domestic sales drop -- by 1.8 percent and 4.8 percent, respectively. Barron's says Toyota is enjoying the fruits of a wide range of vehicles popular for the dependability as well as greater production efficiency. As a result, Toyota comes in well ahead of its rivals in terms of profit per vehicle sold, according to Barron's. U.S.-traded shares of Toyota eased 4 cents to end Friday's trading at $77.19. Domaines Barons de Rothschild extended to Sept. 17 its $9.25-per-shaer cash offer to buy all outstanding Chalone Wine Group CHLN, +1.27% shares, Chalone said late Friday. Shares of Napa, Calif.-based Chalone closed 17 cents higher at $10.52. Shares of Spectrum Pharmaceuticals SPPI, -1.83% rose 14 percent to $7.50 in Friday's after-hours trading. The drugmaker has received regulatory approval for an abbreviated new drug application for the generic version of Cipro, an antibiotic developed by Bayer BAY, +15.56% Spectrum's clearance covers tablets in dosages of 250, 500 and 750 milligrams. A Lockheed Martin-led team has been designated the winner of a U.S. Air Force contract with a potential value of as much as $9 billion. The contract calls for the provision of information-technology products and services, said Lockheed Martin LMT, +0.78% whose shaers added 6 cents to $54.23 on Friday. The team includes Lucent Technologies LU the services arm of IBM IBM, +0.60% Fluor Corp. FLR, +2.45% Avaya AV., -0.38% NextiraOne, World Wide Technology, Abacus Technology and telecom providers SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% Qwest Communications International Q, +0.00% and Sprint FON, +5.56% In a similar vein, Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% received a $290 million contract from the Defense Logistics Agency to provide IT infrastructure. The five-year agreement comes with one-year options for another five years. Shares of Hewlett-Packard, a Dow Jones Industrial Average component, rose 17 cents to $18.29 ahead of the announcement Friday. Separately, Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% said late Friday it's leading a team that won an Air Force contract valued at $308 million. The team will a battle management command and control subsystem for E-10A aircraft. Shares of Northrop Grumman fell 25 cents to $50.22 ahead of the news Friday. Interstate Bakeries Corp. IBC, +0.00% said late Friday that it has amended its credit line. Under the new terms of its arrangement with its creditors, it can borrow up to $255 million. Continued borrowings from its revolving credit line after Sept. 26 require approval by two-thirds of the company's creditors. Interstate must deliver financial statements and related audit information to the banks by Sept. 26, it said, and loans made after Sept. 13 require the company to submit a weekly cash flow forecast. Analysts are concerned that the maker of Hostess Twinkies and Wonder Bread might have to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Last month, the company failed to file its fiscal 2004 annual report to securities regulators. Interstate's shares skidded 27 cents on Friday to end at $5.31. Norfolk Southern NSC, +1.35% set the pricing on its exchange offer for up to $400 million of its outstanding 7.35 percent notes due 2007. The exchange price works out to $1,103.81 per $1,000 principal amount of notes; early participation tenders will get an additional payment of $5. The interest rate on the new notes, due 2014, will be 5.257 percent, the railroad operator said. To date, $483.6 million of the 2007 notes have been tendered under the offer, which will expire at 2 p.m. Eastern on Sept. 14, unless extended. Norfolk Southern's shares added 34 cents to close Friday at $29.15. American Electric Power AEP, -0.10% said a federal court dismissed all claims brought against it in a securities lawsuit. The case filed by Albert Fadem Trust was dismissed "with prejudice," meaning plaintiffs cannot file any further complaints related to the matter. The case stemmed from allegations that the energy giant had failed to publicly disclose the actions of five former traders. Shares of American Electric Power closed up 14 cents at $32.94. Florida Power & Light, an FPL Group FPL, +1.97% subsidiary, has restored as of Saturday morning power to nearly 87 percent of customers who lost power during Hurricane Frances, which hit the Sunshine State on Sept. 3-4. A total of 373,000 customers remain without power, out of nearly 2.9 million whose electricity was interrupted by Frances. Weather permitting, Florida P&L says it hopes to have all customers restored on or before Sept. 19. Meanwhile, Progress Energy PGN, -0.73% reported early Friday that it had restored power to 90 percent of its customers, and Teco Energy TE, +0.00% said later that its Tampa Electric has brought back service to more than 98 percent of its customers. FPL Group shares rose 20 cents to end Friday at $68.90, while Progress Energy slipped 17 cents to $43.08 and Teco Energy added 4 cents to $13.08. Another company experiencing fallout from Frances, Apartment Investment & Management AIV, +0.42% said late Friday it expects casualty expenses from the hurricane to be $4.6 million to $5.2 million. The Denver-based real-estate investment trust said it now sees third-quarter funds from operations coming in 5 cents a share lower than previously expected. That figure is in addition to the previously announced impact from Hurricane Charley and tropical storm Gaston, which it sees lowering funds from operations by 2 cents a share. Shares of Apartment Investment & Management closed down 35 cents at $35.15 ahead of the announcement. Friday's advancers AK Steel AKS, +5.84% shares gained 5.6 percent after the company raised the price of its Type 409 stainless steel products by 5 percent. The price increase will become effective on Sept. 27. The company cited increased demand and rising costs for the hike. Artesyn Technologies ATSN jumped 20.7 percent after the Boca Raton, Fla., computing and telecom component maker said its board would review an unsolicited acquisition approval from Bel Fuse BELFA, +3.21% The proposed bid is a swap of 0.265 of a share of Bel Fuse Class B BELFB, +0.00% common stock for each Artesyn common share. Decode Genetics DCGN gained 11.9 percent after the company said it has appointed Deloitte & Touche as its independent public accountant, effective immediately. The appointment fills a gap created on Aug. 19 when PricewaterhouseCoopers resigned. Investment Technology ITG, +0.77% tacked on 4.2 percent after the company said Robert Russel resigned as CEO to pursue other interests. Russel will stay on as a consultant for the rest of this year. He will be replaced by Raymond Killian, the company's chairman, who served as chief executive twice before -- from 1994 to 1997 and from 1998 to 2002. Keynote Systems KEYN advanced 9.5 percent after the company acquired Vividence, a private provider of Web-based customer research, for $20 million in cash. Keynote said it may make an additional payment of $6 million, if certain targets are reached by Sept. 30. The company said that the deal is expected to increase fiscal year 2005 revenue by $11 million to $14 million. NetSolve NTSL added 21.9 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% in a deal worth about $128.4 million. See full story. Oracle ORCL, +1.71% rose 5.3 percent after a federal judge ruled late Thursday that the software company can pursue its $7.7 billion hostile takeover bid for rival PeopleSoft. See full story. PeopleSoft PSFT, +0.00% added 10.3 percent on news of the antitrust ruling and an upgrade from Merrill Lynch. See full story. Quiksilver ZQK rose 14.4 percent after the company, which makes youth-oriented clothing, reported higher profit for its fiscal third quarter and raised its 2004 forecasts. See full story. Safeguard Scientifics SFE, -2.39% jumped 9.1 percent after the company said its shareholders approved plans to sell its majority stake in CompuCom Systems CMPC, +0.04% to an affiliate of privately held Platinum Equity. Safeguard expects to receive about $128 million in gross cash proceeds for its common and preferred stock holdings in CompuCom. Shares of CompuCom added 4 cents to $4.58. SigmaTel SGTL rose more than 5.5 percent after the chipmaker announced new applications for one of its key product ranges. The Austin, Texas-based company said a chip in its family of GoChip USB Mass Storage products will now be able to support Renesas Technology's AG-AND and Toshiba Corp.'s MLC flash memory, allowing for substantial improvements in storage density and system cost. Flash memory is used to store data in such devices as personal digital assistants, digital cameras and digital music players. Sonus Networks SONS jumped more than 11.5 percent after the company received a re-listing notice from Nasdaq. Take-Two Interactive Software TTWO, +0.33% surged 5.2 percent after the video-game maker said 2004 sales would be higher than analysts expected. See full story. Urban Outfitters URBN, +1.59% leapt 9.7 percent after the Philadelphia specialty apparel retailer said in a Form 10-Q filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its same-store sales remain "significantly ahead of plan" in the third quarter. Veritas Software VRTS, +0.36% rose 7.3 percent after the company said in a Form 8-K filing with the SEC that it has entered a pre-arranged stock trading plan for the buyback of up to $250 million worth of its common stock between Sept. 15 and March 15. Vishay Intertechnology VSH, +2.20% gained 8.6 percent after the Malvern, Pa., chipmaker said its third-quarter results would fall short of its expectations due to weak demand but that it anticipates sequential improvement in both revenue and earnings in the fourth quarter. Volterra Semiconductor VLTR rose 25.1 percent, advancing for a second straight session after the chipmaker posted strong second-quarter results. World Airways WLDA, -1.64% jumped 22.6 percent after the carrier said it expects to receive roughly $94 million in fiscal 2005 to provide fixed passenger flying services for the U.S. Air Force Mobility Command. The contract is part of a larger indefinite delivery/indefinite quantity contract, worth an estimated $998 million, awarded to World Airways and a group called the Alliance Contractor Team. Friday's decliners Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% tumbled 5.4 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $3.3 million, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent earnings of $2.4 million, or 15 cents per share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 12 percent to $76.5 million in the fourth quarter. Looking ahead, the Lake Success, N.Y. chemical products distributor expects to earn 21 to 24 cents per share in the first quarter of fiscal 2005. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 21 cents in the September quarter. Aftermarket Technology ATAC, -0.60% fell 8.7 percent after the company said it will write off $16 million to $20 million worth of assets and take a $2.6 million charge to close a plant in North Carolina after losing a manufacturing contract from General Motors. See full story. Alcoa AA, +1.22% slumped 7.4 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings to fall short of Wall Street forecasts, citing a strike, a fire and restructuring costs. See full story Brillian BRLC plunged 12.3 percent after the company cut its third-quarter outlook because it missed shipment targets. The company, which makes microdisplays for use in HDTVs, said it expects revenue of $600,000 to $800,000, down from its earlier projection of $2.8 million to $3.2 million. It sees a loss of $5.6 million to $6.1 million, wider than its previous forecast of a loss of $4.4 million to $4.9 million. Two analysts were looking for a loss of 64 cents a share on sales of $3 million. Capstead Mortgage CMO, -0.12% lost 9.6 percent after the Dallas-based real estate investment trust said it expects higher borrowing costs to dampen earnings "because interest rates on most of our borrowings rise (and fall) almost immediately with changes in short-term interest rates while ARM (adjustable-rate mortgage) security yields change slowly by comparison." The company, however, didn't provide an updated outlook. Secure Computing SCUR lost 4.5 percent after Wedbush Morgan lowered its rating on the stock to "sell" from "hold," saying it's receiving negative feedback about the company's sale, especially to government customers. The research firm, which also dropped its price target by 25 percent to $6, said it's "particularly concerned" about the ability of the San Jose provider of security technology to meet its third-quarter financial outlook for earnings of 8 cents per share and year-over-year sales growth of 17 percent. Transmeta TMTA dropped 9.5 percent after the chipmaker lowered its third-quarter revenue outlook to a range of $6.8 million to $7.5 million against its earlier estimate of $8 million to $8.7 million. Trico Marine Services TMAR plunged 22.6 percent after the company said Friday more than two thirds of the holders of its senior notes agreed to a restructuring that allows the company to convert its debt to equity. The swap of the marine services company's $250 million debt into stock will pave the way for a prepackaged bankruptcy filing in which current stockholders would receive warrants for 10 percent of a reorganized Trico. Visteon VC, +2.18% dropped 11 percent after the car parts maker warned that second-half and full-year earnings would come in "significantly below" earlier forecasts. Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded the company a full two notches to "underperform" from "outperform" and slashed its price target to $5 from $11. Visteon cited Ford's lower-than-expected vehicle production estimates for the rest of 2004. See full story. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Monday

World Airways WLDA, -1.64% jumped 22.6 percent after the carrier said it expects to receive roughly $94 million in fiscal 2005 to provide fixed passenger flying services for the U.S. Air Force Mobility Command. The contract is part of a larger indefinite delivery/indefinite quantity contract, worth an estimated $998 million, awarded to World Airways and a group called the Alliance Contractor Team. Friday's decliners Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% tumbled 5.4 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $3.3 million, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent earnings of $2.4 million, or 15 cents per share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 12 percent to $76.5 million in the fourth quarter. Looking ahead, the Lake Success, N.Y. chemical products distributor expects to earn 21 to 24 cents per share in the first quarter of fiscal 2005. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 21 cents in the September quarter. Aftermarket Technology ATAC, -0.60% fell 8.7 percent after the company said it will write off $16 million to $20 million worth of assets and take a $2.6 million charge to close a plant in North Carolina after losing a manufacturing contract from General Motors. See full story. Alcoa AA, +1.22% slumped 7.4 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings to fall short of Wall Street forecasts, citing a strike, a fire and restructuring costs. See full story Brillian BRLC plunged 12.3 percent after the company cut its third-quarter outlook because it missed shipment targets. The company, which makes microdisplays for use in HDTVs, said it expects revenue of $600,000 to $800,000, down from its earlier projection of $2.8 million to $3.2 million. It sees a loss of $5.6 million to $6.1 million, wider than its previous forecast of a loss of $4.4 million to $4.9 million. Two analysts were looking for a loss of 64 cents a share on sales of $3 million. Capstead Mortgage CMO, -0.12% lost 9.6 percent after the Dallas-based real estate investment trust said it expects higher borrowing costs to dampen earnings "because interest rates on most of our borrowings rise (and fall) almost immediately with changes in short-term interest rates while ARM (adjustable-rate mortgage) security yields change slowly by comparison." The company, however, didn't provide an updated outlook. Secure Computing SCUR lost 4.5 percent after Wedbush Morgan lowered its rating on the stock to "sell" from "hold," saying it's receiving negative feedback about the company's sale, especially to government customers. The research firm, which also dropped its price target by 25 percent to $6, said it's "particularly concerned" about the ability of the San Jose provider of security technology to meet its third-quarter financial outlook for earnings of 8 cents per share and year-over-year sales growth of 17 percent. Transmeta TMTA dropped 9.5 percent after the chipmaker lowered its third-quarter revenue outlook to a range of $6.8 million to $7.5 million against its earlier estimate of $8 million to $8.7 million. Trico Marine Services TMAR plunged 22.6 percent after the company said Friday more than two thirds of the holders of its senior notes agreed to a restructuring that allows the company to convert its debt to equity. The swap of the marine services company's $250 million debt into stock will pave the way for a prepackaged bankruptcy filing in which current stockholders would receive warrants for 10 percent of a reorganized Trico. Visteon VC, +2.18% dropped 11 percent after the car parts maker warned that second-half and full-year earnings would come in "significantly below" earlier forecasts. Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded the company a full two notches to "underperform" from "outperform" and slashed its price target to $5 from $11. Visteon cited Ford's lower-than-expected vehicle production estimates for the rest of 2004. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Toyota, US Airways, Chalone, Spectrum Pharma, more

content: Apartment Investment: Frances to cost $4.6M - $5.2M (6:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Apartment Investment and Management Co. AIV, +0.42% said late Friday it expects its casualty expenses from Hurricane Frances to be $4.6 million to $5.2 million. The Denver-based company said it sees third-quarter funds from operations to be 5 cents a share lower than previously expected. Apartment Investment said that figure is in addition to the previously announced impact from Hurricane Charley and tropical storm Gaston, which it sees lowering funds from operations by 2 cents a share. Shares of Apartment Investment closed down 35 cents at $35.15 ahead of the announcement. Platinum warns of 2004 earns shortfall (4:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Platinum Underwriters Holdings PTP, -22.22% warned late Friday its 2004 earnings would come in below analyst expectations. The insurer said it expects earnings of $3 a share, due in part to catastrophe losses from the rest of the year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call currently expect earnings of $3.74 a share on revenue of $1.4 billion. Platinum also said it expects losses from Hurricane Frances of $25 million to $40 million. The insurer said the loss estimate is based on commercial and proprietary models and "very few" of its clients have reported actual losses from its reinsurance policies. Shares Platinum closed up 18 cents to $29.10 ahead of the announcement. Chiron to get $78M Roche payment in HIV patent dispute (4:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Chiron CHIR said late Friday it has reached a settlement with Hoffman-La Roche over a patent and licensing dispute over testing methods for HIV. The Emeryville, Calif.-based biotechnology company said it will receive a lump-sum payment of $78 million in lieu of royalties beyond Jan. 1, 2005. Chiron said Roche may choose to get a partial refund and revert to paying royalties on the sales of its products in North America. Chiron said the amount of the potential refund is initially $64 million. Chiron said it will recognize $14 million as revenue in the third quarter. Shares of Chiron closed up 88 cents to $44.16 ahead of the announcement. Archstone-Smith reiterates 2004 outlook (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Archstone-Smith ASN, +0.00% said after the bell Friday that it is reinterating its previously issued earnings outlook for the full year 2004. The Denver-based real estate company said for 2004 it expects earnings in the range of $1.60 to $1.75 per share. Archstone-Smith said 2004 funds from operations will be in the range of $1.88 to $1.94 per share. The company said 2004 funds from operations gains will be between $2.33 to $2.41 per share. Archstone-Smith said it is still assessing the financial impact of Hurricans Charley and Frances on its portfolio. On Friday Archstone-Smith shares closed up 4 cents to $31.64, ahed of the news. Landry's Restaurants loses $1.8M-$2.2M due to Frances (3:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Seafood chain Landry's Restaurants Inc. LNY, -25.00% said Friday it has lost $1.8 million to $2.2 million in third-quarter revenue due to the impact of Hurricane Frances at its locations in Florida and along the Eastern seaboard. The impact of the loss was somewhat offset by the cancellation of planned advertising expenditures, Landry's said. The company has yet to determine the storm's impact on third-quarter earnings. Yellow Roadway to take $18M, Q3 non-cash charge (2:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Yellow Roadway YELL said Friday it has entered into a new 5-year, $500 million credit facility which replaces a secured credit agreement. The transportation company, based in Overland Park, Kan., also said it will take a third-quarter non-cash charge of $18 million from the unamortized portion of its debt issuance costs for the secured credit agreement. After-tax, Yellow will net $11 million on the charge. Shares of Yellow last traded up 78 cents at $46. Capstead off after noting higher rates will hurt earns (2:32 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Capstead Mortgage CMO, -0.12% lost more than 10 percent to $13.31 after the Dallas-based real estate investment trust said it expects higher borrowing costs to dampen earnings "because interest rates on most of our borrowings rise (and fall) almost immediately with changes in short-term interest rates while ARM (adjustable-rate mortgage) security yields change slowly by comparison." The company, however, didn't provide an updated outlook. Charlotte Russe slips further as Wedbush cuts forecasts (2:23 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Charlotte Russe CHIC extended a more than 20 percent loss from the prior session as Wedbush Morgan Securities became the latest brokerage to lower its estimates after the company's fourth quarter profit warning Thursday. Analyst Adrienne Tennant slashed her 12-month price target by $10 to $15 and lowered her fourth quarter earnings forecast to 11 cents from 30 cents a share. Tennant said the company's statement that its Rampage chain is proving difficult to turn around suggests it will continue to weigh on overall company performance in the near-term. Tennant identifies the privately-owned Forever 21 chain, with its lower prices, as the main competition for mall-located Rampage stores. On a positive note, the analyst said Charlotte Russe has potential for margin expansion over the next 12 months. Shares of Charlotte Russe were last down 0.5 percent at $11.15 in afternoon trading Friday. Gannett Aug. revenue rose 11.9 percent on ad strength (2:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Gannett GCI, +0.50% said Friday that it's August operating revenue rose 11.9 percent from a year ago to $575 million, helped by a 10.7 percent rise in advertising revenue. The company attributed the boost to the strength of Summer Olympics advertising on its NBC-affiliated TV stations and national and classified advertising in its newspaper unit. Shares of Gannett last traded up 4 cents to $85.57. BlackRock affirms financial outlook (2:04 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- BlackRock BLK, +2.59% reaffirmed expectations for third-quarter earnings of 69 to 73 cents per share and a full year profit of $2.95 to $3.05 per share. The current average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson First Call are for profits of 71 cents per share and $2.89 per share in the respective periods. In addition, the New York-based provider of investment management services said it still expects earnings of $3.20 to $3.40 per share for fiscal 2005. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $3.51 per share for the year. Shares of BlackRock rose 59 cents to $73.16. Thermogenesis reports wider Q4 loss (2:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Thermogenesis KOOL, +1.52% reported a wider fourth-quarter loss Friday afternoon. Thermogenesis posted a loss of $1.1 million, or 2 cents a share, for the period ended June 30, compared with $991,000, or 3 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Revenue rose to $3.6 million from $2.9 million. Thermogenesis had 44.7 million shares outstanding in fourth quarter vs. 39.2 million in the same period last year. Shares of Thermogenesis were down a penny to $4.15 in afternoon trade. Midland reaffirms 2004 earns view after storm losses (2:02 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Midland MLAN said Friday it expects to incur an after-tax loss of 10 cents a share to 14 cents a share from Hurricane Frances. The company also said its after-tax losses from Hurricane Charley are expected to be 20 cents a share to 22 cents a share. The Cincinnati-based insurer reaffirmed its 2004 earnings view of $2.40 a share to $2.60 a share. "Our strategy to limit our Florida exposures coupled with our comprehensive reinsurance program helped soften the impact on our bottom line," said John Hayden, Midland's chief executive. Midland said it's now keeping a close eye on Hurricane Ivan as it approaches the southern U.S. It said that its reinsurance coverage for the next catastrophic event are the same as the coverage it had for Hurricane Frances. Shares of Midland last traded up 21 cents at $28.51. Sirva to sell three units, provides 2004, 2005 outlook (11:42 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sirva SIR, +0.15% said Friday that it is selling its specialized transporation unit to North American Van Lines. The company will receive a cash payment of an undisclosed amount for the unit and will keep pre-closing working capital of $20 million. The deal is expected to close by Oct. 31. The company also announced its intention to sell its European specialized transportation unit and its transportation solutions unit. Sirva expects to take a one-time charge of $65 million from the three sales, with $30 million being recorded in the third quarter, $25 million in the fourth quarter and the remainder in 2005. The company provided an earnings outlook for 2004 of $1.15 to $1.18 a share. For 2005, Sirva forecast revenue growth of 10 percent with an earnings rise of 20 percent. Shares of Sirva last traded up 60 cents to $22.25. Visteon slides as profit warning prompts CSFB downgrade (10:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW)-- Shares of Visteon VC, +2.18% tumbled 14 percent to $7.73 Friday as Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded the carparts maker after it warned second half and full earnings would come in "significantly below" earlier forecasts. Analyst Christopher Ceraso cut his rating by a full two notches to "underperform" from "outperform" and slashed his price target to $5 from $11. Ceraso said his downward revision reflects Visteon's decision to take a charge of $825 million to $900 million in the third quarter due to lower-than-expected vehicle production estimates for the rest of 2004 at Ford, one of its major clients. Visteon is also not benefiting as much as had been expected from labor cost savings linked to Visteon workers moving over to Ford to be replaced by lower-paid employees. The analyst is concerned by rising steel costs which have moved even higher since Visteon issued its earning outlook in July. Ceraso said he is now forecasting a third quarter loss of 65 cent a share vs. a prior estimate of 60 cents. For the fourth quarter, he is anticipating a profit of 11 cents a share down sharply from a prior forecast of 31 cents. Brinker tumbles on outlook, J.P. Morgan downgrade (10:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Brinker International EAT, +0.03% shares slumped almost 4 percent to $30.12 in early action. After Thursday's closing bell, the Dallas-based restaurant operator reported its August sales and a disappointing outlook for both the first quarter and full year fiscal 2005. The company said same-store sales in August - which fell 1.7 percent at its namesake locations, 2.7 percent at its Chili's restaurants and 3.2 percent at its Macaroni Grill restaurants - were adversely impacted by Hurricane Charley. Brinker added that its expects September same-store sales to be hurt by Hurricane Frances. The company now sees earnings before items of 38 to 40 cents per share in the first quarter and $2.14 to $2.26 per share for the full year. The current average estimates for analysts polled by Thomson First Call are for earnings of 43 cents per share in the September quarter and $2.51 per share for the full year. J.P. Morgan dropped its rating on the stock to "neutral" following the news, saying its patience with the company has been "undeserved" and that same-store sales at the Brinker restaurants took a hit from higher than expected advertising levels. Goodyear to cut more jobs, take Q3 charges (9:22 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Gooduyear Tire & Rubber GT, +0.83% said Friday morning that it will cut 340 jobs in its engineered products and chemicals units in a bid to cut costs not related to its tire business. The company said it expects a $23.5 million to $27.5 million third-quarter charge for the engineered products unit, as well as $4.5 million to $6.5 million in additional costs. For the chemicals unit, Goodyear expects to take a $5.5 million to $6 millon third-quarter charge and sees $2 million to $2.5 million in additonal costs tied to the cuts. Goodyear stock ended Thursday's session down 18 cents at $11.52. First Investors Financial Servs Q1 2c vs. 4c a year-ago (9:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- First Investors Financial Services FIFS posted Friday first quarter net income of $86,953 or 2 cents a share compared with $220,079, or 4 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The Houston, Texas-based consumer finance company said the decline was largely due to an unrealized loss of interest rate derivative positions of $67,657 during the quarter versus a gain in the same period a year ago. The company also announced that it was expanding its share repurchase program, with the board of directors authorizing the repurchase of an additional $1.5 million of shares on the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. Shares of First Investors Financial Services were trading down a penny at $3.75 in pre-market trading Friday. Compex Q4 profit drops on jump in expenses (9:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Compex Technologies CMPX reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings $1 million, or 8 cents per share, down from its year-ago equivalent earnings of $1.7 million, or 15 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company. The company said selling, general and administrative expenses rose to $13.1 million in the latest quarter from $10.8 million in the year-ago period due to its acquisition of Filsport in July and higher marketing expenses for new products in both the U.S. and Europe. Looking ahead, the New Brighton, Minn. medical device company said it sees earnings of 28 to 32 cents per share on revenue of between $94 million and $100 million for fiscal 2005. Shares of the company closed Thursday up 75 cents to $5.75. Wellchoice execs to confirm earnings outlook (9:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Wellchoice WC said its senior management plan to confirm the company's ability to meet its previously disclosed earnings outlook during a presentation Friday at a conference sponsored by Bear Stearns. On July 22, the New York-based health insurance provider said it expect earnings of $2.90 to $2.94 per share for 2004 and a profit of 69 to 73 cents per share in the third quarter. The stock closed Thursday at $37.22, up 18 cents. Aceto posts in-line Q4 profit (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aceto Corporation ACET, +3.97% reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $3.3 million, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent earnings of $2.4 million, or 15 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 20 cents per share. Sales rose 12 percent to $76.5 million in the fourth quarter. Looking ahead, the Lake Success, N.Y. chemical products distributor expects to earn 21 to 24 cents per share in the first quarter of fiscal 2005. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 21 cents in the September quarter. Shares of the company closed Thursday up 47 cents to $16.42. Ameritrade sees Q4 net at low end of previous forecast (8:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW)-- Ameritrade Holding AMTD, +3.49% said Friday it is expecting earnings in the fourth quarter to be at the lower end of its previous forecast of 10 cents to 22 cents per share. The current Thomson First Call average estimate is for earnings of 12 cents a share. Separately, the online brokerage said it saw 113,000 average client trades per day in August. The Omaha, Neb-based company opened 20,000 new accounts in the month and closed 10,000. Ameritrade said it now has a total of 3,509,000 client accounts. It also reported average client margin balances of around $3.2 billion for August. Shares of Ameritrade were down 0.1 percent at $11.73 at the close of trading Thursday. Alcoa's Q3 warning prompts Morgan Stanley downgrade (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Alcoa's AA, +1.22% third quarter profit warning overnight has prompted investment bank Morgan Stanley to slash its rating on the aluminum producer to "equal weight" from "overweight." Analyst Wayne Attwell said the downward revision reflects concern that higher energy, healthcare and freight costs will have a negative impact on earnings over the next 18 months. After the market close Thursday, Alcoa said it expects to report third-quarter operating earnings of 30 cents to 35 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting 52 cents a share. The company blamed the shortfall on a strike, a fire, restructuring costs and weaker-than-expected demand in some of its markets. The analyst cut his own earnings forecast for the third quarter to 35 cents a share to reflect the company's new estimates. However Attwell said Alcoa should be considered a core long-term metals holding as it is one of the few metals companies that should be able to earn its cost of capital. The cost of capital is the required return necessary to make investment in a capital project worthwhile. Shares of Alcoa were down 6.9 percent at $30.98 in pre-market trading in Instinet. Chip designer Transmeta lowers Q3 rev. outlook (6:15 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Chip designer Transmeta Corp. TMTA lowered its third quarter revenue outlook to a range of $6.8 million and $7.5 million against its earlier estimate at $8 million to $8.7 million. "Our current quarter sales will reflect our constrained product availability as we moved through our 90nm product qualification process," said the company. "In addition, our sales will be significantly affected by softening demand in the enterprise sector and by our customers' product lifecycle-related transitions within their Transmeta-based product lines." Premier Foods H1 sales up 14% to 96 mln pounds (2:49 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Premier Foods(UK:PFD), the maker of Branston Pickle, said pre-tax profits before exceptional items rose 17.7 percent to 96.5 million pounds for the half-year to July 3. Revenue increased 14.4 percent to 425.8 million pounds. Operating profit on continuing operations rose 28.9 percent to 35.6 million pounds. In its first results since listing on the stock exchange in July, Premier said: "We have grown sales, cut costs and developed our margin ahead of last year and in line with our strategy." It said the IPO enabled it to reduce net debt and its interest payments, which stand at 38.8 million pounds for the first half, should be "significantly" reduced. Looking ahead, it said: "While the trading environment remains tough, the second half of the year is looking positive, where seasonally better trading, brand performance and cost cutting measures are expected to contribute to our full-year results." Aga Foodservice: Orders for Rangemaster higher (2:18 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Aga Foodservice Group(UK:AGA), the U.K. kitchen appliance and food services provider, posted a 9.8 percent rise in sales in the first half of the year to 204.4 million pounds. Pre-tax profit rose 7.6 percent to 12.7 million pounds. Looking ahead, it said U.K. and European "consumer activity remains strong with Aga home surveys up and Rangemaster seeing a strong order book for the autumn. In the U.S., Domain's orders are edging up." In foodservice, it said U.K. and European order books "are healthier and are expected to deliver better results... U.S. foodservice markets are patchy but the focus on bakery products brings new opportunities." More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers AK Steel AKS, +5.84% shares gained 5.6 percent after the company raised the price of its Type 409 stainless steel products by 5 percent. The price increase will become effective on Sept. 27. The company cited increased demand and rising costs for the hike. Artesyn Technologies ATSN jumped 20.7 percent after the Boca Raton, Fla., computing and telecom component maker said its board would review an unsolicited acquisition approval from Bel Fuse BELFA, +3.21% The proposed bid is a swap of 0.265 of a share of Bel Fuse class B BELFB, +0.00% common stock for each Artesyn common share. Decode Genetics DCGN gained 11.9 percent after the company said it has appointed Deloitte & Touche as its independent public accountant, effective immediately. The appointment fills a gap created on Aug. 19 when PricewaterhouseCoopers resigned. Investment Technology ITG, +0.77% tacked on 4.2 percent after the company said its chief executive, Robert Russel, has resigned to pursue other interests. Russel will stay on as a consultant for the rest of this year. He will be replaced by Raymond Killian, the company's chairman, who served as chief executive twice before -- from 1994 to 1997 and from 1998 to 2002. Keynote Systems KEYN advanced 9.5 percent after the company acquired Vividence, a private provider of Web-based customer research, for $20 million in cash. Keynote said it may make an additional payment of $6 million, if certain targets are reached by Sept. 30. The company said that the deal is expected to increase fiscal year 2005 revenue by $11 million to $14 million. NetSolve NTSL added 21.9 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% in a deal worth about $128.4 million. See full story. Oracle ORCL, +1.71% rose 5.3 percent after a federal judge ruled late Thursday that the software company can pursue its $7.7 billion hostile takeover bid for rival PeopleSoft. See full story. PeopleSoft PSFT, +0.00% added 10.3 percent on news of the antitrust ruling and an upgrade from Merrill Lynch. See full story. Quiksilver ZQK rose 14.4 percent after the company, which makes youth-oriented clothing, reported higher profit for its fiscal third quarter and raised its 2004 forecasts. See full story. Safeguard Scientifics SFE, -2.39% jumped 9.1 percent after the company said its shareholders approved plans to sell its majority stake in CompuCom Systems CMPC, +0.04% to an affiliate of privately held Platinum Equity. Safeguard expects to receive about $128 million in gross cash proceeds for its common and preferred stock holdings in CompuCom. SigmaTel SGTL rose more than 5.5 percent after the chipmaker announced new applications for one of its key product ranges. The Austin, Texas-based company said a chip in its family of GoChip USB Mass Storage products will now be able to support Renesas Technology's AG-AND and Toshiba Corp.'s MLC flash memory, allowing for substantial improvements in storage density and system cost. Flash memory is used to store data in such devices as personal digital assistants, digital cameras and digital music players. Sonus Networks SONS jumped more than 11.5 percent after the company received a re-listing notice from Nasdaq. Take-Two Interactive Software TTWO, +0.33% surged 5.2 percent after the video-game maker said 2004 sales would be higher than analysts expected. See full story. Urban Outfitters URBN, +1.59% leapt 9.7 percent after the Philadelphia specialty apparel retailer said in a Form 10-Q filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its same-store sales remain "significantly ahead of plan" in the third quarter. Veritas Software VRTS, +0.36% rose 7.3 percent after the company said in a Form 8-K filing with the SEC that it has entered a pre-arranged stock trading plan for the buyback of up to $250 million worth of its common stock between Sept. 15 and March 15. Vishay Intertechnology VSH, +2.20% gained 8.6 percent after the Malvern, Pa., chipmaker said its third-quarter results would fall short of its expectations due to weak demand but that it anticipates sequential improvement in both revenue and earnings in the fourth quarter. Volterra Semiconductor VLTR rose 25.1 percent, advancing for a second straight session after the chipmaker posted strong second-quarter results. World Airways WLDA, -1.64% jumped 22.6 percent after the carrier said it expects to receive roughly $94 million in fiscal 2005 to provide fixed passenger flying services for the U.S. Air Force Mobility Command. The contract is part of a larger indefinite delivery/indefinite quantity contract, worth an estimated $998 million, awarded to World Airways and a group called the Alliance Contractor Team. Decliners Aceto Corporation ACET, +3.97% tumbled 5.4 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $3.3 million, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent earnings of $2.4 million, or 15 cents per share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 12 percent to $76.5 million in the fourth quarter. Looking ahead, the Lake Success, N.Y. chemical products distributor expects to earn 21 to 24 cents per share in the first quarter of fiscal 2005. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 21 cents in the September quarter. Aftermarket Technology ATAC, -0.60% fell 8.7 percent after the company said it will write off $16 million to $20 million worth of assets and take a $2.6 million charge to close a plant in North Carolina after losing a manufacturing contract from General Motors GM, +2.45% See full story. Alcoa AA, +1.22% slumped 7.4 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings to fall short of Wall Street forecasts, citing a strike, a fire and restructuring costs. See full story Brillian BRLC plunged 12.3 percent after the company cut its third-quarter outlook because it missed shipment targets. The company, which makes microdisplays for use in HDTVs, said it expects revenue of $600,000 to $800,000, down from its earlier projection of $2.8 million to $3.2 million. It sees a loss of $5.6 million to $6.1 million, wider than its previous forecast of a loss of $4.4 million to $4.9 million. Two analysts were looking for a loss of 64 cents a share on sales of $3 million. Capstead Mortgage CMO, -0.12% lost 9.6 percent after the Dallas-based real estate investment trust said it expects higher borrowing costs to dampen earnings "because interest rates on most of our borrowings rise (and fall) almost immediately with changes in short-term interest rates while ARM (adjustable-rate mortgage) security yields change slowly by comparison." The company, however, didn't provide an updated outlook. Secure Computing SCUR lost 4.5 percent after Wedbush Morgan lowered its rating on the stock to "sell" from "hold," saying it's receiving negative feedback about the company's sale, especially to government customers. The research firm, which also dropped its price target by 25 percent to $6, said it's "particularly concerned" about the ability of the San Jose provider of security technology to meet its third-quarter financial outlook for earnings of 8 cents per share and year-over-year sales growth of 17 percent. Transmeta TMTA dropped 9.5 percent after the chipmaker lowered its third-quarter revenue outlook to a range of $6.8 million to $7.5 million against its earlier estimate of $8 million to $8.7 million. Trico Marine Services TMAR plunged 22.6 percent after the company said Friday more than two thirds of the holders of its senior notes agreed to a restructuring that allows the company to convert its debt to equity. The swap of the marine services company's $250 million debt into stock will pave the way for a prepackaged bankruptcy filing in which current stockholders would receive warrants for 10 percent of a reorganized Trico. Visteon VC, +2.18% dropped 11 percent after the car parts maker warned that second-half and full-year earnings would come in "significantly below" earlier forecasts. Credit Suisse First Boston downgraded the company a full two notches to "underperform" from "outperform" and slashed its price target to $5 from $11. Visteon cited Ford's F, +2.03% lower-than-expected vehicle production estimates for the rest of 2004. See full story. title: Decode Genetics, Secure Computing, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aceto Corporation ACET, +3.97% reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $3.3 million, or 20 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent earnings of $2.4 million, or 15 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 20 cents per share. Sales rose 12 percent to $76.5 million in the fourth quarter. Looking ahead, the Lake Success, N.Y. chemical products distributor expects to earn 21 to 24 cents per share in the first quarter of fiscal 2005. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 21 cents in the September quarter. Shares of the company closed Thursday up 47 cents to $16.42.
title: Aceto posts in-line Q4 profit

content: Mesa Air completes financial restatements (8:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Mesa Air Group MESA completed a restatement of fiscal years 2001 through 2003 and the first quarter of 2004 Friday, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The restatements took the company's earnings on a per-share basis to 76 cents from 83 cents in 2003, widened its loss to 34 cents from 28 cents in 2002, and left its loss unchanged in 2001, at $1.50. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2003, Mesa's earnings were cut to 12 cents a share from 16 cents a share. The restatements were forced by an adjustment for depreciation on some of Mesa's aircraft during a period when they were on manufacturer-provided interim financing. Mesa stock ended Friday's session down 4.2 percent at $6.56. Edison International tops Q1 estimates (2:56 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Edison International EIX, +0.94% said it earned $97 million, or 30 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $57 million, or 17 cents a share a year ago, buoyed by improved earnings at its Edison Mission Energy unit and a gain on the sale of a stake. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 20 cents a share. Revenue edged back to $2.510 billion from $2.523 billion. Shares were last trading down 2.5 percent at $22.58. Frontier Airlines April load factor 69.1% vs 60.9% (2:43 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Frontier Airlines FRNT, +0.00% said its April load factor rose to 69.1 percent from 60.9 percent a year ago. The airline said revenue passenger miles rose 40 percent to 475 million as capacity increased 23.5 percent to 687.8 available seat miles. Shares were last trading down 1.2 percent at $9.00. Nuvelo tumbles after Q1 falls well short of estimates (11:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Nuvelo NUVO dropped 11 percent to $9.82 after posting a first quarter loss which was much wider than analysts were anticipating. The biotechnology company reported a net loss of $17.7 million, or 65 cents a share compared with a loss of $13.6 million, or 82 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for a quarterly loss of 25 cents a share. The company attributed the loss to increased development expenses related to a license for one of its new drugs, rNAPc2, a treatment for coronary disease and ongoing expense and research costs for another drug, ARC183, another cardiovascular treatment. Revenues also dipped to $600,000 from $1.3 million. Aceto climbs on strong Q3, upbeat Q4, 2004 outlook (11:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Aceto Corp ACET, +3.97% rose 8 percent to $15.13 after it gave an upbeat fourth quarter and full-year outlook in the wake of forecast-beating third quarter results.
