The company, which distributes chemically-derived pharmaceuticals, biopharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals, posted net income of $3.7 million, or 23 cents a share compared with $2.4 million, or 16 cents a share in the same period in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 20 cents a share. Sales climbed to $79.6 million from $70.5 million. Looking ahead, Aceto said it is forecasting fourth quarter earnings in the range of 20 cents to 23 cents a share, three cents ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by First Call. For fiscal 2004, the company is targeting earnings of 80 cents to 83 cents a share, compared with a First Call average estimate of 78 cents a share. Party City stock falls after Q1 report (11:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Party City PCTY, +1.13% shares fell 10 percent to $14.87 after the company reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $5.6 millon, or 33 cents per share, compared to a loss of $1.8 million, or 11 cents per share, a year ago. The Rockaway, N.J.-based party goods chain said the third-quarter loss includes a $4.1 million charge for the tentative settlement of a California class action suit relating to overtime wage and hour laws. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call for the March period was for a loss of 14 cents per share. Same-store sales for the third quarter fell 1 percent for company-owned stores and increased 1.3 percent for franchise stores. Party City attributed the difference to "different regional concentrations" of the stores. The company said total chain-wide sales rose 3.2 percent to $203.1 million. Commonwealth sees $10M in future cost for hedges (10:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Commonwealth CMIN stock fell 9 percent to $8 after the Louisville, Ky.-based aluminum sheet manufacturer reported first-quarter earnings of $2.9 million, or 18 cents per share, compared to a loss of $6.5 million, or 41 cents per share, a year ago. The latest results include a gain of $3 million, or 19 cents per share, related to certain aluminum hedge transactions. These transactions were necessary after the company determined the hedges it had in place to reduce its exposure to aluminum price fluctuations did not meet current accounting standards. Commonweath now expects to carry $10 million in costs related to these hedge transactions into future periods. The average estimate as polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 15 cents per share for the March quarter. Enesco slides after Q1 losses widen vs. year-ago (10:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Enesco Group ENC, -2.44% fell 8 percent to $12.05 after it posted a wider first quarter loss compared with the same quarter in 2003. The giftware, collectible and home decor company reported a net loss of $4.4 million, or 31 cents a share against a loss of $2.8 million, or 20 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Revenue climbed 9 percent to $50.5 million from $46.1 million, driven by contributions from its Bilston & Battersea and Gregg Gift acquisitions and its alliance with Walt Disney Art Classics. Favorable foreign currency exchange rates also boosted the company's top line. Enesco said chief financial officer Tom Bradley will continue to act as interim chief executive officer for the company while its search continues for a new CEO. Harvard Bioscience slumps on Q1 miss, 2004 outlook (10:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Harvard Bioscience HBIO, +0.00% tumbled 36 percent to $5.51 after first quarter earnings missed analyst expectations and the company lowered its full-year outlook. The maker of scientific instruments broke even in the first three months of the year after reporting a 3 cent a share profit in the same quarter a year ago. On an adjusted basis, the company posted earnings of 3 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 6 cents a share. Revenues rose 14 percent to $22.2 million from $19.5 million. CEO Chane Graziano attributed the earnings shortfall to the company's genomics, proteomics adn high-throughput screening products delivering "far less operating margin" than expected. Looking ahead, the company said the lack of profitability in these product lines will be a drag on earnings. It is now forecasting adjusted earnings for 2004 to be in the range of 22 cents to 24 cents per share on revenue, excluding further acquisitions, between $100 million to $105 million. The average estimate of two analysts polled by First Call is for earnings of 31 cents a share. Washington Mutual slides on Prudential downgrade (9:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Washington Mutual WM, +1.13% fell 52 cents, or 1.3 percent, to $39.28 after Prudential downgraded the company to "underweight" from "neutral," citing concerns over the relative strength of its mortgage banking business, risks related to layoffs and operations consolidation and the susceptibility of its business model to rising interest rates. "Finally, we believe Washington Mutual's earnings quality, growth and profits could continue to falter as the company goes through its current 'transition' period, which includes significant cost cuts -- $1 billion by mid-2005 - coincident with a major branch build-out - adding 250 in 2004. Analyst Bradley Ball also lowered his 2004 earnings forecast to $4.00 a share from $4.05 and his 2005 estimate to $4.45 a share from $4.60. Interpublic Group reports Q1 5c loss (9:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- The Interpublic Group IPG, +0.79% reported a first-quarter loss of $16.9 million, or 5 cents per share, wider than its year-ago loss of $8.6 million, or 2 cents per share, last year. The New York-based advertising and marketing firm said the latest results include a $70.2-million charge related to a restructuring program and $8.8 million in charges related to investment and asset impairment. The average analysts' estimate as polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of a penny per share in the March period. Revenue rose 6 percent in the latest three months to $1.4 billion from $1.3 billion in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Interpublic said it expects an $80 million charge in the second quarter due to termination of a contract with Formula One Administration Limited related to the British Grand Prix. Arizona electricity demand juices up Pinnacle West's Q1 (9:00 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Pinnacle West Capital PNW, +0.42% the parent of utility Arizona Public Service, saw its first-quarter results benefit from the hottest March weather ever recorded in the state. First-quarter net income came in at $30.2 million, or 33 cents per share, up from $25.3 million, or 28 cents, earned in the comparable 2003 period. The latest quarter's profit easily beat the 22-cent average of analyst estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Pinnacle West's operating income reached $83.4 million from $69.3 million in the year-ago first quarter, as revenue climbed to $574.4 million from $552.6 million. Arizona Public's retail electricity consumption rose by 10.3 percent from the first three months of 2003, Pinnacle West said. Shares of Pinnacle West ended Thursday's action at $38.72, up 11 cents. FirstEnergy's Q1 adjusted profit misses by 3 cents (8:51 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- FirstEnergy FE, -1.10% reported first-quarter net earnings of $174 million, or 53 cents per share, down from the prior year's $218.5 million, or 74 cents. Backing out special items -- most notably, replacement-power and maintenance costs associated with the company's Davis-Besse nuclear plant -- FirstEnergy came in with earnings of $212.3 million, or 65 cents per share. This compared to an adjusted profit of $166.6 million, or 57 cents, in the year-ago first quarter, but the per-share profit missed the average estimate of 68 cents as compiled by Thomson First Call. Quarterly revenue dropped to $3.18 billion from $3.22 billion. Despite the profit miss, CEO Anthony Alexander called FirstEnergy's latest results "strong," citing the now-completed restart of Davis-Besse and a rate-stabilization plan before Ohio regulators. Shares of FirstEnergy slipped 6 cents to end Thursday's trading at $38.53. Pioneer Natural Resources posts in-line Q1 net (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Pioneer Natural Resources PXD, +2.54% posted first quarter net income of $60.2 million, or 50 cents a share compared with $84.2 million, or 71 cents a share in the year-ago quarter, which included a one-time benefit of 13 cents a share due to a change in accounting procedures. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 50 cents a share. Revenue soared to $448.2 million from $289.1 million. First quarter oil and gas sales averaged 185,858 barrels per day on a barrel oil equivalent basis. Looking ahead, the company said oil and gas production in the second quarter is expected to average 180,000 to 195,000 per barrel oil equivalent. Shares of Pioneer Natural Resources were down 2.8 percent at $31.58 at the close of trading Thursday. Dreyer's reports Q1 loss of 85c per share (8:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Holdings DRYR reported a first-quarter net loss of $18.8 million, or 85 cents per share, compared to $9.3 million, or 14 cents per share, a year ago. The gap in the Oakland, Calif.-based ice cream and frozen-dessert firm 's numbers year-over-year is due to the merger of Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream and Nestle Ice Cream Company last June. Due to the "reverse acquisition accounting" for the merger, the operating results of the new company are not directly comparable with the results of either company for the corresponding prior year period. The company's revenue rose 194 percent to $337.9 million for the quarter ended March 27, from $114.8 million in the first quarter of 2003. Cornell Companies posts in-line adj Q1 net (8:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Cornell Companies CRN, +0.33% posted first quarter net income of $700,000, or 5 cents a share compared with $2 million, or 15 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Excluding exceptional items, earnings were $1.8 million, or 14 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 14 cents a share. Looking ahead, Cornell said it expects adjusted earnings in the second quarter of 19 cents a share, which excludes pre-opening and start-up costs for new facilities and losses associated with its New Morgan Academy. For 2004, the company is forecasting adjusted earnings of 90 cents a share. The First Call average estimate is for second quarter and full-year earnings of 19 cents and 89 cents per share respectively. Shares of Cornell were up 0.4 percent at $12.15 at the close of trading Thursday. Hain Celestial misses Q3 forecasts, Q4 to also miss (8:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Hain Celestial HAIN, +0.69% reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $5 million, or 14 cents a share, down from 23 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 16 cents a share, due primarily to higher costs and problems with soup supply. Sales rose 6 percent to $136.9 million, missing analyst forecasts of $141.2 million. The natural and organic foods company said it expects cost to continue to rise and the time needed to rebuild its soup position will result in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 13 to 15 cents a share and revenue of $127 million to $130 million, vs. current analyst projections of 20 cents and $131.8 million, respectively. The stock closed Thursday up 32 cents at $18.57. MTR Gaming Q1 net tops Street estimates by 2c (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- MTR Gaming Group MNTG posted first quarter net income of $3 million, or 11 cents a share compared with $3.3 million, or 12 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 9 cents a share. Revenues rose 19 percent to $75.7 million from $63.6 million. The casino group reiterated its 2004 earnings forecast of net income between $15 million and $17 million on revenue expected to be in a range of $323 million to $335 million. MTR is also maintained its estimate of earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization between $59 million to $62 million. Shares of MTR were up 2 cents at $9.16 at the close of trading Thursday. CompuDyne reports weaker-than-expected Q1 (8:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- CompuDyne CDCY reported a first-quarter loss of $307,000, or 4 cents per share, down from earnings of $942,000, or 12 cents per share, last year. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call was for first-quarter earnings of 3 cents per share. The Hanover, Md.-based public security firm attributed the loss to depressed conditions in the company's Institutional Security Systems business, and delays in awards in the Attack Protection business, resulting in six straight quarters of declining backlogs. The company also said that budget deficits at the state and local government levels have slowed down prison construction contracts and new software projects for public safety. Looking ahead, the company expects "continued weak results" in the second quarter of 2004, "potentially significantly improved results" in the second half of 2004, and "is planning a return to normal levels of profitability and growth" in 2005. CompuDyne stock closed Thursday down 20 cents at $10. Martha Stewart Q1 loss wider than expected (7:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Martha Steward Living Omnimedia MSO, +0.00% reported a first-quarter loss from continuing operations of $20.3 million, or 41 cents a share, vs. a loss of 9 cents a share in the same period a year ago, wider than the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 20 cents a share, due primarily to higher income tax expense. Revenue fell 23 percent to $44.5 million, just shy of the $45.2 million expected by analysts, amid a 30 percent drop in publishing revenue, a 36 percent slide in TV revenue and 4.8 percent growth in merchandising revenue. The media company added that a analysis of its business indicated that magazine subscribers were unfazed by the verdict of its founder Martha Stewart. Looking ahead, the company expects to lose 35 to 40 cents a share in the second quarter, vs. current analyst loss projections of 12 cents. The stock closed Thursday down 11 cents at $9.70. Ballard Power reports wider-than-expected Q1 loss (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Ballard Power Systems BLDP, +1.43% reported a first-quarter net loss of $525 million, or 31 cents a share, vs. a loss of 19 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and wider than the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 28 cents a share, due to weakness at its engineering service business and the negative impact of currency translation. Revenue fell 52 percent to $16 million, below analyst forecasts of $24.07 million. The Canada-based fuel cell company's stock closed Thursday down 22 cents at $10.30. Hollis-Eden Q1 loss narrows, but wider than expected (7:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Hollis-Eden Pharmaceuticals HEPH reported a first-quarter net loss of $5.9 million, or 31 cents a share, narrower than the 40 cents a share it lost in the year-earlier period, but a penny a share wider than the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Research and development costs rose 81 percent to $4.7 million. Cash and cash equivalents totaled $79.2 million at the end of March, while first-quarter cash used increased 93 percent to $5.4 million. The drugmaker's stock closed Thursday up 2 cents at $7.20. ATA Holdings Q1 loss widens (7:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - ATA Holdings ATAH reported a first-quarter net loss of $64.7 million, or $5.47 a share, vs. a loss of 97 cents a share in the same period a year ago, due to a one-time accounting related charge, price and capacity competition and high fuel prices. Total revenue rose 3.7 percent to $387.3 million, as 13 percent increase in scheduled service revenue helped offset an 18 percent decline in charter service revenue. Traffic at the air carrier increased 5.9 percent to 3.57 billion revenue passenger miles, but load factor fell 2.8 percentage points to 67 percent as capacity rose 20 percent to 4.6 billion available seat miles. Cost per available seat mile grew 4.3 percent to 7.34 cents. The stock closed Thursday down 12 cents at $7.88. Macerich Q1 FFO, revenue rise above expectations (6:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Macerich MAC, -1.56% reported first-quarter funds from operations (FFO) of $68.7 million, or 90 cents a share, up from 84 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 86 cents a share. Total revenue, before an accounting change, rose 7.6 percent to $123.8 million, topping analyst forecasts of $120.4 million, amid strength in retail sales growth and high occupancy levels. Net income fell to $18.1 million, or 31 cents a share from 37 cents a share. The mall-focused real estate investment trust also reiterated its 2004 FFO forecast of $3.78 to $3.88 a share. The stock closed Thursday up 39 cents at $42.17. Sanders Morris Q1 earns more than double (6:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Sanders Morris Harris Group SMHG reported fiscal first-quarter net income of $3.3 million, or 18 cents a share, up from 7 cents a share in the same period a year ago, driven by strength in its investment banking and asset management businesses. Revenue increased 43 percent to $29.8 million. The stock closed Thursday up 71 cents at $13.92. Longs Drug Q1 same-store sales rose 2.7 percent (6:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Longs Drug Stores LDG, -22.86% said fiscal first-quarter same-store sales rose 2.7 percent over the same period a year ago, amid a 3.7 percent increase in pharmacy sales and 1.9 percent growth in front-end store sales. Total sales rose 5.1 percent to $1.16 billion, vs. the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.14 billion. For the month of April, same-store sales increased 2.3 percent, with pharmacy and front-end sales rising 4.7 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively, and total sales grew 4.1 percent to $357.4 million. The drugstore chain's stock closed Thursday down 16 cents at $19.75. Krispy Kreme warns of fiscal Q1, 2005 earnings miss (6:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Krispy Kreme KKD warned that fiscal first-quarter and 2005 earnings would miss expectations, as sales of packaged doughnuts to grocery stores have been hurt by increased consumer interest in low-carbohydrate diets. The doughnut seller now expects earnings excluding special items of 23 cents for its quarter ending April and $1.04 to $1.06 for the year ending January 2005, vs. the average analyst estimates compiled by Thomson First Call of 27 cents and $1.17, respectively. Systemwide-sales for the first quarter are expected to have increased 24 percent. The stock closed Thursday down 57 cents at $31.80. Total says Q1 net falls 8%, favorable climate in Q2 (2:58 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- French oil giant Total TOT, +2.65% (FR:012027)on Friday said first quarter net income declined 8 percent to 1.96 billion euros, on a 2 percent decline in sales to 27.3 billion euros. The company said the results were impacted by weakness in the dollar, a decline in European refining margins, slightly higher hydrocarbon prices and a rebound in chemicals. Total said the second quarter has seen a favorable oil market environment due to demand growth and low inventory levels, with both oil prices and refining margins at high levels. The average Brent price for the quarter was $32/barrel, a rise of 2 percent, while European refining margins dropped 33 percent on a pullback from the high levels reached last year on market tensions. Deutsche Boerse Q1 EBIT up 5.3% on market recovery (2:26 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- German stock exchange and futures market operator Deutsche Boerse(DE:581005)late Thursday said first quarter EBIT rose by 5.3 percent to 132.8 million euros, on a 8 percent revenue rise to 379.1 million euros. "The recovery of equity markets is benefiting the securities custody business, cash market trading, and the settlement of on and off-exchange transactions," the company said, though operating profits declined 17 percent at Eurex due to the start of its U.S. derivatives exchange. P&O Q1 ferry passengers down, container vol. higher (2:20 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Peninsular & Oriental Steam Nav. Co.(UK:PO), the U.K. shipping, ports and ferries group, said Friday container volume in ports rose 17 percent in the first quarter amid strength in Asia and Europe. It saw a record container volumes in P&O terminals in China and India. Ferries' tourist rates improved despite a decline in overall market volumes. Passengers on ferries declined to 2.1 million from 2.275 million in the year-ago period. Freight volumes were broadly unchanged but freight rates were down on the first quarter. United Utilities sees UK 3.2 bn in water cap ex to 2010 (2:15 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- United Utilities(UK:UU), a FTSE 100 stock, said its final budget of 3.2 billion pounds for capital spending from 2005 to 2010 at its water and wastewater subsidiary United Utilities Water. The utility expects customer bills will need to increase by an average of 7.8 percent ahead of retail price inflation each year to fund the plans. The budget is down from the 3.8 billion pounds in spending initially expected, it said. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Monday's session is Bally Total Fitness BFT, -0.54% The gym chain is expected to report a first-quarter loss of 20 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Cablevision Systems CVC, -0.36% is seen posting a loss of 37 cents a share for the first quarter. First-quarter numbers for Dendreon DNDN are expected to show a loss of 27 cents a share. Pacific Sunwear's PSUN first-quarter results are seen coming in at a per-share profit of 17 cents. Symbol Technologies SBL, +5.07% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 8 cents a share. Clear Channel Communications CCU, +2.26% Chairman and Chief Executive Lowry Mays said Friday that he is taking sick leave to recover from surgery he underwent last week to relieve swelling in his brain. Mark Mays, the company's chief operating officer, will assume the role of chief executive until Lowry Mays' return. The shares closed Friday at $40.48, down 67 cents, ahead of the announcement. Mesa Air Group MESA completed a restatement of fiscal years 2001 through 2003 and the first quarter of 2004 Friday, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The restatements took the company's earnings on a per-share basis to 76 cents from 83 cents in 2003, widened its loss to 34 cents from 28 cents in 2002, and left its loss unchanged in 2001, at $1.50. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2003, Mesa's earnings were cut to 12 cents a share from 16 cents a share. The restatements were forced by an adjustment for depreciation on some of Mesa's aircraft during a period when they were on manufacturer-provided interim financing. Mesa stock ended Friday's session down 4.2 percent at $6.56. Sprint FON, +5.56% said it would cut an 550 additional jobs by the end of the year in its restructuring efforts, according to a quarterly filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, bringing the total number of layoffs to 2,550. The phone company said in November that it would cut 2,000 jobs as part a series of measures to reduce costs by 5 to 7 percent over the next three years, with annual savings eventually expected to top $1 billion. As of March 31, roughly 1,750 of the layoffs had taken place, according to the filing. Sprint also said it does not expect pre-tax charges to exceed $90 million. Additional charges associated with the layoffs will be recorded in subsequent periods and will impact all of the company's divisions. Shares of Sprint ended Friday's session down 1.3 percent at $17.76. Friday's advancers Shares of Aceto Corp ACET, +3.97% leapt almost 11 percent after it gave an upbeat fourth-quarter and full-year outlook in the wake of forecast-beating third-quarter results. The company, which distributes chemically-derived pharmaceuticals, biopharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals, posted net income of $3.7 million, or 23 cents a share, up from 16 cents a share in the same period in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 20 cents a share. Sales climbed to $79.6 million from $70.5 million. Looking ahead, Aceto said it is forecasting fourth-quarter earnings in the range of 20 cents to 23 cents a share, three cents ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by First Call. For fiscal 2004, the company is targeting earnings of 80 cents to 83 cents a share, above analyst forecasts of 78 cents. Faro Technologies FARO, +1.83% shares surged more than 25 percent after the company reported a sharp increase in first-quarter earnings as revenue climbed 57 percent and margins improved. Faro, which makes computerized measurement devices and related software, posted earnings of 20 cents after 4 cents a year ago. Revenue rose to $21 million from $13.4 million, while margins rose 8 percentage points to 64 percent. The company reiterated its outlook for 2004 of 71 to 86 cents a share. National Commerce Financial shares NCF, +0.00% shot up more than 13 percent after saying it was reviewing "strategic alternatives," including remaining independent, after a report said the bank may be at the center of a bidding war. The Memphis, Tenn.-based company is in talks with SunTrust Banks STI, +2.22% and Cleveland-based Fifth-Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% to be sold for as much as $6 billion, according to a report in Friday's Wall Street Journal citing anonymous sources. Shares of Viisage VISG ran up 13 percent after the maker of identity verification technology won a $10.2 million contract from the U.S Department of Defense. Under the terms of the deal, Viisage will supply desktop printers, as well as consumables and services, to be used in the production of secure identification cards for the Department of Defense's Defense Manpower Data Center (DMDC). The work will be carried out through Telos, the DMDC's support contractor. Friday's decliners Ballard Power Systems BLDP, +1.43% slumped almost 5 percent after the fuel cell company reported a first-quarter net loss of $525 million, or 31 cents a share, vs. a loss of 19 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and wider than the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 28 cents a share, due to weakness at its engineering service business and the negative impact of currency translation. Revenue fell 52 percent to $16 million, below analyst forecasts of $24.07 million. Shares of Enesco Group ENC, -2.44% ended down more than 12 percent after it posted a wider first-quarter loss compared with the same quarter in 2003. The giftware, collectible and home decor company reported a net loss of $4.4 million, or 31 cents a share against a loss of $2.8 million, or 20 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Revenue climbed 9 percent to $50.5 million from $46.1 million, driven by contributions from its Bilston & Battersea and Gregg Gift acquisitions and its alliance with Walt Disney Art Classics. Shares of Harvard Bioscience HBIO, +0.00% plunged 45 percent after first-quarter earnings missed analyst expectations and the company lowered its full-year outlook. The maker of scientific instruments broke even in the first three months of the year after reporting a 3-cent per share profit in the same quarter a year ago. On an adjusted basis, the company posted earnings of 3 cents a share, half the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call, due to operating margin that was "far less" than expected. Revenues rose 14 percent to $22.2 million from $19.5 million. Looking ahead, the company is forecasting adjusted 2004 earnings of 22 to 24 cents per share vs. analyst forecasts of 31 cents. Homestore HOMS shed more than 13 percent after it disappointed Wall Street late Thursday with a modest first-quarter revenue gain and a net loss from its Web sites catering to the real-estate industry. Homestore said it lost $5 million, or 4 cents per share. In the year-ago period, it earned $87.2 million, or 72 cents per share. Homestore increased revenue by 8 percent to $56 million from $54.9 million in the comparable period a year ago. See full story. Krispy Kreme KKD took a more than 29-percent dive after it warned that fiscal first-quarter and 2005 earnings would miss expectations, as sales of packaged doughnuts to grocery stores have been hurt by increased consumer interest in low-carbohydrate diets. The doughnut seller now expects earnings excluding special items of 23 cents for its quarter ending April and $1.04 to $1.06 for the year ending January 2005, vs. the average analyst estimates compiled by Thomson First Call of 27 cents and $1.17, respectively. Systemwide-sales for the first quarter are expected to have increased 24 percent. See full story. Martha Steward Living Omnimedia MSO, +0.00% was knocked lower by more than 6 percent after it reported a first-quarter loss from continuing operations of $20.3 million, or 41 cents a share, vs. a loss of 9 cents a share in the same period a year ago, wider than the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 20 cents a share, due primarily to higher income tax expense. Revenue fell 23 percent to $44.5 million, just shy of the $45.2 million expected by analysts, amid a 30 percent drop in publishing revenue, a 36 percent slide in TV revenue and 4.8 percent growth in merchandising revenue. Looking ahead, the company expects to lose 35 to 40 cents a share in the second quarter, vs. current analyst loss projections of 12 cents. Shares of Nuvelo NUVO fell more than 10 percent after the company posted a first-quarter loss which was much wider than analysts were anticipating. The biotechnology company reported a net loss of $17.7 million, or 65 cents a share compared with a loss of $13.6 million, or 82 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for a quarterly loss of 25 cents a share. The company attributed the loss to increased development expenses related to a license for one of its new drugs, rNAPc2, a treatment for coronary disease and ongoing expense and research costs for another drug, ARC183, another cardiovascular treatment. Revenues also dipped to $600,000 from $1.3 million. Party City PCTY, +1.13% shed more than 16 percent after the company reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $5.6 million, or 33 cents per share, compared with a loss of $1.8 million, or 11 cents per share, a year ago. The Rockaway, N.J.-based party goods chain said the third-quarter loss includes a $4.1 million charge for the tentative settlement of a California class action suit relating to overtime wage and hour laws. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call for the March period was for a loss of 14 cents per share. Same-store sales for the third quarter fell 1 percent for company-owned stores and increased 1.3 percent for franchise stores, while total chain-wide sales rose 3.2 percent to $203.1 million. Symbol Technologies SBL, +5.07% dropped more than 5 percent after the software company said late Thursday that a court ruled that its Telxon subsidiary would have to pay $218 million to Smart Media. Symbol and Telxon plan to appeal the judgment. Smart Media had filed suit against Telxon in 1999, alleging that it suffered financial losses after Telxon failed, following discussions between the companies, to form a business alliance or provide financial support to develop the "Smart handle" product. Shares of VistaCare VSTA tumbled almost 33 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based provider of hospice services lowered its outlook for 2004 about 5 percent to between 93 and 98 cents per share. The average analysts' estimate for the full year as polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $1.02 per share. The company cited problems recruiting marketing staff, which led to lower admissions. The company also reported first-quarter earnings of $3.7 million, or 22 cents per share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.8 million, or 17 cents per share. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Monday: CCU, FON, PSUN, BFT, DNDN

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Aceto Corp ACET, +3.97% rose 8 percent to $15.13 after it gave an upbeat fourth quarter and full-year outlook in the wake of forecast-beating third quarter results. The company, which distributes chemically-derived pharmaceuticals, biopharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals, posted net income of $3.7 million, or 23 cents a share compared with $2.4 million, or 16 cents a share in the same period in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 20 cents a share. Sales climbed to $79.6 million from $70.5 million. Looking ahead, Aceto said it is forecasting fourth quarter earnings in the range of 20 cents to 23 cents a share, three cents ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by First Call. For fiscal 2004, the company is targeting earnings of 80 cents to 83 cents a share, compared with a First Call average estimate of 78 cents a share.
title: Aceto climbs on strong Q3, upbeat Q4, 2004 outlook

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% rallied more than 10 percent to $25.16 after the company agreed to acquire Pharma Waldhof, the biopharmaceutical distribution unit of Switzerland's Roche Holding AG. Financial terms weren't disclosed, but Aceto said it would fund the deal with cash on hand, and that it wouldn't incur or assume any debt in connection with the deal. Earlier in the session, the stock hit a 52-week high of $26.34.
title: Aceto jumps on acquisition of Roche unit

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to be active during Monday's trading session, telecom software supplier Comverse Technology CMVT is expected to post a second-quarter loss of 4 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Remec REMC a maker of voice and data transmission equipment, is seen reporting a loss of 7 cents a share for the second quarter. Software maker Ulticom ULTI, +2.55% is expected to post a second-quarter profit of 2 cents a share. Israel-based software maker Verint Systems VRNT, +13.90% will report results from the second quarter and is expected to show a profit of 14 cents a share. Tenet Healthcare THC, +1.76% said late Friday that it's being investigated by the Senate Finance Committee. The probe centers on Tenet's corporate governance in matters of federal health care programs. The committee has asked Tenet to supply it with documents relating primarily to its Redding Medical Center, physician relationships, alleged unnecessary medical procedures and Medicare outlier payments, according to a company statement. Tenet said it will cooperate with the committee. Shares ended Friday's session down 2 percent at $15.66. Cancer diagnostic company Impath IMPH said that the Securities and Exchange Commission has opened a formal investigation of possible accounting irregularities. Impath said it would continue to cooperate with the SEC. The company also said it didn't appeal the Nasdaq's decision to delist Impath shares, which are now listed on the OTC Pink Sheets. Shares of Impath closed at $4.05 on the over-the-counter market. They fell 5 cents in late trading but volume was extremely thin. One person was killed and 10 injured in an accident at Disney's DIS, +1.93% Anaheim, California amusement park Friday. Shares of Disney fell 2.1 percent in late trade action, to $20.75. Gen-Probe GPRO, -1.03% which makes diagnostic tests, said its board had approved a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend. Shares of Gen-Probe added 27 cents to change hands for $59.78. Shares of business communications company Via Net.Works VNWI fell 3 cents to $1.34 after announcing that CFO Fraser Park had resigned for personal reasons. Park will leave the firm at the end of September and corporate controller Matt Gough, will become interim CFO Barr Labs BRL, -30.00% said it received FDA approval to market its Seasonale Extended-Cycle oral contraceptive, which reduces a women's menstrual period to four from 13 times a year. Pacific Sunwear PSUN said late Friday that its board had approved a 3-for-2 stock split. The shares will begin trading on a split-adjusted basis on Monday. Shares of PacSun edge higher in by 19 cents to $32.04 in late trading action. Friday's advancers Andrx ADRX gained more than 11 percent after the company said it has agreed to settle patent infringement litigation related to a generic version of Glucotrol XL, a drug that helps control blood sugar levels for people with type 2 diabetes. Pfizer and Alza have agreed to dismiss their lawsuits against Andrx, and Andrx will receive a royalty-bearing sub-license under relevant Alza patents. This will allow it to manufacture and market products under its abbreviated new drug application for Glucotrol. Additionally, no later than January 1, Pfizer will supply Andrx with all or any strength of its product for sale by Andrx as an authorized generic under Pfizer's own new drug application. Chartered Semiconductor CHRT, -0.70% gained nearly 10 percent after the company raised its third quarter revenue outlook on stronger-than-expected demand in its computer segment. In its mid-quarter update yesterday, Chartered said it's now expecting third quarter revenue of about $183 million, up 30 pct from a year ago and ahead of a projected 10 percent increase for the overall chip market. Chartered also reduced its loss per share forecast by a penny. JP Morgan analysts reiterated an "overweight" rating on the stock despite the good news. Chartered trades "far above its fundamental value" given the challenge it faces in reaching break-even, they said. Shares of Descartes Systems DSGX, +2.70% added almost 8 percent after RBC Capital Markets raised the stock to "outperform" from "perform" following second quarter earnings yesterday. Analyst David Beck said business at Descartes, which operates a network linking suppliers to transport partners, is back on track. "After successive disappointments and restructurings, the recent quarter and business outlook suggest that Descartes's business has stabilized based on sequential revenue growth, network sign ups, and new partnerships," Beck told clients. Descarte's valuation is also attractive, trading at 7 times 2004 revenue based on embedded value, he said. G-III Apparel Group GIII, +3.01% rose more than 28 percent. After Thursday's closing bell, the company posted second-quarter profit of $2.7 million, or 37 cents per share, up from its year-ago earnings of $576,000, or 8 cents per share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $45.3 million from $40 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed its strong results to the stellar performance of its sports apparel business. Looking ahead, G-III sees earnings of $1.10 to $1.15 per share on sales of about $220 million Impax Laboratories IPXL, +0.00% jumped nearly 6 percent after the company received tentative approval of its abbreviated new drug application for a generic version of Oxycontin, a pain management medication marketed by Purdue Pharma. The company said final approval is contingent upon the earlier of either resolution of pending patent-infringement litigation brought by Purdue Pharma, the expiration of the 30-month stay process under the Hatch-Waxman Amendments or the expiration of any generic marketing exclusivity. IntraBiotics IBPI soared almost 111 percent after the company received fast track designation for the development of iseganan for use in patients receiving mechanical ventilation to reduce the risk of pneumonia from the Food and Drug Administration. I-Stat STAT added more than 6 percent after the company received clearance by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to market its Cardiac Troponin I test, a device that tests for heart damage and produces results in 10 minutes. Metris MXT, +0.50% posted double-digit gains for the second straight day Friday, and was the top percentage gainer on the NYSE. The shares rose more than 19 percent Friday after adding more than 17 percent in the previous session. Analysts and investors have been arguing over the company's prospects for months, and the shares have been beaten down by those that argue its short term funding issues are likely to keep the price down. On Wednesday, Jefferies & Co. said in a research report that it believes, after discussions with company management, that the liquidity concerns were "overblown". Nortel Networks NT gained nearly 8 percent after the company after Standard & Poor's revised its outlook on the telecom equipment company to a "stable" from "negative" late Thursday. S&P also affirmed its credit rating on the Canadian firm. S&P said challenging end-markets and ongoing weakness in macroeconomic conditions for Nortel are partially offset by its strong position in its market segments and improving operating performance. S&P also affirmed its credit ratings on Lucent Technologies LU late Thursday. SuperGen SUPG rose almost 8 percent after the Dublin, Calif., drug firm said founder Joseph Rubinfeld would resign as chairman and CEO on Dec. 31. Rubinfeld will become chairman emeritus and continue to serve as a director. The company named James Manuso to succeed Rubinfeld on Jan. 1, 2004. Friday's decliners Aceto ACET, +3.97% shares fell more than 15 percent. Before the opening bell, the Lake Success, N.Y., chemicals distributor reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.4 million, or 23 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $1.6 million, or 17 cents per share. Sales rose 5 percent in the latest three months to $68.1 million. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of at least 20 cents per share in the first quarter, and 22 cents per share in the second quarter. This outlook excludes any contributions from new product launches. Atari ATAR, +0.00% shares fell nearly 11 percent after the company said it expects a year-over-year decline in second-quarter earnings due to a lack of new product releases. Last year, the company earned $731,000, or a penny per share, on revenue of $109.4 million, in the September quarter. Atari plans to release the bulk of its new products for fiscal 2004 in the first, third and fourth quarters. For the year, the New York-based video game firm forecast earnings of between $35 million and $45 million on revenue of $560 million to $590 million. Atari also said it would account for its issuance of stock to satisfy debt to Infogrames as a dividend, and it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $125 million worth of common stock. Proceeds will be used to reduce debt and for general corporate purposes. CarMax KMX, +2.14% slid more than 6 percent after the company raised its outlook for its second quarter earnings to 36 cents a share, up from a previous projection for earnings from 33-35 cents a share after posting a 14 percent rise for second quarter ending Aug. 31 to $1.24 billion. Same-store sales rose 6 percent for the quarter. Dot Hill Systems HILL tumbled almost 19 percent after the company reaffirmed its outlook for the remainder of 2003, saying it expects earnings of 9 cents per share on revenue of $46 million in the third quarter, and a profit of 15 cents per share on revenue of $55 million in the fourth quarter. This performance would add up to earnings of 25 cents per share on revenue of $180 million for 2003. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call, however, is for a profit of 30 cents per share in fiscal 2003. Finish Line FINL, -2.52% shares fell nearly 7 percent after Merrill Lynch cut its rating on the stock to "neutral" from "buy". Analyst Virginia Genereux said the company's recent strong performance is "increasingly baked" into the share price. "We are troubled by the stock's recent response to positive news --yesterday the stock opened up over 10 percent but actually closed down, on August quarter comps up a monster 21 percent," she said. The move suggests investors are moving to lock in gains made since the stock hit lows last fall. Despite the rating downgrade, Merrill is raising its fiscal 2004 EPS estimate to $1.67 from a prior $1.42. The brokerage is forecasting same-store sales growth of 17 percent for the period, up from an earlier forecast of 11.4 percent growth. H&R Block HRB, +1.03% dipped almost 5 percent after the company said late Thursday that its CFO, Frank Cotroneo, will step down Oct. 31. The tax-preparation company is searching for a successor to Cotroneo, who joined H&R Block in February of 2000. Shares of Royal & Sun Alliance RSA, -0.25% tumbled nearly 5 percent after JP Morgan cut the stock to "underweight" from "overweight" on news of a dilutive $1.5 billion rights issue and possible $1.2 billion third-quarter charge. Standard & Poor's placed the company's ratings outlook on CreditWatch negative on the news released yesterday. JP Morgan analyst Gordon Aitken said RSA's decision to sell the renewal rights for much of its U.S. business is disappointing as it reduces diversification and may place the company's 'A' rating at risk. "We believe the group's UK life funds, which have significant guaranteed annuity liabilities, may see greater capital requirements as a result of the introduction of realistic accounting," said Aitken. "We do not expect RSA's share price to rally in the same way as Zurich's rose following its rights issue." Versata VATA lost almost 24 percent after the Oakland, Calif., business software firm reported a third-quarter pro forma loss of $1.4 million, or 19 cents per share, slightly wider than its year-ago equivalent loss of $1.3 million, or 18 cents per share. Revenue dropped to $2.7 million in the latest three months from $4.6 million in the same period a year earlier. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Monday: CMVT, ULTI, THC, IMPH, DIS

content: Interpublic swings to loss and misses target (4:32 PM ET) Interpublic Group reported a first-quarter net loss of $8.6 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. Wall Street's consensus estimated profit of 7 cents a share. The advertising group earned $59.8 million, or 16 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Interpublic IPG, +0.79% cited weak demand and higher costs for the shortfall. Shares of Interpublic, halted in after-hours trading, dropped more than 2 percent to $11.309 in the regular session. Nvidia Q1 earns 12c, revenue $405m (4:25 PM ET) Nvidia NVDA, +4.63% said it rode increased market share and new product launches to first-quarter financial results that topped expectations. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research expected earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $409.8 million, on average. Univision Q1 profit jumps 68 percent (4:21 PM ET) Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications said after the market closed that its first-quarter profit rose 68 percent over the year-ago period on increased ratings at its television networks. The company said it earned $12.8 million, or 5 cents a share, compared to $7.6 million, or 3 cents, in the same quarter last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected a profit of 4 cents in the latest period. Revenue rose 22 percent to $261.7 million; respondents to First Call were looking for a figure of $258.4 million. Shares of Los Angeles-based Univision UVN, +0.00% fell $1.60 to close at $29.15 ahead of the announcement. Activision reports loss, meets target (4:21 PM ET) Video-game publisher Activision ATVI, +2.26% reported a fiscal fourth-quarter net loss, although the company met Wall Street targets. Santa Monica, Calif-based Activision's net loss was $8 million, or 13 cents a share. A year earlier, the company earned $10.9 million, or 17 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting a loss of 13 cents, on average. The company's sales were $125 million, down from $164.9 million a year earlier. Activision shares fell 50 cents to $17.57, ahead of the report. Service Corp. tops by a penny in Q1 (1:35 PM ET) Service Corp. International SRV, +0.58% is up almost 8 percent to $3.72 after the Houston-based funeral and cemetery services firm reported first-quarter earnings of $42.3 million, or 13 cents per share, a penny ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue slid to $580.1 million in the latest three months from $601.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Delhaize shares get boost from Q1 results (1:22 PM ET) Shares of Delhaize Group DEG, +10.00% are rallying more than 22 percent to $28.70 on the New York Stock Exchange. Before the opening bell, the Brussels-based self-service food retailer reported first-quarter earnings of EUR 0.50 per share on sales of EUR 4.7 billion. The company said the significant cost savings program at its Food Lion stores and continued commercial successes at its Hannaford and Delhaize Belgium stores, and in Greece offset the adverse impact of the weak dollar, and slumping sales at its Food Lion and Kash n' Karry stores. The company also backed its outlook for the full year. Christopher & Banks gets lift from April sales results (12:42 PM ET) Christopher & Banks CBK, +1.90% is adding more than 4 percent to $26.22 after the Minneapolis women's apparel retailer reported April same-store sales rose 2 percent. Total sales for the five weeks ended May 3 jumped 24 percent to $36.8 million from $29.7 million in the same period a year earlier. "Although economic conditions remain uncertain and we face difficult same-store sales comparisons in May and June, we remain confident in our long-term prospects and are encouraged by our improving sales trends," said Bill Prange, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. U.S. Industries' shares give back 8 percent (12:24 PM ET) U.S. Industries USI, -3.27% is tripping more than 8 percent to $4.55 after the West Palm Beach, Fla., maker of bath and plumbing products reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $5.8 million, or 8 cents per share, a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Including an impairment charge of $39.9 million related to its asset disposal plan, the company lost $33.3 million, or 45 cents per share, in the latest quarter. The company said reduced margins in its domestic whirlpool bath product lines hurt operating income in the period. Looking ahead, U.S. Industries forecast a increase of 12 percent in both net income and sales from continuing operations for fiscal 2003 from its earnings of $31.5 million on sales of $1.07 billion in fiscal 2002. Airgas slips on firm's conservative EPS outlook (11:24 AM ET) Airgas ARG, +2.04% is sinking more than 8 percent to $18.45 after the Radnor, Pa., gas distribution firm reported fourth-quarter earnings of $18.2 million, or 25 cents per share, in line with Wall Street's consensus estimate for the period. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of $1.05 to 1.12 per share for fiscal 2004. That range matches the low to mean estimate of 7 analysts polled by Thomson First call. The high end of estimates from First Call is for $1.16 per share. Airgas said the low end of its expectations reflect a continuation of the current business environment while the high end assumes improvement. Banc of America Securities analyst Mark Gulley reamins more optimistic though, and he raised his estimate for fiscal 2004 earnings per share to $1.15, and lifted his target price to $25, "based on improving sales and margins related to CO2." Erratic weather hurts same-store sales at Brown Shoe (11:06 AM ET) Brown Shoe Co. BWS is falling more than 11 percent to $27.90 after the St. Louis footwear firm said it's comfortable with the current Thomson First Call consensus estimate for a profit of 47 cents per share in the first quarter. The company said retail sales for its Famous Footwear stores totaled $91.9 million for April, while sales for its Naturalizer stores totaled $10.9 million in the month. Same-store sales for the month rose 4.1 percent at Famous Footwear and fell 1.3 percent at Naturalizer. Brown Shoe said same-store sales at its Famous Footwear stores were weaker than expected for the month due to erratic weather trends and the impact of the uncertain economy on consumer spending. Aceto blows past Q3 earnings estimate (10:41 AM ET) Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% is up more than 10 percent to $17.99 after the Lake Success, N.Y., pharmaceutical distribution firm reported third-quarter earnings of $2.4 million, or 24 cents per share, 6 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Sales leapt to $70.6 million in the latest three months from $61.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it gained market share in its Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients' business in the quarter, and that its Chemicals and Colorants business performed well. Looking ahead, Aceto said it expects earnings of at least 17 cents per share in the fourth quarter, and a profit of at least 88 cents per share for the full year. Orbit Intl tops in Q1; sees FY EPS ahead of view (10:23 AM ET) Orbit International ORBT, +1.97% is up more than 12 percent to $5.40 after the Hauppage, N.Y., power components firm reported first-quarter earnings of $406,000, or 17 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $267,000, or 12 cents per share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 6 percent in the latest three months to $4.3 million from $4.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Orbit forecast earnings between $1.45 million and $1.53 million, or 62 to 65 cents per share, on revenue ranging from $17.6 million to $18 million for the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 59 cents per share for the period. Reliant Res. tops NYSE losers on Q1 results, outlook (10:08 AM ET) Reliant Resources RRI, -2.04% is falling 90 cents, or 16 percent, to $4.81 and is the biggest percentage loser on the NYSE after the electricity and energy services company reported a wider than anticipated first quarter loss, and indicated that full-year results would fall short. The net loss for the quarter ending March was $56 million, or 19 cents a share, versus income of 28 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding a non-recurring item, the loss was 9 cents a share, below the average analyst forecast of 7 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. Total revenue increased 54 percent to $2.55 billion. Looking ahead, the company is projecting earnings of 50 to 70 cents a share for the year, below analyst forecasts of 81 cents. CTI Molecular posts in-line Q2; hit w/ downgrade (9:54 AM ET) CTI Molecular CTMI is losing more than 12 percent to $17.44 in early action. The drop comes after the Knoxville, Tenn., provider of positron emission tomography equipment reported second-quarter earnings of $4.5 million, or 10 cents per share, in line with Wall Street's consensus estimate. Revenue jumped 48 percent in the latest three months to $82 million from $55.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 16 to 18 cents per share in the third quarter on revenue of about $90 million, surrounding the average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 17 cents per share. CTI also reaffirmed its full-year outlook for earnings of 60 to 64 cents per share on revenue of about $355 million. But the results prompted USB Piper Jaffray to lower its rating on the shares to 'market perform' from 'outperform.' The firm cited valuation, disappointments in the company's PETNet business and a softer than expected outlook. Gaylan's Trading tumbles on Q1 warning (9:42 AM ET) Gaylan's Trading Co. GLYN is down almost 16 percent to $13.90 after the Plainfield, Ind., outdoor and athletic equipment retailer forecast a wider than expected loss for the first quarter due to a steep decline in same-store sales and higher markdowns resulting from competitive pressures. The company now sees a loss of 12 to 14 cents per share in the quarter on sales of $129.6 million. Same-store sales fell 6.3 percent in the period. Gaylan's previous outlook was for a loss of 8 to 12 cents per share in the quarter. Kohl's April same-store sales off 4.1 percent (9:22 AM ET) Kohl's KSS, +1.47% is reporting April same-store sales fell 4.1 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 5.8 percent to $718 million from $679 million in the same period a year earlier. Due to the April same-store sales performance, Kohl's forecast first-quarter earnings of 32 cents per share, 4 cents below Wall Street's current consensus profit estimate. Shares of the Menomonee Falls, Wis., department store retailer closed Wednesday at $56.50, down 1 percent. Too, Inc. warns of Q1, Q2 earns miss (9:21 AM ET) Too, Inc. TOO, -0.87% warned that fiscal first-quarter earnings would be 11 to 12 cents a share, missing the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 17 cents, due to a year-over-year net sales decline of 12 percent. Fiscal second quarter earnings are projected to be 4 to 7 cents, below analyst forecasts of 16 cents. Comparable-store sales of the quarter ending April fell 18 percent, and are expected to decline 10 to 12 percent during the quarter ending July. The company blamed its results, and its outlook and a "fashion misstep," bad weather, softening consumer confidence and increasing inventories cost per square foot. The stock closed Wednesday down 40 cents at $17.28. Clorox doubles third-quarter earnings (9:13 AM ET) Clorox CLX, +2.15% reported third-quarter net earnings of $110 million, or 50 cents per share vs. $46 million, or 20 cents per share in the year-ago period. Operating earnings were 51 cents per share, a penny ahead of the forecast of 50 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company reiterated its fourth-quarter EPS forecast of 67-70 cents per share, vs. 68 cents expected by Wall Street. Shares rose 35 cents to $46.08 on Wednesday. TJX: April sales below plan but Q1 EPS on track (9:05 AM ET) TJX Cos. TJX, +1.08% is saying April same-store sales were flat. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 6 percent to $956 million from $899 million in the same period a year earlier. The Framingham, Mass., off-price retailer said the month's sales were below expectations due to unseasonably cold weather. However, TJX added that first-quarter earnings remain within its expectations due to strong merchandise margins. 15 analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for earnings of 22 cents per share in the period, on average. The stock closed Wednesday at $18.20, down 3.1 percent. May Dept. Stores warns of Q1 earns shortfall (8:59 AM ET) May Department Stores MAY, +0.00% warned that fiscal first-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations due to weaker than anticipated sales results. Net sales for the quarter ending April fell 7.2 percent from the comparable-period a year ago to $2.87 billion, missing the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of $3.05 billion. Same-store sales for the period fell 8.8 percent. For the month of April, net sales fell 3.8 percent to $967.4 million and same-store sales fell 5.6 percent. The retailer is scheduled to report first quarter earnings on May 13, with analysts currently forecasting 20 cents a share. The stock closed Wednesday down 20 cents at $21.70. Gap sees Q1 earnings well ahead of consensus (8:48 AM ET) Gap Inc. GPS, +0.97% is saying April same-store sales soared 20 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 jumped 22 percent to $1.2 billion from $962 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the company sees first-quarter earnings of 19 to 22 cents per share on sales of $3.4 billion. 28 analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a profit of 11 cents per share in the period, on average. The stock closed Wednesday at $16.60, down 24 cents. Gymboree reaffirms Q1, FY profit outlook (8:43 AM ET) Gymboree GYMB is reporting April same-store sales leapt 11 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 14 percent to $40.9 million from $35.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The Burlingame, Calif., children's apparel retailer also reaffirmed its outlook for the first quarter and full year, and said it expects May same-store sales in the positive mid single digits. The stock closed Wednesday at $16.30, down 3.3 percent. Whole Foods tumbles on full-year sales outlook (8:34 AM ET) Shares of Whole Foods Market WMFI are tumbling $9.10, or 15 percent, to $51.50 after the organic foods supermarket retailer said late Wednesday that sales for fiscal 2003 will be "at the low end" of its previously stated expected range of 15 to 20 percent. Same-store sales are also projected to be at the low end of expectations of 6.5 percent to 8.5 percent growth. For the fiscal second quarter, earnings were 41 cents a share, up from 34 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research. Sales increased 16 percent to $725.1 million, just shy of analyst forecasts of $729.8 million. Dillard's same-store sales fall 2% (8:11 AM ET) Dillard's DDS, +0.96% said April same-store sales decreased 2 percent. Total sales were $536.5 million, down from $548.4 million. Shares fell 2 cents to $14.02 on Wednesday. Pacific Sunwear's Q1 sales rise 23%, tops expectations (8:04 AM ET) Pacific Sunwear PSUN said fiscal first-quarter sales rose 23 percent over the same period a year ago to $198.3 million, versus the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of $195.3 million. Comparable-store sales for the quarter ending April increased 13 percent. For the month of April, total sales rose 26 percent to $60.4 million and same-store sales increased 17 percent. The casual apparel retailer's stock closed Wednesday down 31 cents at $22.84. Movie Gallery beats first-quarter forecast (7:58 AM ET) Movie Gallery MOVI said first-quarter net income grew to $13.3 million, or 40 cents per share, vs. $9.9 million, or 35 cents per share last year. Revenue rose 37 percent to $168.7 million, from $123.1 million. Adjusted earnings per diluted share were 46 cents. The company beat the Wall Street forecast of 45 cents EPS and revenue of $166 million, according to a survey of analysts by Reuters Research. The Dothan, Ala. movie retailer said it expects 2003 EPS of $1.41 to $1.48 vs. the current Wall Street forecast of $1.47. Comcast narrowly beats revenue target (7:46 AM ET) Comcast CMCSK reported a first-quarter loss of $297 million or 13 cents per share, vs. a loss of $89 million or 9 cents per share in the year-ago period. Cash flow was $1.638 billion, up from $808 million as it absorbed the acquisition of AT&T Broadband. Revenue was $5.518 billion, compared to $2.667 billion last year. The Philadelphia-based cable TV giant company narrowly beat the revenue target of $5.512 billion, but slightly missed the expectation of $1.654 billion in cash flow in a survey of analysts by Reuters Research. It fell short of the forecast for a loss of 7 cents per share. The company expects to add 75,000 to 100,000 new basic cable subscribers in 2003, up from its earlier forecast of flat growth. Shares of Comcast rose 53 cents to $28.95 on Wednesday. Radio One's Q1 rev. rises 9%, but Q2 growth to slow (7:41 AM ET) Radio One ROIAK said first quarter broadcast revenue rose 9 percent over the same period a year ago to $63.4 million, matching the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research. For the second-quarter, however, revenue is expected to be up a low-single digit percentage or down a low-single digit percentage, given the uncertain economic environment. EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) for the quarter ending March rose 12 percent to $25.9 million, just above analyst forecasts of $25.2 million. Net income was $6.9 million, or 7 cents a share, versus a loss of 30 cents a share in the year-earlier period. The radio broadcaster's stock closed Wednesday up 44 cents at $17. Tommy Hilfiger to exceed Q4 earns forecasts (7:30 AM ET) Tommy Hilfiger TOM, +0.00% said it expects to report a fiscal fourth-quarter net loss of $1.26 to $1.31 a share. Excluding non-recurring items, primarily a non-cash charge for the impairment of goodwill, earnings for the quarter ending March are expected to be 26 to 31 cents a share, well above the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 17 cents. The apparel retailer said results benefited from better merchandise pricing and from favorable currency translation. The stock closed Wednesday up 17 cents at $8.62. Limited Brands Q1 sales rise 2%, matches expectations (7:23 AM ET) Limited Brands LTD, +0.52% said fiscal first-quarter net sales increased 2 percent over the comparable period a year ago to $1.84 billion, matching the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of $1.81 billion. Same-store sales for the quarter ending April declined 1 percent. For the month of April, net sales rose 5.6 percent to $580.6 million and same-store sales increased 3 percent. The stock closed Wednesday down 35 cents at $13.80. Cost Plus ups Q1 earns est. as Apr. sales rise 19% (7:10 AM ET) Cost Plus CPWM raised its fiscal first-quarter earnings estimate to 11 cents a share, which is 2 cents above the average analyst forecast compiled by Reuters Research. Total sales for the quarter ending April increased 19 percent over the same period a year ago to $159.2 million, just above the analyst expectations of $155.7 million. Comparable-store sales for the quarter ending April rose 3 percent. The casual home products retailer's stock closed Wednesday up 31 cents at $31.53. Mylan Labs' Q4 earns, rev. rise above expectations (6:57 AM ET) Mylan Laboratories MYL, +1.65% reported fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of $73.8 million, or 40 cents a share, up from 35 cents a share in the year-earlier period, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 37 cents. Revenue for the quarter ending March increased 25 percent to $353.7 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of $330 million, citing continued strength in its generic business and the successful launch of a "significant" new branded product. Looking ahead, the drugmaker confirmed its previous earnings estimate of $1.59 to $1.69 a share for fiscal 2004. The stock closed Wednesday up 3 cents at $29.27. Pier 1 revises up its Q1 earns est. (6:46 AM ET) Pier 1 Imports PIR, +2.88% revised its earnings estimate for the fiscal first quarter to 19 to 22 cents a share from 16 to 22 cents due to improving sales trends. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 19 cents, on average. For the month of April, the decorative home furnishings retailer said sales increased 5 percent over the comparable period a year ago to $120.6 million. Same-store sales declined 2.6 percent. The company traffic, conversion rates and transactions rose over March levels, boosted by the conclusion of the war with Iraq. The stock closed Wednesday up 2 cents at $19.82. Dean Foods' Q1 earns top est., sets 3 for 2 stock split (6:36 AM ET) Dean Foods DF, -0.12% reported first-quarter net income of $63.2 million, or 65 cents a share, versus a loss of 23 cents a share in the year-earlier period. On a pro forma basis, earnings were 64 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 63 cents. Net sales declined 4 percent to $2.1 billion, as lower raw material costs translated into lower selling prices. The food and beverage company reaffirmed its previous earnings outlook for 2003. Separately, the company declared a three for two stock split, payable June 9 for shareholders of record on May 23. The company also announced a business reorganization, in which marketing and selling of Dean's branded products will be down by the newly created Dean Branded Products Group, while all of its private label dairy products and dairy manufacturing assets will be managed by Dean Dairy Group. The stock closed Wednesday down 35 cents at $44.25. BMW Q1 net income slumps 19.3% (3:06 AM ET) BMW Group(DE:519000)said on Thursday that net income fell 19.3 percent to 510 million euros, on the continued high level of expenditure for its product and market campaign and the expected lower sales volume of BMW brand cars. Group revenues for the first quarter were 10.2 billion euros, 4.6 percent lower than last year. Deutsche Bourse Q1 EBIT rises 44% (3:01 AM ET) Deutsche Boerse(DE:581005)said its first-quarter EBIT rose 44 percent to 126 million euros, on a 71 percent increase in revenues to 350.5 million euros. Its Eurex unit saw revenues increase 42 percent to 104 million euros. KLM Q4 loss of 447 million euros worse than expected (2:53 AM ET) Struggling Dutch airline KLM Group KLM, +25.00% (NL:00964)said Thursday that it taken a 447 million euro loss in its fourth quarter that ended March 31, against expectations of a 303 million euro loss. KLM said it took a charge of 69 million euros for retiring its fleet of Boeing 747-300s earlier than expected. KLM also had to make a 180 million euro penalty payment to Alitalia, an expected development. Passenger traffic revenues were off 7 percent to 904 million euros, while cargo traffic fell 2 percent to 249 million euros. KLM said it does not see a short-term recovery due to current economic difficulties and the SARS virus. DoCoMo swings back to profit in FY02 with $1.8b profit (2:36 AM ET) NTT DoCoMo DCM, +0.87% said it swung back into the black in fiscal 2002 with a net profit of 212.5 billion yen ($1.8 billion). DoCoMo booked a net loss of 116.2 billion yen a year ago, when it posted massive special losses on investments in overseas telecom companies. For the current business year through next March, Japan's top mobile phone operator expects net profits to nearly triple to 618 billion yen. DoCoMo's shares fell 7,000 yen, or 2.6 percent, to close at 262,000 yen ahead of the announcement. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Friday stocks to watch Video-game maker Activision ATVI, +2.26% reported a fiscal fourth-quarter net loss, although the company met Wall Street targets. Santa Monica, Calif-based Activision's net loss was $8 million, or 13 cents a share. A year earlier, the company earned $10.9 million, or 17 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting a loss of 13 cents, on average. The company's sales were $125 million, down from $164.9 million a year earlier. Activision shares fell 50 cents to $17.57, ahead of the report. See full story. Genzyme announced Thursday that it will end separate publicly traded stocks for its three units. Under the plan, the two small units, Genzyme Biosurgery and Genzyme Molecular Oncology, will become part of the main Genzyme division, which will continue to trade under the ticker symbol "GENZ." The plan will take effect July 1. Genzyme said it expects full-year earnings for the corporation to be $1.25 to $1.35 per share. Shares of Genzyme General GENZ fell 73 cents to $38.40 in after-hours dealings. Shares of Genzyme Molecular Oncology GZMO were unchanged at $2.09 and shares of Genzyme Biosurgery GZBX were also unchanged at $2.51. Interpublic Group reported a first-quarter net loss of $8.6 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. Wall Street's consensus estimated profit of 7 cents a share. The advertising group earned $59.8 million, or 16 cents a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Interpublic IPG, +0.79% cited weak demand and higher costs for the shortfall. Shares of Interpublic, halted in after-hours trading, dropped more than 2 percent to $11.309 in the regular session. See full story. Nvidia NVDA, +4.63% said it rode increased market share and new product launches to first-quarter financial results that topped expectations. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research expected earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $409.8 million, on average. See full story. Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications said after the market closed that its first-quarter profit rose 68 percent over the year-ago period on increased ratings at its television networks. The company said it earned $12.8 million, or 5 cents a share, compared to $7.6 million, or 3 cents, in the same quarter last year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected a profit of 4 cents in the latest period. Revenue rose 22 percent to $261.7 million; respondents to First Call were looking for a figure of $258.4 million. Shares of Los Angeles-based Univision UVN, +0.00% fell $1.60 to close at $29.15 ahead of the announcement. See full story. Thursday advancers Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% rose almost 12 percent after the Lake Success, N.Y., pharmaceutical distribution firm reported third-quarter earnings of $2.4 million, or 24 cents per share, 6 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Sales leapt to $70.6 million in the latest three months from $61.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it gained market share in its Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients' business in the quarter, and that its Chemicals and Colorants business performed well. Looking ahead, Aceto said it expects earnings of at least 17 cents per share in the fourth quarter, and a profit of at least 88 cents per share for the full year. Edison Schools EDSN soared almost 58 percent after the company said its founder, Christopher Whittle, and other members of the company's management are contemplating an offer to buy all the outstanding shares of common stock they don't already own. The company said it has not yet received any offer and has no indication of what the purchase price might be if an offer is made. Gymboree GYMB leapt nearly 7 percent after the company reported April same-store sales leapt 11 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 14 percent to $40.9 million from $35.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The Burlingame, Calif., children's apparel retailer also reaffirmed its outlook for the first quarter and full year, and said it expects May same-store sales in the positive mid single digits. Men's Wearhouse MW jumped almost 11 percent after the Houston-based men's apparel firm reported U.S. same-store sales leapt 6.1 percent in April. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 6.8 percent to $109.3 million from $102.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales at Canadian locations fell 8.7 percent for the month. Orbit International ORBT, +1.97% leapt nearly 23 percent after the Hauppage, N.Y., power components firm reported first-quarter earnings of $406,000, or 17 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $267,000, or 12 cents per share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 6 percent in the latest three months to $4.3 million from $4.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Orbit forecast earnings between $1.45 million and $1.53 million, or 62 to 65 cents per share, on revenue ranging from $17.6 million to $18 million for the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 59 cents per share for the period. Ross Stores ROST, +2.39% added almost 6 percent after the company said April same-store sales fell 1 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 9 percent to $289 million from $264 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Newark, Calif., off-price retailer said strong inventory and expense controls have offset the impact of lower-than-anticipated revenue in the first quarter, and it expects a profit of 63 cents per share for the period, a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Also, despite adopting "more conservative sales assumptions," the company expects earnings of 66 to 70 cents per share for the second quarter, surrounding the average estimate of 10 analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 68 cents per share. Service Corp. International SRV, +0.58% rose more than 5 percent after the Houston-based funeral and cemetery services firm reported first-quarter earnings of $42.3 million, or 13 cents per share, a penny ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue slid to $580.1 million in the latest three months from $601.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Thursday decliners Airgas ARG, +2.04% fell more than 10 percent after the Radnor, Pa., gas distribution firm reported fourth-quarter earnings of $18.2 million, or 25 cents per share, in line with Wall Street's consensus estimate for the period. However, looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of $1.05 to 1.12 per share for fiscal 2004. Airgas explained that the low end of this range represents a continuation of the current business environment while the high end assumes improvement. Seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a profit of $1.12 per share in the period. Brown Shoe Co. BWS lost almost 14 percent after the St. Louis footwear firm said it's comfortable with the current Thomson First Call consensus estimate for a profit of 47 cents per share in the first quarter. The company said retail sales for its Famous Footwear stores totaled $91.9 million for April, while sales for its Naturalizer stores totaled $10.9 million in the month. Same-store sales for the month rose 4.1 percent at Famous Footwear and fell 1.3 percent at Naturalizer. Brown Shoe said same-store sales at its Famous Footwear stores were weaker than expected for the month due to erratic weather trends and the impact Cephalon CEPH fell nearly 9 percent after the company reported a first-quarter profit of $12.2 million, or 21 cents per share. In the 2002 first quarter, the biotech firm had a loss of $2.9 million, or 5 cents per share. The company had been expected to earn 20 cents per share, according to the average estimate of analysts polled by Reuters Research. See full story. Chico's FAS CHS, +0.33% tumbled almost 10 percent after the Fort Myers, Fla., women's clothing retailer reported April same-store sales rose 4.7 percent.
