Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 jumped 27 percent to $59.6 million from $46.9 million in the same period a year earlier. But Southwest Securities lowered its rating on the company's stock to "neutral" from "strong buy," saying the lower-than-expected same-store sales performance and the current valuation would create selling pressure. Clorox CLX, +2.15% dipped nearly 5 percent after the company reported third-quarter net earnings of $110 million, or 50 cents per share vs. $46 million, or 20 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Oakland, Calif.-based bleach maker matched the forecast of 50 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company reiterated its fourth-quarter EPS forecast of 67 to 70 cents per share, vs. 68 cents expected by Wall Street. CTI Molecular CTMI lost more than 17 percent. The drop comes after the Knoxville, Tenn., provider of positron emission tomography equipment reported second-quarter earnings of $4.5 million, or 10 cents per share, in line with Wall Street's consensus estimate. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 16 to 18 cents per share in the third quarter on revenue of about $90 million, surrounding the average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 17 cents per share. But the results prompted USB Piper Jaffray to lower its rating on the shares to 'market perform' from 'outperform.' The firm cited valuation, disappointments in the company's PETNet business and a softer than expected outlook. Factory 2-U Stores FTUS slipped almost 9 percent. After Wednesday's closing bell, the San Diego off-price retailer said April same-store sales rose 3.7 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 increased 2.1 percent to $35.2 million from $34.5 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the same-store sales increase to an improved in-store inventory position and a calendar shift of pre-Easter sales to April from March. Gaylan's Trading Co. GLYN dropped nearly 10 percent after the Plainfield, Ind., outdoor and athletic equipment retailer forecast a wider than expected loss for the first quarter due to a steep decline in same-store sales and higher markdowns resulting from competitive pressures. The company now sees a loss of 12 to 14 cents per share in the quarter on sales of $129.6 million. Same-store sales fell 6.3 percent in the period. Gaylan's previous outlook was for a loss of 8 to 12 cents per share in the quarter. Kohl's KSS, +1.47% slipped almost 6 percent after the company reported April same-store sales fell 4.1 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended May 3 rose 5.8 percent to $718 million from $679 million in the same period a year earlier. The company forecast first-quarter earnings of 32 cents per share, 4 cents below Wall Street's consensus estimate. Movie Gallery MOVI dropped more than 7 percent after the company said first-quarter net income grew to $13.3 million, or 40 cents per share, vs. $9.9 million, or 35 cents per share last year. Revenue rose 37 percent to $168.7 million, from $123.1 million. Adjusted earnings per diluted share were 46 cents. The company beat the Wall Street forecast of 45 cents EPS and revenue of $166 million, according to a survey of analysts by Reuters Research. The Dothan, Ala. movie retailer said it expects 2003 EPS of $1.41 to $1.48 vs. the current Wall Street forecast of $1.47. Nordstrom JWN, +1.06% lost nearly 9 percent after the company warned investors that profits in the fiscal first quarter will total 12 cents to 15 cents a share, well below the 19 cents a share expected by Wall Street analysts. The department-store retailer also reported its third consecutive month of same-store sales declines, with April's results down 0.3 percent. The company said preliminary sales for the four-week period that ended May 3 rose 5.2 percent to $439.7 million. Sunrise Assisted Living SRZ, +0.00% lost almost 14 percent after analyst Doug Simpson at Merrill Lynch has downgraded it to "sell" from "neutral," citing what he believes to be "very rich valuation," which appears to be based on a long-term outlook that could prove to be "very optimistic." The stock after the health-care services company reported first-quarter results. The company earned 56 cents a share, a penny above the average analyst estimate, according to Reuters. Operating revenue increased 23 percent to $136.7 million, just shy of the $139 million expected by analysts. The company also reiterated its 2003 earnings forecast of $2.57 to $2.65 a share. Tommy Hilfiger TOM, +0.00% sank nearly 9 percent after the company said it expects to report a fiscal fourth-quarter net loss of $1.26 to $1.31 a share. Excluding nonrecurring items, primarily a non-cash charge for the impairment of goodwill, earnings for the quarter ending March are expected to be 26 to 31 cents a share, well above the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 17 cents. The apparel retailer said results benefited from better merchandise pricing and from favorable currency translation. Shares of United Natural Foods UNFI, +0.59% slumped more than 12 percent after the Dayville, Conn., distributor of natural and organic foods received a downgrade from Adams Harkness on news of Whole Foods' WFMI weaker than expected outlook. The firm, which also cited the proximity of United Natural's valuation to its $31 price target, went to "buy" from "strong buy" on the shares. Wild Oats Markets OATS fell more than 10 percent in midday trades. Like Whole Foods, the Boulder, Colo., firm operates natural foods supermarkets. U.S. Industries USI, -3.27% tumbled almost 7 percent after the West Palm Beach, Fla., maker of bath and plumbing products reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $5.8 million, or 8 cents per share, a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Including an impairment charge of $39.9 million related to its asset disposal plan, the company lost $33.3 million, or 45 cents per share, in the latest quarter. The company said reduced margins in its domestic whirlpool bath product lines hurt operating income in the period. Looking ahead, U.S. Industries forecast a increase of 12 percent in both net income and sales from continuing operations for fiscal 2003 from its earnings of $31.5 million on sales of $1.07 billion in fiscal 2002. Value City Department Stores VCD lost 11 percent after the company said April same-store sales jumped 2 percent. Sales for the four weeks ended May 3 increased 6.8 percent to $205.8 million from $192.8 million in the same period a year ago. Shares of NYSE trading specialist and market maker Van der Moolen VDM fell nearly 11 percent Thursday after the company reported first-quarter net income dropped 55 percent amid a 38 percent drop in revenue. Shares of Whole Foods Market WFMI tumbled 12 percent after the organic foods supermarket retailer said late Wednesday that sales for fiscal 2003 will be "at the low end" of its previously stated expected range of 15 to 20 percent. Same-store sales are also projected to be at the low end of expectations of 6.5 percent to 8.5 percent growth. For the fiscal second quarter, earnings were 41 cents a share, up from 34 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research. Sales increased 16 percent to $725.1 million, just shy of analyst forecasts of $729.8 million. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Edison Schools, Sunrise Assisted Living and more

content: Aceto Corp. ACET, +3.97% is up more than 10 percent to $17.99 after the Lake Success, N.Y., pharmaceutical distribution firm reported third-quarter earnings of $2.4 million, or 24 cents per share, 6 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Sales leapt to $70.6 million in the latest three months from $61.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it gained market share in its Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients' business in the quarter, and that its Chemicals and Colorants business performed well. Looking ahead, Aceto said it expects earnings of at least 17 cents per share in the fourth quarter, and a profit of at least 88 cents per share for the full year.
title: Aceto blows past Q3 earnings estimate

content: Stocks to watch Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% announced a committee of board members Friday afternoon who will oversee its compliance with last week's antitrust ruling. In that ruling, a federal judge ordered a series of remedies, starting with the creation of this compliance committee. Harvard Prof. James Cash will lead it. Microsoft shares fell 91 cents to $55.10 on Friday. World Wrestling Entertainment WWE, -0.30% said the head of its New York City entertainment complex The World was arrested Friday following an internal audit of suspicious financial transactions. WWE said Kenton Jenkins, former general manager of The World, was arrested by the Manhattan District Attorney's office after the company turned over evidence collected by accountants KPMG Forensic. The company said the incident would not have a material impact on its results. The company declined to discuss what Jenkins was charged with, and the Manhattan DA's office was not immediately available for comment. WWE shares closed down a nickel Friday, at $8.31. Advancers Aceto ACET, +3.97% rose almost 22 percent after the Lake Success, N.Y., distributor of pharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals reported first-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 35 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $535,000, or 8 cents a share. Sales jumped 43 percent to $68 million in the latest three months compared to $47.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Aeroflex ARXX gained nearly 9 percent after the Plainview, N.Y., microelectronics firm reported first-quarter earnings of $632,000, or a penny per share, up from its year-ago loss of $672,000, or a penny per share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales jumped to $66.5 million in the latest three months, from $39.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Aeroflex sees earnings of 3 cents a share and a sequential sales increase of more than 5 percent for the second quarter. Wall Street's consensus estimate is for a profit of 3 cents a share on revenue of $72 million in the December quarter. It also sees substantial improvement in its operating results in the second half. Applied Digital Solutions ADSX surged 25 percent after the Palm Beach, Fla., technology development firm said that it would move the listing of its securities to the Nasdaq SmallCap Market starting Nov. 12. The company said the move would give it until July 2003 to get its share price above $1 for more than ten consecutive trading days in order to maintain the listing. The shares previously listed on the Nasdaq National Market. Brass Eagle XTRM, -13.33% jumped almost 16 percent. The Bentonville, Ark., maker of paintball products reported third-quarter earnings of $1.5 million, or 21 cents a share, up from its year-ago loss of $418,000, or 6 cents a share. Sales leapt 40.4 percent to $21.9 million in the latest three months from $21.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Brass Eagle cited an improving retail environment for the strong results. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of $1.10 to $1.20 per share on sales of $105 million to $110 million for the full year. Earlier in the session, the shares hit a 52-week high of $8.31. Factory 2-U Stores FTUS soared almost 165 percent after the company late Thursday named William Fields, a former chief executive of Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37% as its new chairman and CEO. Fields replaces Mike Searles. Fields held Wal-Mart's top spot from 1993 to 1996. Most recently, he was CEO of Apec China Asset Management, Hudson's Bay and Blockbuster Entertainment. Granite State Bankshares GSBI rose more than 19 percent after the company agreed to acquired by Chittenden CHZ, +0.00% for $247 million, or $46 a share. That represents a 25 percent premium over Thursday's closing price of $36.88. As part of the agreement, Granite State shareholders can choose to receive $46 a share in cash or 1.64 shares of Chittenden stock for each Granite share they own, which equates to $44.03 as of Thursday's closing price ($26.85). The deal is expected to close in the second quarter of 2003. Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% tacked on almost 6 percent after the company said it expects a slight decline in sales this year and expects earnings per share of 2.55 to $2.57 for the year. Lilly said it remains cautious about 2003, and would offer more specific 2003 guidance when new product launch timelines and resolution of manufacturing issues with the FDA become more certain. Party City PCTY, +1.13% rose more than 5 percent after the Rockaway, N.J., party goods retailer reported a first-quarter loss of $1.7 million, or 11 cents a share, slightly better than its year-ago loss of $1.8 million, or 14 cents a share, and 2 cents narrower than the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales at company-owned stores jumped 12.8 percent to $91.1 million in the three months ended Sept. 28 from $80.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 3.4 percent in the quarter. Party City also reported a 6.6 percent increase in chain-wide sales to $212 million for the five-week Halloween selling season ended Nov. 2. Research In Motion RIMM surged almost 27 percent after the company licensed its BlackBerry wireless messaging software to Nokia NOK, +0.74% Financial terms weren't disclosed. The deal gives Nokia the right to use and distribute certain BlackBerry software applications in conjunction with Nokia products on a global basis. Univision Communications UVN, +0.00% climbed more than 6 percent after the Spanish language media firm said that its third-quarter profit more than doubled from prior-year results, surpassing most estimates. Net income was $20.3 million, or 8 cents a share, compared with $6.9 million, or 3 cents a share, in last year's third quarter. See full story. Decliners American Tower AMT, +0.72% fell almost 10 percent after the company reporting a third-quarter loss from continuing operations of $353.9 million, or $1.81 per share, almost three times as wide as its year-ago loss of $122.9 million, or 64 cents a share. The company recorded a charge of about $271 million related to asset impairment in the latest quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a loss of 37 cents a share in the period, on average. Revenue fell to $266.6 million in the latest three months from $273.7 million in the same period a year earlier. The Boston-based firm said that cash flow rose 33 percent to $86.8 million in the third quarter from $65.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Benihana [ BNHN slid more than 14 percent after the Miami-based operator of Asian restaurants reported second-quarter earnings of $1.5 million, or 16 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $500,000, or 5 cents a share, but well below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 23 cents a share. Revenue rose to $42 million in the latest three months from $37.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-location sales rose 7.5 percent in the period. Benihana said the economy "has clearly slowed things down somewhat." C-Cor.net CCBL fell almost 18 percent after the State College, Pa., provider of fiber optic communications services forecast a pro forma loss of 16 to 20 cents a share for the second quarter, wider than the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of 10 cents a share. Sales for the quarter are projected at between $49 million and $53 million. C.Cor.net also said it continues to restructure as part of the integration of recently acquired Philips Broadband and its reaction to the current business environment, and that it plans to eliminate between $16 million to $20 million in annual costs. The company expects to eliminate between 300 to 350 jobs. Daisytek DZTK sank nearly 19 percent after the Allen, Texas, computer and office products distributor reported a second-quarter loss of $27.3 million, or $1.49 per share, a drop from its year-ago profit from continuing operations of $3.2 million, or 19 cents a share. The latest results include a goodwill impairment charge of $13.8 million related to its tape and Argentina businesses, and incremental balance sheet reserves of $14.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 11 cents a share in the period, on average. Revenue surged 62 percent to $452.9 million in the latest three months from $278.8 million in the same period a year earlier. El Paso EP, +0.00% lost almost 17 percent after the company reported third-quarter results that fell well short of Wall Street forecasts due to weak trading and refining results, and announced plans to exit the energy trading business. The net loss for the quarter ending September was $69 million, or 12 cents a share, versus a profit of $211 million, or 41 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, the loss for the period was 2 cents a share, versus the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 27 cents a share. Operating revenue fell 16 percent to $2.66 billion. The provider of natural gas services said higher capital costs have prompted its exit of the energy trading business. H&R Block HRB, +1.03% sank more than 9 percent after Salomon Smith Barney lowered its rating on shares of the tax preparation services firm to "underperform" from "outperform" after the company received an unfavorable court decision in Texas. The decision concerned H&R Block's conduct with regard to offering instant income tax refunds, including its failure to disclose to customers its business relationship with lender Household International HI, +1.32% H&R Block has said it plans to appeal the ruling. Salomon said the ruling creates "substantial litigation uncertainties," that are unlikely to be resolved quickly or cheaply. Infineon IFX, -8.16% shares fell almost 8 percent after the company's wider-than-expected fourth quarter loss disappointed and its bleak outlook for near-term sales raised the alarm. See full story. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% dropped nearly 8 percent after the company said that it will not achieve its previously announced earnings target for 2002 due to weaker than anticipated October sales and the adverse impact of a number of non-cash restructuring charges that will reduce its pre-tax income by between $350 million and $425 million in the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 35 cents a share in the fourth quarter, and $1.43 per share for the full year, on average. The Dow component didn't provide revised estimates. McDonald's said system-wide sales rose 3 percent to $3.5 billion in October, and 2 percent to $34.5 billion for the first 10 months of the year. As part of its business optimization plans, the Oak Brook, Ill., fast food restaurant operator is restructuring operations in four countries, pulling out of three other countries, and closing roughly 175 under-performing stores in about ten other countries. It will also eliminate between 400 and 600 jobs. Nvidia NVDA, +4.63% slumped almost 22 percent after the company reported a third-quarter loss of $48.6 million, or 32 cents a share, on revenue of $430.3 million. The loss included a charge of $61.8 million. The chipmaker's sales were inline with what Wall Street expected. See full story. Safeway SWY, +1.82% lost almost 12 percent after the Pleasanton, Calif., supermarket operator lowered earnings expectations for the fourth quarter and full year due to sluggish sales resulting from a soft economy. The company sees earnings of 78 to 80 cents per share in the quarter, and $2.77 to $2.79 per share for the full year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for profits of 82 cents a share in the quarter, and $2.81 per share in the year, on average. For 2003, it sees earnings of $2.50 to $2.65 per share, below the current Wall Street consensus estimate for a profit of $2.92 per share. Safeway also pegged capital spending for 2003 at $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion Sonic Solutions SNIC fell more than 25 percent. After Thursday's closing bell, the Novato, Calif., DVD technology firm posted second-quarter operating earnings of $726,000, or 4 cents a share, compared with its year-ago loss of $1.8 million, or 13 cents a share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped $7.5 million in the latest three months from $4 million in the same period a year earlier. However, W.R. Hambrecht lowered its rating on the stock to "buy" from "buy - analyst select list," citing a projected shortfall in shipments of recordable DVD drives. "We remain very bullish on Sonic Solutions' shares over the long term," the firm said. "However, yesterday's muted holiday outlook cuts the legs out from under the 'strong Christmas' catalyst, and we think Sonic shares will lack a significant upward driver until the supply chain issue is resolved." Syncor SCOR, -1.07% slumped 19 percent. The stock, which plumbed a 52-week low of $17.35 earlier in the session, has now dropped almost 50 percent from Tuesday's closing price of $35.92. Before Wednesday's opening bell, the company disclosed an investigation of the propriety of certain payments involving its overseas units. The payments were discovered by merger partner Cardinal Health as that company did due diligence related to the planned merger. Completion of the merger been cast into doubt by the revelation Teco Energy TE, +0.00% fell more than 22 percent after Merrill Lynch lowered its rating on shares of the Tampa, Fla., utility firm to "sell" from "neutral," citing credit concerns. The firm explained that Teco management confirmed late Thursday that the company has largely drawn down a $350 million credit line at one of its units to cover the pending maturity of $236 million in debt. Merrill sees "reasonably high risk" that Teco will be unable to renew the facility. "Our main concern is that with limited access to capital markets and bank renewals, TE's credit ratings could come under pressure," the firm told clients in a research note Tenet THC, +1.76% plunged almost 117 percent after the company unveiled a revamped management team in the wake of questions about the hospital chain's Medicare reimbursements. Tenet also reaffirmed its earnings per share estimate for fiscal 2003 -- analysts are expecting $2.97 a share -- and earnings from operations to increase by 25 percent over fiscal 2002's $2.34. Over the long term, however, Tenet said it's reassessing its prior outlook due to new information CEO Jeff Barbakow received about the company's pricing strategies. The news weighed on shares of peers such as HCA Inc. HCA, -0.15% Community Health CYH, -3.65% and Lifepoint Hospitals LPNT, -1.67% Tier Technologies TIER, -1.81% lost 18 percent after the Walnut Creek, Calif., information technology consulting services firm reported fourth-quarter pro forma earnings from continuing operations of $3.8 million, or 20 cents a share, a penny short of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue from continuing operations jumped 39 percent to $32.4 million in the latest three months from $23.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Trenwick Group Ltd. TWK dropped more than 43 percent after the Bermuda-based specialty insurance firm posted a net loss of $137.2 million, or $3.73 per share for the third quarter, wider than its year-ago loss of $96.1 million, or $2.61 per share. The results in the latest quarter reflect an increase of $90.7 million in loss reserves recorded for its U.S. operating units and Trenwick International Ltd, and a $54.5 million loss from the establishment of a deferred tax valuation reserve in connection with the U.S. operations. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 19 cents a share in the September quarter. The company also announced the halt of dividend payments on its common shares. Triad Hospitals TRI, +0.31% slid almost 17 percent after Prudential downgraded the stock to "hold" from "buy" citing valuation. The firm maintained its earnings estimates on Triad, but lowered its price target to $37 from $55 due to concerns about near-term industry growth. Vesta Insurance VTA, +0.86% lost more than 14 percent after the Birmingham, Ala., financial and insurance businesses holding company said it expects to record a $15.3 million charge in the third quarter to reflect a negative ruling by an arbitration panel in its dispute with NRMA Insurance Ltd. Vesta said the ruling wouldn't impact its cash position and that it plans to continue to pursue its claims in this and other arbitrations. title: Microsoft, El Paso, McDonald's, and more

content: Q2 loss, outlook hurts Daisytek shares (2:07 PM ET) Daisytek DZTK is off $1.26, or 15.4 percent, to $6.92, after the Allen, Texas, computer and office products distributor reported a second-quarter loss of $27.3 million, or $1.49 per share, a drop from its year-ago profit from continuing operations of $3.2 million, or 19 cents a share. The latest results include a goodwill impairment charge of $13.8 million related to its tape and Argentina businesses, and incremental balance sheet reserves of $14.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 11 cents a share in the period, on average. Revenue surged 62 percent to $452.9 million in the latest three months from $278.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Daisytek also warned that it expects run-rate issues, including Tape and Argentina performance and the costs and factors related to U.S. expansion into office products, that hurt its results in the second quarter to persist into the third quarter and to a lesser extent into the fourth quarter. Brass Eagle shares hit 52-week high (1:40 PM ET) Brass Eagle XTRM, -13.33% is up 91 cents, or 12.6 percent, to $8.11, in midday dealings. The Bentonville, Ark., maker of paintball products reported third-quarter earnings of $1.5 million, or 21 cents a share, up from its year-ago loss of $418,000, or 6 cents a share. Sales leapt 40.4 percent to $21.9 million in the latest three months from $21.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Brass Eagle cited an improving retail environment for the strong results. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of $1.10 to $1.20 per share on sales of $105 million to $110 million for the full year. Earlier in the session, the shares hit a 52-week high of $8.31. Aceto gets boost from Q1 profit of $2.3M (1:24 PM ET) Aceto ACET, +3.97% is up $1.95, or 19.4 percent, to $12, after the Lake Success, N.Y., distributor of pharmaceuticals and specialty chemicals reported first-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 35 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $535,000, or 8 cents a share. Sales jumped 43 percent to $68 million in the latest three months to $47.6 million in the same period a year earlier. C-Cor.net warns on Q2; continues restructuring (1:11 PM ET) C-Cor.net CCBL is losing 63 cents, or 17.4 percent, to $3.00, after State College, Pa., provider of fiber optic communications services forecast a pro forma loss of 16 to 20 cents a share for the second quarter, wider than the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of 10 cents a share. Sales for the quarter are projected to come in between $49 million and $53 million. C.Cor.net also said that it continues to restructure as part of the integration of recently acquired Philips Broadband and its reaction to the current business environment, and that it plans to eliminate between $16 million to $20 million in annual costs. The company expects to eliminate between 300 to 350 jobs. Benihana tumbles in wake of Q2 results (12:39 PM ET) Benihana BNHN is down $2.47, or 16.8 percent, to $12.25, after the Miami-based operator of Asian restaurants reported second-quarter earnings of $1.5 million, or 16 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $500,000, or 5 cents a share, but well below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 23 cents a share. Revenue rose to $42 million in the latest three months from $37.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-location sales rose 7.5 percent in the period. Benihana said that the general economy "has clearly slowed things down somewhat" in discussing the results. Vesta Insurance to record $15.3M charge in Q3 (11:51 AM ET) Vesta Insurance VTA, +0.86% is losing 47 cents, or 14.7 percent, to $2.67, after the Birmingham, Ala., financial and insurance businesses holding company said it expects to record a $15.3 million charge in the third quarter to reflect its negative ruling by an arbitration panel in its dispute with NRMA Insurance Ltd. The panel ruled that the whole account quota share contract effective July 1, 1997, between Vesta Fire Insurance Corp. and NRMA Insurance Ltd. does not apply to loss occurrences prior to July 1, 1997. Vesta said the ruling will not impact its cash position and that it plans to continue to pursue its claims in this and other arbitrations. Trenwick loses $137.2M in Q3; halts common stock divs (11:00 AM ET) Trenwick Group Ltd. TWK is losing $1.01, or 35.9 percent, to $1.80, after the Bermuda-based specialty insurance firm posted a net loss of $137.2 million, or $3.73 per share for the third quarter, wider than its year-ago loss of $96.1 million, or $2.61 per share. The results in the latest quarter reflect an increase of $90.7 million in loss reserves recorded for its U.S. operating units and Trenwick International Ltd, and a $54.5 million loss from the establishment of a deferred tax valuation reserve in connection with the U.S. operations. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 19 cents a share in the September quarter. The company also announced the halt of dividend payments on its common shares. Safeway tumbles on lower view for Q4, FY02, FY03 (10:47 AM ET) Safeway SWY, +1.82% is down $1.60, or 7.1 percent, to $21, after the Pleasanton, Calif., supermarket operator lowered earnings expectations for the fourth quarter and full year due to sluggish sales resulting from a soft economy. The company sees earnings of 78 to 80 cents per share in the quarter, and $2.77 to $2.79 per share for the full year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for profits of 82 cents a share in the quarter, and $2.81 per share in the year, on average. For 2003, it sees earnings of $2.50 to $2.65 per share, below the current Wall Street consensus estimate for a profit of $2.92 per share. Safeway also pegged capital spending for 2003 at $1.3 billion to $1.5 billion. Aeroflex surges on in-line Q1, strong Q2 outlook (10:31 AM ET) Aeroflex ARXX is up 82 cents, or 13 percent, to $7.14, after the Plainview, N.Y., microelectronics firm reported first-quarter earnings of $632,000, or a penny per share, up from its year-ago loss of $672,000, or a penny per share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales jumped to $66.5 million in the latest three months from $39.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, however. Aeroflex sees earnings of 3 cents a share and a sequential sales increase of more than 5 percent for the second quarter. Wall Street's consensus estimate is for a profit of 3 cents a share on revenue of $72 million in the December quarter. It also sees substantial improvement in its operating results in the second half. Tier Tech comes in a penny short in Q4 (10:16 AM ET) Tier Technologies TIER, -1.81% is losing $3.60, or 19.9 percent, to $35.82, after the Walnut Creek, Calif., information technology consulting services firm reported fourth-quarter pro forma earnings from continuing operations of $3.8 million, or 20 cents a share, a penny short of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue from continuing operations jumped 39 percent to $32.4 million in the latest three months from $23.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Party City beats Wall St. loss view for Q1 (9:54 AM ET) Party City PCTY, +1.13% is tacking on 32 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $12.77, after the Rockaway, N.J., party goods retailer reported a first-quarter loss of $1.7 million, or 11 cents a share, slightly better than its year-ago loss of $1.8 million, or 14 cents a share, and 2 cents narrower than the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales at company-owned stores jumped 12.8 percent to $91.1 million in the three months ended Sept. 28 from $80.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales rose 3.4 percent in the quarter. Party City also reported a 6.6 percent increase in chain-wide sales to $212 million for the five-week Halloween selling season ended Nov. 2. Sonic Solutions' holiday outlook prompts downgrade (9:49 AM ET) Sonic Solutions SNIC is down $1.89, or 20.8 percent, to $7.16, in early action. After Thursday's closing bell, the Novato, Calif., DVD technology firm posted second-quarter operating earnings of $726,000, or 4 cents a share, up from its year-ago loss of $1.8 million, or 13 cents a share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped $7.5 million in the latest three months from $4 million in the same period a year earlier. However, W.R. Hambrecht lowered its rating on the stock to "buy" from "buy - analyst select list," citing a projected shortfall in shipments of recordable DVD drives for the remainder of the year due to shortages in laser pick-up heads. "We remain very bullish on Sonic Solutions' shares over the long term," the firm said. "However, yesterday's muted holiday outlook cuts the legs out from under the 'strong Christmas' catalyst, and we think Sonic shares will lack a significant upward driver until the supply chain issue is resolved." 7-Eleven Oct. U.S. same-store merchandise sales up 3.9% (9:12 AM ET) 7-Eleven SE, +3.11% is saying U.S. same-store merchandise sales rose 3.9 percent in October. Total merchandise sales for the month jumped 5 percent to $614.1 million from $584.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Gasoline sales leapt 19.3 percent in October to $262.4 million from $219.9 million in the year-ago period. The stock closed Thursday at $8.15, down 1.8 percent. McDonald's to fall short of 2002 earnings target (8:57 AM ET) McDonald's MCD, -1.28% is saying that it will not achieve its previously announced earnings target for 2002 due to weaker than anticipated October sales and the adverse impact of a number of non-cash restructuring charges that will reduce its pre-tax income by between $350 million and $425 million in the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 35 cents a share in the fourth quarter, and $1.43 per share for the full year, on average. In its press release announcing third-quarter results on Oct. 22, the company set a target for a profit of $1.43 per share or better for the year. The Dow component didn't provide revised estimates. McDonald's said system-wide sales rose 3 percent to $3.5 billion in October, and 2 percent to $34.5 billion for the first 10 months of the year. As part of its business optimization plans, the Oak Brook, Ill., fast food restaurant operator is restructuring operations in four countries, pulling out of three other countries, and closing roughly 175 underperforming stores in about ten other countries. It will also eliminate between 400 and 600 jobs. The stock closed Thursday at $19.31, up 1.3 percent. Longs Drug October same-store sales up 1.6 percent (8:43 AM ET) Longs Drug Stores LDG, -22.86% is reporting October same-store sales rose 1.6 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended Oct. 31 rose 3.7 percent to $325.2 million from $313.6 million in the same period a year earlier. For the third quarter, same-store sales rose 5.4 percent, and total sales jumped 4.6 percent to $1.06 billion. The stock closed Thursday at $22, down 0.6 percent. American Tower posts Q3 loss of $353.9M (8:32 AM ET) American Tower AMT, +0.72% is reporting a third-quarter loss from continuing operations of $353.9 million, or $1.81 per share, almost three times as wide as its year-ago loss of $122.9 million, or 64 cents a share. The company recorded a charge of about $271 million related to asset impairment in the latest quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a loss of 37 cents a share in the period, on average. Revenue fell to $266.6 million in the latest three months from $273.7 million in the same period a year earlier. The Boston-based firm said that tower cash flow rose 33 percent to $86.8 million in the third quarter from $65.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The shares closed Thursday unchanged at $1.67. Granite Broadcasting third-quarter net loss narrows (8:25 AM ET) Granite Broadcasting GBTVK reported a third-quarter net loss of $2.65 million, or 39 cents per share, vs. $16.88 million, or $1.34 per share in the year-ago period. Two analysts surved by Thomson First Call forecasted losses of 60 cents per share and 68 cents per share respectively. Revenue rose to $26.1 million, from $25.5 million. Broadcast cash flow jumped to $4.5 million, from $1.3 million. The TV station operator said it plans to post fourth-quarter same-station net revenue in the range of $32.1 million to $32.9 million and broadcast cash flow in the range of $7.9 million to $9.2 million. Shares of Granite Broadcasting rose 27 cents to $2.27 on Thursday. Barbeques Galore Q3 sales rise 2.7 percent to $43.1M (8:20 AM ET) Barbeques Galore BBQZ is reporting third-quarter sales rose 2.7 percent to $43.1 million from $42 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales at the Irvine, Calif., barbeque supplies seller's U.S. locations fell 2.1 percent in the quarter, while its restaurants in Australia saw an increase of 7.5 percent in the period. The company plans to release its full financial results for the quarter in early December. The stock closed Thursday at $3, down 2.2 percent. Armstrong sales rise (8:06 AM ET) Armstrong Holdings ACK, -5.50% reported third-quarter net income of $29.4 million, or 72 cents per share, compared with $14.3 million, or 35 cents per share, in the year-ago period. Net sales climbed to $846 million from $804.9 million. Operating income was $52.4 million, up from $32.9 million. Shares rose 5 cents to $1.78 in pre-opening-bell trades. Eli Lilly affirms 2002, remains 'cautious' on 2003 (7:55 AM ET) Drugmaker Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% on Friday affirmed its expectation for a slight decline in sales this year and that it expects earnings per share of 2.55 to $2.57 for the year. Lilly said it remains cautious on 2003 and said it would offer more specific 2003 guidance when new product launch timelines and resolution of manufacturing issues with the FDA become more certain. On the manufacturing issue, Lilly said it believes it is "are making progress" with the FDA. Lilly detailed submission plans and approval expectations for a large number of products in a statement early Friday ahead of meetings with investors/analysts. El Paso misses Q3 forecast, exits energy trading ops (7:29 AM ET) El Paso Corp. EP, +0.00% reported third-quarter results that fell well short of Wall Street forecasts due to weak trading and refining results, and announced plans to exit the energy trading business. The net loss for the quarter ending September was $69 million, or 12 cents a share, versus a profit of $211 million, or 41 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, the loss for the period was 2 cents a share, versus the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 27 cents a share. Operating revenue fell 16 percent to $2.66 billion. The provider of natural gas services said higher capital costs have prompted its exit of the energy trading business. The stock closed Thursday down 30 cents at $9.20. Sales jumped 43 percent to $68 million in the latest three months to $47.6 million in the same period a year earlier.

content: (EDGAR Online via COMTEX) -- Item 2. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations CAUTIONARY STATEMENT RELATING TO THE SAFE HARBOR PROVISIONS OF THE PRIVATE SECURITIES LITIGATION REFORM ACT OF 1995 This Quarterly Report contains forward-looking statements as that term is defined in the federal securities laws. The events described in forward-looking statements contained in this Quarterly Report may not occur. Generally, these statements relate to our business plans or strategies, projected or anticipated benefits or other consequences of our plans or strategies, financing plans, projected or anticipated benefits from acquisitions that we may make, or projections involving anticipated revenues, earnings or other aspects of our operating results or financial position, and the outcome of any contingencies. Any such forward-looking statements are based on current expectations, estimates and projections of management. We intend for these forward-looking statements to be covered by the safe-harbor provisions for forward-looking statements. Words such as "may," "will," "expect," "believe," "anticipate," "project," "plan," "intend," "estimate," and "continue," and their opposites and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. We caution you that these statements are not guarantees of future performance or events and are subject to a number of uncertainties, risks and other influences, many of which are beyond our control that may influence the accuracy of the statements and the projections upon which the statements are based. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those set forth or implied by any forward-looking statement include, but are not limited to, our ability to remain competitive with competitors, risks associated with the generic product industry, dependence on a limited number of suppliers, risks associated with healthcare reform and reductions in reimbursement rates, difficulty in predicting revenue stream and gross profit, industry and market changes, the effect of fluctuations in operating results on the trading price of our common stock, risks associated with holding a significant amount of debt, inventory levels, reliance on outside manufacturers, risks of incurring uninsured environmental and other industry specific liabilities, governmental approvals and regulations, risks associated with hazardous materials, potential violations of government regulations, product liability claims, reliance on Chinese suppliers, potential changes to Chinese laws and regulations, potential changes to laws governing our relationships in India, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, tax assessments, changes in tax rules, global economic risks, risk of unsuccessful acquisitions, effect of acquisitions on earnings, indemnification liabilities, terrorist activities, reliance on key executives, litigation risks, volatility of the market price of our common stock, changes to estimates, judgments and assumptions used in preparing financial statements, failure to maintain effective internal controls, and compliance with changing regulations, as well as other risks and uncertainties discussed in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including, but not limited to the Company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended June 30, 2017, as amended (the "2017 10-K") and other filings. Copies of these filings are available at www.sec.gov. Any one or more of these uncertainties, risks and other influences could materially affect our results of operations and whether forward-looking statements made by us ultimately prove to be accurate. Our actual results, performance and achievements could differ materially from those expressed or implied in these forward-looking statements. We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether from new information, future events or otherwise. NOTE REGARDING DOLLAR AMOUNTS In this quarterly report, all dollar amounts are expressed in thousands, except for per-share amounts. The following Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) is intended to provide the readers of our financial statements with a narrative discussion about our business. The MD&A is provided as a supplement to and should be read in conjunction with our financial statements and the accompanying notes. Executive Summary We are reporting net sales of $356,484 for the six months ended December 31, 2017, which represents a 40.6% increase from the $253,570 reported in the comparable prior period. Gross profit for the six months ended December 31, 2017 was $73,953 and our gross margin was 20.7% as compared to gross profit of $61,644 and gross margin of 24.3% in the comparable prior period. Our selling, general and administrative costs ("SG&A") for the six months ended December 31, 2017 was $59,212, an increase of $10,117 from what we reported in the prior period. We had a net (loss) of $(13,410), or $(0.38) per diluted share, compared to net income of $3,821, or $0.13 per diluted share, in the prior period. As more fully described in the notes to our condensed consolidated financial statements, on December 22, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017 ("TCJA") was signed by the U.S. President. The TCJA significantly changes the income tax environment for U.S. multinational corporations and as such, the Company recorded additional income tax expense of $13,909 in the second quarter of fiscal year 2018. Our financial position as of December 31, 2017 remains strong, as we had cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments of $67,984, working capital of $238,776 and shareholders' equity of $397,023. Our business is separated into three principal segments: Human Health, Pharmaceutical Ingredients and Performance Chemicals. Products that fall within the Human Health segment include finished dosage form generic drugs and nutraceutical products. Aceto sells generic prescription products and over-the-counter pharmaceutical products to leading wholesalers, chain drug stores, distributors and mass merchandisers. On December 21, 2016, Rising completed the acquisition of certain generic products and related assets of entities formerly known as Citron Pharma LLC ("Citron") and its affiliate Lucid Pharma LLC ("Lucid"). Rising formed two subsidiaries to consummate the product acquisition - Rising Health, LLC (which acquired certain products and related assets of Citron) and Acetris Health, LLC (which acquired certain products and related assets of Lucid). Citron was a privately-held New Jersey-based pharmaceutical company focused on developing and marketing generic pharmaceutical products in partnership with leading generic pharmaceutical manufacturers based in India and the U.S. Lucid was a privately-held New Jersey-based generic pharmaceutical distributor specializing in providing cost-effective products to various agencies of the U.S. Federal Government including the Veterans Administration and the Defense Logistics Agency. Lucid serviced 18 national contracts with the Federal Government, nearly all of which have 5-year terms. The assets acquired in this transaction expand, complement, and strengthen our existing and future product offerings. In what has become a competitive generic drug business environment, one key for long-term success is having an ever-growing commercial portfolio of generic products, a strong internal drug development pipeline and capable, reliable manufacturing partners. This transaction adds significantly to the Rising business platform in all three crucial areas. We believe that, consistent with our strategy of expanding our portfolio of finished dosage form generic products through product development partnerships and acquisitions of late stage assets, abbreviated new drug applications ("ANDAs") and complementary generic drug businesses, this product acquisition significantly expanded our roster of commercialized products and pipeline of products under development. In addition, we believe that this transaction greatly enhanced our size and stature within the generic pharmaceutical industry, expanded our partnership network and offers us opportunities to realize meaningful cost and tax efficiencies, as well as representing an integral component of Aceto's continued strategy to become a Human Health oriented company. According to a QuintilesIMS press release on May 5, 2017, growth in U.S. spending on prescription medicines fell in 2016 as competition intensified among manufacturers, and payers ramped up efforts to limit price increases. According to the QuintilesIMS Institute study, "Drug spending grew at a 4.8 percent pace in 2016 to $323 billion, less than half the rate of the previous two years, after adjusting for off-invoice discounts and rebates. The surge of innovative medicine introductions paused in 2016, with fewer than half as many new drugs launched than in 2014 and 2015. While the total use of medicines continued to climb-with total prescriptions dispensed reaching 6.1 billion, up 3.3 percent over 2015 levels-the spike in new patients being treated for hepatitis C ebbed, which contributed to the decline in spend. Net price increases-reflecting rebates and other price breaks from manufacturers-averaged 3.5 percent last year, up from 2.5 percent in 2015." Aceto supplies the raw materials used in the production of nutritional and packaged dietary supplements, including vitamins, amino acids, iron compounds and biochemicals used in pharmaceutical and nutritional preparations. The Pharmaceutical Ingredients segment has two product groups: Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) and Pharmaceutical Intermediates. We supply APIs to many of the major generic drug companies, who we believe view Aceto as a valued partner in their effort to develop and market generic drugs. The process of introducing a new API from pipeline to market spans a number of years and begins with Aceto partnering with a generic pharmaceutical manufacturer and jointly selecting an API, several years before the expiration of a composition of matter patent, for future genericizing. We then identify the appropriate supplier, and concurrently utilizing our global technical network, work to ensure they meet standards of quality to comply with regulations. Our client, the generic pharmaceutical company, will submit the ANDA for U.S. Food and Drug Administration ("FDA") approval or European-equivalent approval. The introduction of the API to market occurs after all the development testing has been completed and the ANDA or European-equivalent is approved and the patent expires or is deemed invalid. Aceto, at all times, has a pipeline of APIs at various stages of development both in the United States and Europe. Aceto has long been a supplier of pharmaceutical intermediates, the complex chemical compounds that are the building blocks used in producing APIs. These are the critical components of all drugs, whether they are already on the market or currently undergoing clinical trials. Faced with significant economic pressures as well as ever-increasing regulatory barriers, the innovative drug companies look to Aceto as a source for high quality intermediates. Aceto employs, on occasion, the same second source strategy for our pharmaceutical intermediates business that we use in our API business. Historically, pharmaceutical manufacturers have had one source for the intermediates needed to produce their products. Utilizing our global sourcing, regulatory support and quality assurance network, Aceto works with the large, global pharmaceutical companies, sourcing lower cost, quality pharmaceutical intermediates that will meet the same high level standards that their current commercial products adhere to. The Performance Chemicals segment includes specialty chemicals and agricultural protection products. Aceto is a major supplier to many different industrial segments providing chemicals used in the manufacture of plastics, surface coatings, cosmetics and personal care, textiles, fuels and lubricants. The paint and coatings industry produces products that bring color, texture, and protection to houses, furniture, packaging, paper, and durable goods. Many of today's coatings are eco-friendly, by allowing inks and coatings to be cured by ultraviolet light instead of solvents, or allowing power coatings to be cured without solvents. These growing technologies are critical in protecting and enhancing the world's ecology and Aceto is focused on supplying the specialty additives that make modern coating techniques possible. The chemistry that makes much of the modern world possible is often done by building up simple molecules to sophisticated compounds in step-by-step chemical processes. The products that are incorporated in each step are known as intermediates and they can be as varied as the end uses they serve, such as crop protection products, dyes and pigments, textiles, fuel additives, electronics - essentially all things chemical. Aceto provides various specialty chemicals for the food, flavor, fragrance, paper and film industries. Aceto's raw materials are also used in sophisticated technology products, such as high-end electronic parts used for photo tooling, circuit boards, production of computer chips, and in the production of many of today's modern gadgets. According to a January 17, 2018 Federal Reserve Statistical Release, in the fourth quarter of calendar year 2017, the index for consumer durables, which impacts the Specialty Chemicals business of the Performance Chemicals segment, is expected to increase at an annual rate of 8.5%. Aceto's agricultural protection products include herbicides, fungicides and insecticides, which control weed growth as well as the spread of insects and microorganisms that can severely damage plant growth. One of Aceto's most widely used agricultural protection products is a sprout inhibitor that extends the storage life of potatoes. Utilizing our global sourcing and regulatory capabilities, we identify and qualify manufacturers either producing the product or with knowledge of the chemistry necessary to produce the product, and then file an application with the U.S. EPA for a product registration. Aceto has an ongoing working relationship with manufacturers in China and India to determine which of the non-patented or generic, agricultural protection products they produce can be effectively marketed in the Western world. We have successfully brought numerous products to market. We have a strong pipeline, which includes future additions to our product portfolio. The combination of our global sourcing and regulatory capabilities makes the generic agricultural market a niche for us and we will continue to offer new product additions in this market. In the National Agricultural Statistics Services release dated June 30, 2017, the total crop acreage planted in the United States in 2017 decreased by .3% to 318 million acres from 319 million acres in 2016. The number of peanut acres planted in 2017 increased 8.8% from 2016 levels while sugarcane acreage harvested decreased 3.4% from 2016. In addition, the potato acreage harvested in 2017 increased approximately .7% from the 2016 level. We believe our main business strengths are sourcing, regulatory support, quality assurance, marketing and distribution. We distribute more than 1,100 chemical compounds used principally as finished products or raw materials in the pharmaceutical, nutraceutical, agricultural, coatings and industrial chemical industries. With business operations in ten countries, we believe that our global reach is distinctive in the industry, enabling us to source and supply quality products on a worldwide basis. Leveraging local professionals, we source approximately two-thirds of our products from Asia, buying from approximately 500 companies in China and 200 in India. In this MD&A, we explain our general financial condition and results of operations, including, among other things, the following: � factors that affect our business � our earnings and costs in the periods presented � changes in earnings and costs between periods � sources of earnings � the impact of these factors on our overall financial condition As you read this MD&A section, refer to the accompanying condensed consolidated statements of operations, which present the results of our operations for the three and six months ended December 31, 2017 and 2016. We analyze and explain the differences between periods in the specific line items of the condensed consolidated statements of operations. Critical Accounting Estimates and Policies As disclosed in our 2017 10-K, the discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations is based on our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. In preparing these financial statements, we were required to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities. We regularly evaluate our estimates including those related to allowances for bad debts, revenue recognition, partnered products, inventories, goodwill and indefinite-life intangible assets, long-lived assets, environmental and other contingencies, income taxes, stock-based compensation and purchase price allocation. We base our estimates on various factors, including historical experience, advice from outside subject-matter experts, and various assumptions that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances, which together form the basis for our making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates. Since June 30, 2017, there have been no significant changes to the assumptions and estimates related to those critical accounting estimates and policies. RESULTS OF OPERATIONS Six Months Ended December 31, 2017 Compared to Six Months Ended December 31, 2016 Net Sales by Segment Six months ended December 31, Comparison 2017 2017 2016 Over/(Under) 2016 % of % of $ % Segment Net sales Total Net sales Total Change Change Human Health $ 209,481 58.8 % $ 101,870 40.2 % $ 107,611 105.6 % Pharmaceutical Ingredients 70,205 19.7 77,432 30.5 (7,227 ) (9.3 ) Performance Chemicals 76,798 21.5 74,268 29.3 2,530 3.4 Net sales $ 356,484 100.0 % $ 253,570 100.0 % $ 102,914 40.6 % Gross Profit by Segment Six months ended December 31, Comparison 2017 2017 2016 Over/(Under) 2016 Gross % of Gross % of $ % Segment Profit Sales Profit Sales Change Change Human Health $ 47,545 22.7 % $ 31,124 30.6 % $ 16,421 52.8 % Pharmaceutical Ingredients 10,221 14.6 12,612 16.3 (2,391 ) (19.0 ) Performance Chemicals 16,187 21.1 17,908 24.1 (1,721 ) (9.6 ) Gross profit $ 73,953 20.7 % $ 61,644 24.3 % $ 12,309 20.0 %  Net Sales Net sales increased $102,914, or 40.6%, to $356,484 for the six months ended December 31, 2017, compared with $253,570 for the prior period. We reported sales increases in our Human Health and Performance Chemicals segments and a decrease in our Pharmaceutical Ingredients segment. Human Health Net sales for the Human Health segment increased by $107,611 for the six months ended December 31, 2017, to $209,481, which represents a 105.6% increase over net sales of $101,870 for the prior period. The primary reason for the increase is due to the acquisition of certain products and related assets of Citron and Lucid. Sales from the product acquisition of $113,850 are included in the six months ended December 31, 2017. In addition, there was a rise of $2,964 in sales of nutritional products, sold abroad, primarily by our German subsidiary. These increases in Human Health were offset in part, by a decline in sales of other Rising products due to continued pricing pressure, consolidation of customers and softer than expected contributions from new product launches. Pharmaceutical Ingredients Net sales for the Pharmaceutical Ingredients segment decreased $7,227 or 9.3% to $70,205 when compared to the prior period net sales of $77,432. The decrease in sales for this segment was due primarily to a decline in sales of domestic APIs of $4,119, mainly due to reduced orders of a customer-launched API, timing of sales of three products that are expected to be shipped in the third and fourth quarters of fiscal year 2018, delayed customer launch of an API, competition on another API and the discontinuance of two finish dosage drugs sold by our API business unit. These decreases in domestic APIs were offset in part by customer launches of certain new products. In addition, APIs sold abroad decreased $1,313, specifically in Germany. Sales of intermediates sold abroad have decreased $1,418 from the prior period primarily occurring in Germany, due to a supplier interruption and timing of orders for certain intermediate products that was pushed to the third and fourth quarters of fiscal 2018. Performance Chemicals Net sales for the Performance Chemicals segment was $76,798 for the six months ended December 31, 2017, representing an increase of $2,530 or 3.4%, from net sales of $74,268 for the prior period. The Specialty Chemicals business experienced a rise in sales of $8,029 over the prior period. The rise in Specialty Chemicals sales is partly due to an increase in domestic sales of $5,482, primarily from increased sales of agricultural and pigment intermediates as well as surface coatings. In addition, sales of specialty chemical products sold abroad, increased $2,547 over the prior period, predominantly at our subsidiary in Germany. Performance Chemicals sales were impacted by a $5,499 drop in sales of our agricultural protection products, predominantly from a decline in sales of a fungicide used to prevent disease on pecan crops and an herbicide used to treat weeds on rice crops. Gross Profit Gross profit increased $12,309 to $73,953 (20.7% of net sales) for the six months ended December 31, 2017, as compared to $61,644 (24.3% of net sales) for the prior period. Human Health Human Health segment's gross profit of $47,545 for the six months ended December 31, 2017 increased $16,421, or 52.8%, over the prior period. The gross margin of 22.7% was lower than the prior period's gross margin of 30.6%. The increase in Human Health's gross profit was partially related to gross profit of $25,321 on sales from the product acquisition, which is included in the six months ended December 31, 2017. This increase was partially offset by the decline of gross profit and gross margin on other Rising products, primarily driven by unfavorable product mix on certain products, increased competition and consolidation of customers. Pharmaceutical Ingredients Pharmaceutical Ingredients' gross profit of $10,221 for the six months ended December 31, 2017 decreased $2,391, or 19.0%, over the prior period. The gross margin of 14.6% was lower than the prior period's gross margin of 16.3%. The decrease in gross profit and gross margin was predominantly the result of the decrease in the sales volume of APIs sold domestically, as well as a drop in reorders of a certain API which typically yields a significantly higher gross margin. In addition, our international subsidiaries experienced an unfavorable product mix on API sales. Performance Chemicals Gross profit for the Performance Chemicals segment decreased to $16,187 for the six months ended December 31, 2017, versus $17,908 for the prior year, a decrease of $1,721 or 9.6%. The gross margin at 21.1% for the six months ended December 31, 2017 was lower than the prior year's gross margin of 24.1%. The decrease in gross profit was due to a $2,248 decline in gross profit for the Agricultural Protection Products business, as a result of the sales volume decline. The drop in gross margin from the prior period is a result of an unfavorable product mix on sales of specialty chemical products sold both domestically and in Germany. Selling, General and Administrative Expenses SG&A of $59,212 for the six months ended December 31, 2017 increased $10,117 or 20.6% from $49,095 reported for the prior period. As a percentage of sales, SG&A decreased to 16.6% for the six months ended December 31, 2017 versus 19.4% in the prior period. SG&A for the current period included $10,730 of amortization expense associated with the purchased intangible assets related to the product purchase. We recorded $4,064 of one-time costs associated with the separation of the Company's former Chief Executive Officer, including $2,017 of stock-based compensation. In addition, SG&A increased due to a $902 environmental charge related to Arsynco. The increase in SG&A is also due in part to approximately $644 of consulting services provided by former Citron and Lucid employees in connection with the Transition Services Agreement associated with the product purchase agreement, as well as approximately $1,274 of outsourcing fees related to the accounting processes of Rising Health and Acetris Health. SG&A for the prior period included $9,009 of transaction costs related to the product purchase agreement. Research and Development Expenses Research and development expenses ("R&D") increased to $3,737 for the six months ended December 31, 2017 compared to $2,391 for the prior period. R&D expenses represent investment in our generic finished dosage form product pipeline. The majority of the R&D expenses are milestone based, which was the primary cause for such increase and will likely cause fluctuation from quarter to quarter. Operating Income For the six months ended December 31, 2017 operating income was $11,004 compared to $10,158 in the prior period, an increase of $846 or 8.3%. Interest Expense Interest expense was $10,403 for the six months ended December 31, 2017, an increase of $5,501 or 112.2% from the prior period. The increase was primarily due to interest expense associated with the Second Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, which was entered into on December 21, 2016 to help fund our product acquisition, as well as additional interest associated with the $50,000 unsecured deferred payment related to the product acquisition. Provision for Income Taxes The effective tax rate for the six months ended December 31, 2017 increased to 918.2% compared to 34.6% for the prior period. In accordance with the TCJA, for the six months ended December 31, 2017, we recorded additional income tax expense of $13,909. In addition, we recorded $1,101 of additional income tax expense associated with net tax deficiencies under ASU 2016-09, which was . . . Feb 02, 2018 (c) 1995-2018 Cybernet Data Systems, Inc. title: 10-Q: ACETO CORP

Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations CAUTIONARY STATEMENT RELATING TO THE SAFE HARBOR PROVISIONS OF THE PRIVATE SECURITIES LITIGATION REFORM ACT OF 1995 This Quarterly Report contains forward-looking statements as that term is defined in the federal securities laws. The events described in forward-looking statements contained in this Quarterly Report may not occur. Generally, these statements relate to our business plans or strategies, projected or anticipated benefits or other consequences of our plans or strategies, financing plans, projected or anticipated benefits from acquisitions that we may make, or projections involving anticipated revenues, earnings or other aspects of our operating results or financial position, and the outcome of any contingencies. Any such forward-looking statements are based on current expectations, estimates and projections of management. We intend for these forward-looking statements to be covered by the safe-harbor provisions for forward-looking statements. Words such as "may," "will," "expect," "believe," "anticipate," "project," "plan," "intend," "estimate," and "continue," and their opposites and similar expressions are intended to identify forward-looking statements. We caution you that these statements are not guarantees of future performance or events and are subject to a number of uncertainties, risks and other influences, many of which are beyond our control that may influence the accuracy of the statements and the projections upon which the statements are based. Factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those set forth or implied by any forward-looking statement include, but are not limited to, our ability to remain competitive with competitors, risks associated with the generic product industry, dependence on a limited number of suppliers, risks associated with healthcare reform and reductions in reimbursement rates, difficulty in predicting revenue stream and gross profit, industry and market changes, the effect of fluctuations in operating results on the trading price of our common stock, risks associated with holding a significant amount of debt, inventory levels, reliance on outside manufacturers, risks of incurring uninsured environmental and other industry specific liabilities, governmental approvals and regulations, risks associated with hazardous materials, potential violations of government regulations, product liability claims, reliance on Chinese suppliers, potential changes to Chinese laws and regulations, potential changes to laws governing our relationships in India, fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, tax assessments, changes in tax rules, global economic risks, risk of unsuccessful acquisitions, effect of acquisitions on earnings, indemnification liabilities, terrorist activities, reliance on key executives, litigation risks, volatility of the market price of our common stock, changes to estimates, judgments and assumptions used in preparing financial statements, failure to maintain effective internal controls, and compliance with changing regulations, as well as other risks and uncertainties discussed in our reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including, but not limited to, our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended June 30, 2017 and other filings. Copies of these filings are available at www.sec.gov. Any one or more of these uncertainties, risks and other influences could materially affect our results of operations and whether forward-looking statements made by us ultimately prove to be accurate. Our actual results, performance and achievements could differ materially from those expressed or implied in these forward-looking statements. We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether from new information, future events or otherwise. NOTE REGARDING DOLLAR AMOUNTS In this quarterly report, all dollar amounts are expressed in thousands, except for per-share amounts. The following Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&A) is intended to provide the readers of our financial statements with a narrative discussion about our business. The MD&A is provided as a supplement to and should be read in conjunction with our financial statements and the accompanying notes. Executive Summary We are reporting net sales of $185,255 for the three months ended September 30, 2017, which represents a 44.7% increase from the $128,018 reported in the comparable prior period. Gross profit for the three months ended September 30, 2017 was $39,983 and our gross margin was 21.6% as compared to gross profit of $30,839 and gross margin of 24.1% in the comparable prior period. Our selling, general and administrative costs ("SG&A") for the three months ended September 30, 2017 was $31,149, an increase of $10,125 from what we reported in the prior period. Our net income decreased to $454, or $0.01 per diluted share, compared to net income of $4,385, or $0.15 per diluted share, in the prior period. As more fully described below, results for the quarter ended September 30, 2017 reflect the Company's acquisition in December 2016 of certain generic products and related assets of entities formerly known as Citron Pharma LLC ("Citron"), and its affiliate Lucid Pharma LLC ("Lucid"). Our financial position as of September 30, 2017 remains strong, as we had cash and cash equivalents and short-term investments of $75,148, working capital of $240,551 and shareholders' equity of $409,230. Our business is separated into three principal segments: Human Health, Pharmaceutical Ingredients and Performance Chemicals. Products that fall within the Human Health segment include finished dosage form generic drugs and nutraceutical products. Aceto sells generic prescription products and over-the-counter pharmaceutical products to leading wholesalers, chain drug stores, distributors and mass merchandisers. On December 21, 2016, Rising completed the acquisition of certain generic products and related assets of Citron and Lucid. Rising formed two subsidiaries to consummate the product acquisition - Rising Health, LLC (which acquired certain products and related assets of Citron) and Acetris Health, LLC (which acquired certain products and related assets of Lucid). Citron was a privately-held New Jersey-based pharmaceutical company focused on developing and marketing generic pharmaceutical products in partnership with leading generic pharmaceutical manufacturers based in India and the U.S. Lucid was a privately-held New Jersey-based generic pharmaceutical distributor specializing in providing cost-effective products to various agencies of the U.S. Federal Government including the Veterans Administration and the Defense Logistics Agency. Lucid serviced 18 national contracts with the Federal Government, nearly all of which have 5-year terms. The assets acquired in this transaction expand, complement, and strengthen our existing and future product offerings. In what has become a competitive generic drug business environment, one key for long-term success is having an ever-growing commercial portfolio of generic products, a strong internal drug development pipeline and capable, reliable manufacturing partners. This transaction adds significantly to the Rising business platform in all three crucial areas. We believe that, consistent with our strategy of expanding our portfolio of finished dosage form generic products through product development partnerships and acquisitions of late stage assets, abbreviated new drug applications ("ANDAs") and complementary generic drug businesses, this product acquisition significantly expanded our roster of commercialized products and pipeline of products under development. RESULTS OF OPERATIONS Three Months Ended September 30, 2017 Compared to Three Months Ended September 30, 2016 Net Sales by Segment Three months ended September 30, Comparison 2017 2017 2016 Over/(Under) 2016 % of % of $ % Segment Net sales Total Net sales Total Change Change Human Health $ 106,015 57.2 % $ 47,889 37.4 % $ 58,126 121.4 % Pharmaceutical Ingredients 36,576 19.8 40,616 31.7 (4,040 ) (9.9 ) Performance Chemicals 42,664 23.0 39,513 30.9 3,151 8.0 Net sales $ 185,255 100.0 % $ 128,018 100.0 % $ 57,237 44.7 % Gross Profit by Segment Three months ended September 30, Comparison 2017 2017 2016 Over/(Under) 2016 Gross % of Gross % of $ % Segment Profit Sales Profit Sales Change Change Human Health $ 24,647 23.2 % $ 14,205 29.7 % $ 10,442 73.5 % Pharmaceutical Ingredients 5,840 16.0 6,954 17.1 (1,114 ) (16.0 ) Performance Chemicals 9,496 22.3 9,680 24.5 (184 ) (1.9 ) Gross profit $ 39,983 21.6 % $ 30,839 24.1 % $ 9,144 29.7 %  Net Sales Net sales increased $57,237, or 44.7%, to $185,255 for the three months ended September 30, 2017, compared with $128,018 for the prior period.
